—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. On or about 26 May this year, did the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs receive a detailed brief from the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) about the Woden Town Club and the Commission's present and proposed funding for it? —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. How much revenue does the Government expect to raise from the planned removal of the special income tax exemption currently enjoyed by the goldmining industry? Secondly, can the Minister provide the Senate with any information regarding the distributional implications of that measure?

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —In the May economic statement the estimate was published that the revenue to be derived from the ending of the tax exemption for gold would be around $70m in the financial year 1991-92 and around $300m per year thereafter. As far as I know, there is no good reason to substantially vary those estimates.

answer.para: There are two pieces of information about the distribution which I think it is important to stress. The first is that a substantial beneficiary of the present arrangements is the United States Treasury. Some 35 per cent or 36 per cent of the Australian goldmining industry is in foreign ownership, or was in 1984-85, and the great majority of that in the United States. Because the United States is a country with which Australia has a double taxation agreement, tax which would otherwise have been paid by a US company operating in Australia, but which was not paid, is automatically levied by the United States Treasury, and the present arrangements transfer from the pockets of the taxpayers of Australia up to, or as much as, $70m to the United States Treasury.

It is a matter of historical record that the Reagan Administration did a considerable amount of economic damage in the United States, but it has not yet made the United States a Third World country deserving of foreign aid. That is what the present gold taxation arrangements amount to. It is a foreign aid program from Australia to the United States, among other things. Up to $70m--

talk.start.para: —They are getting foreign aid to the extent of $150m a year.

—I know very well what the honourable senator's private views are on this matter. Senator Stone believes, exactly as I do, that the present arrangements for the exemption of the goldmining industry from taxation are an outrage. He believed that throughout his career in the Treasury, and it is one of the things he has always been correct about. The $70m is particularly relevant in view of the letter which the Leader of the Opposition wrote on this subject a bit over 12 months ago, when he said, `We have a particular concern about the effect a gold tax would have on our balance of payments'. Well, the effect of not having one, of exempting goldmining from ordinary company taxation, is to add $70m or there- abouts to our current account deficit, the $70m of revenue which is still collected from the companies concerned but which is collected in Washington instead of Australia.

answer.para: One other beneficiary of the existing arrangements is Elders IXL Ltd. In the Age of 5 October this year Elder IXL inserted an advertisement which stated, `Elders Resources is now among the top ten gold producers in Australia'. So Elders IXL will have to pay some tax in the future which it has not paid in the past, just as those American companies which hold equity in Australian goldmines will have to pay their tax in future in Australia instead of paying it in Washington, which will take that amount off our current account deficit and our foreign debt.

I was hoping-I suppose I should have known better-that even as late as this morning commonsense and some commitment to consistency, sense, or dare I say, even patriotism would have broken out in the Opposition Party room meeting and that it might have rolled the executive. Unfortunately, I understand that is not so. But it is still irrelevant because I believe the Australian Democrats will be supporting the Government's measure as, of course, they should because not even the Democrats fall for the self-interested bleating of companies such as Elders Resources Ltd and those assorted spivs in Western Australia who have been running this campaign for as long as anybody can remember, but running it particularly virulently over the last two or three years.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. What is more demeaning to women than the X-rated video industry which thrives in this city with the legislative support of her Government? How can she advocate improvement in the status of women when her Government condones the exploitation of women in this way? When the Government sets such a poor example in matters within its control, how can it expect different standards from others?

—I think it is interesting that one of the so-called wets of the Liberal Party is asking this question. I wonder-although I would not embarrass him by asking-what Senator Peter Baume's view is on this question. The important thing to realise when one is standing up for the recognition of the status of women is what women regard as important in the public arena. What women regard as important in the private arena, that is, in the privacy of their own homes and in their relationships with their partners, is entirely a matter for those women. I see no contradiction whatsoever in representing the needs and aspirations of Australian women in terms of public policy and leaving those decisions that relate to privacy entirely to Australian women. I think it is interesting that this question should come from a so-called small `l' liberal. Given the debate on the Australia Card and the importance of privacy, it is rather surprising that Senator Hill would be the one to raise this question.
—That is a terrible answer. Answer the question. You are letting Australian womanhood down.

—I think it would be best if Senator Boswell were to talk to representatives of women's organisations about this question. This question relates entirely to privacy, and it is certainly not in the domain of government to interfere in the lives of Australian men and women in the privacy of their own bedrooms.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Recent articles in the press-in particular, one in the Age of 19 October this year headed `Swings and Roundabouts'-have described problems of waste disposal around the world and some very strange, if not very scary, proposals to deal with it. Can the Minister tell the Senate what processes or proposals are in place in this country to deal with Australian waste, particularly industrial chemical waste, and what consultations have taken place with the State governments to ensure that industrial chemical waste is being handled in an environmentally secure manner?

answer.ministerial: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES
answer.speaker: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

talk.start.para: —I can give Senator Crowley some idea of that. Australia's obligations in respect of dealing with chemical waste derive mainly from our being a party to the London Dumping Convention, which is the International Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter. We have given effect to that by the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act, which, hopefully, successfully monitors our dumping of waste. The States have been extensively consulted over that legislation. Provision is made in the legislation for arrangements to be made allowing States to administer sea dumping in accordance with the terms of the Convention. The terms of the Convention are reasonably strict, and they apply within the coastal waters of each State. That is the provision that exists. So far no arrangements are in place, but the exchange of memoranda of understanding that we are about to sign with Tasmania will be a great leap forward, and hopefully we can follow on with other States.

answer.para: If one goes away from the sea and looks at what we do on land, the important thing to look at is intractable wastes, which present quite a problem. There has for some time been consultation between the governments of New South Wales, Victoria and the Commonwealth on the siting of an incinerator which can deal with intractable wastes. It seems that the logical thing to do-and the Australian Environment Council has been looking at it for some years-is to site such a facility on the east coast where most of the chemicals to which Senator Crowley is referring would be either produced or used. The first draft of a report from that committee will be released shortly, but having talked about it with the New South Wales Minister for Environment, Mr Moore, only a few weeks ago, I think it is reasonable to say that we are getting very close to naming the site where we can establish our incinerator.

talk.start.para: —You have your environmental shirt on again!
—Yes; the shirt is both smooth and bright, which distinguishes it from Senator Bishop in a number of ways.

—I did not think Senator Puplick would object to that. Hopefully we can get on with naming the site, because that is something we badly need to do. It is long overdue in this country, and hopefully we will address that question in the next few months.

—I address a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. As the Minister is no doubt aware, a Deputy President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, Mr Justice Staples, has been given no work on the Commission since 1986 and very little prior to that since 1980. As no action has been taken to remove Mr Justice Staples from his office in accordance with normal procedures, can the Minister explain why the Deputy President has been treated in this way, bearing in mind that Mr Justice Staples has repeatedly stated his willingness to fulfil the duties of his office? Does the Minister agree, or would he if he were allowed to, that this disgraceful, longstanding state of affairs warrants an inquiry? Is the Government willing to accede to Mr Justice Staples's request that a joint select committee be established to conduct such an inquiry?

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —Like most other senators I understand the question because Mr Justice Staples wrote to members of the Senate and of the House of Representatives quite recently. I understand that the position is largely as the honourable senator describes it. However, the Government does not support the idea of a parliamentary inquiry into this matter. There are a number of reasons for that and a number of considerations need to be borne in mind. The independence of the judiciary is a long established principle in democratic countries which observe the doctrine of separation of powers. This is enshrined in the Constitution which, amongst other things, limits how and in what circumstances a judge may be removed from office.

answer.para: Under section 72 of the Constitution Federal judges may not be removed, except by the Governor-General in Council on an address from both Houses of Parliament in the same session, praying for such removal on the grounds of proved misbehaviour or incapacity. There are a number of good reasons why this should be so. Basically, they are that confidence in the judicial system depends on its actual and perceived independence. I make the point that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is not a court for the purposes of the Constitution.

talk.start.para: —Or any other purposes.

—Even so, it is self-evident that the Commission, which deals with such vitally important and sensitive matters in the area of labour relations, should have its independence protected. Senator Stone's interjection might have come later. Anything else would undermine its authority and effectiveness. Parliament has accordingly provided under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 for presidential members to have the same rank, status and precedence as a judge of the Federal Court. Legally qualified members such as Mr Justice Staples have the designation of a judge. More importantly, the Act also provides that presidential members are only to be removed in the same way and on the same grounds as apply to a Federal judge.

answer.para: In addition, just as such courts are responsible for the arrangement of their business, the Commission is responsible for the organisation of its work. For example, the Chief Judge of the Federal Court of Australia is empowered to arrange for the constitution of the court with the hearing of matters before it. Similarly, the President of the Arbitration Commission is responsible for the allocation of matters before the Commission. Neither the Parliament nor the Executive, in the Government's view, should interfere with this process unless there are clear grounds for questioning whether any basis exists for the removal of the holder of an office for proved misbehaviour or incapacity. These are the criteria. That is not the case here and there is no useful purpose to be served by a parliamentary inquiry.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his answer and would have to say that just as the Minister knew of Mr Justice Staples's position before I asked the question, I knew the constitutional situation before he gave the answer. I agree, and I think everybody in this chamber agrees, that the judiciary should not be puppets of governments, although governments appoint them. Nor should judges be victimised by governments. Nonetheless we clearly have an unsatisfactory position here.
—Order! Would you ask the supplementary question, Senator Haines?

—Yes, Mr President. Mr Justice Staples is a judge. He is being paid as a judge. He is being given no work as a judge. I ask the Minister: Given that any changes can only be made to the Constitution by referendum, which is hardly an exercise the Government is going to undertake or win if it does, what else does the Minister suggest could be done to avoid a repeat or a continuation of the current highly unsatisfactory situation?

—Senator Haines is quite right to say that this is not an issue of such compelling importance as to lead the Government into suggesting an amendment to the Constitution. There would be very obvious sensitivities in such a proposal which would have an impact on the independence of the judiciary as a whole. I believe there would be no advantage in taking that step even if it were felt that a Constitutional referendum were justified. In regard to the further part of Senator Haines's question as to what might be done about Mr Justice Staples's position, let me say that I believe it to be unique in the judiciary in Australia at present, and I have nothing to add to what I said in the earlier part of my answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Is it not a fact that in the Government's explanatory memorandum to the Classification of Publications Ordinance, X-rated videos are described as `hard core pornography'? Was the decision by Caucus this morning in effect a response to the views expressed by all State governments and by the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material opposing the continued distribution of X-rated classification videos? Was the decision this morning in effect a rejection of the recommendations of all the States and of the majority of the Joint Select Committee?

answer.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: —The deliberations of the Caucus this morning are a matter for members of the Parliamentary Labor Party, but I think it is proper for me to indicate that the real concerns of the majority of the Parliamentary Labor Party in that Caucus were of a more positive kind. What came through in the discussions was a real concern that out in the community there was a confusion and a misunderstanding of what exactly fell into the category of X-rated videos, particularly compared with R-rated videos. Indeed, I know from correspondence that I have received and certainly from conversations I have had out in the community that many members of the community do not understand that X-rated material deals with explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults, certainly not children, but does not include any depiction suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind. Senators would agree that out in the community, as one talks to people or as people make representations, there is indeed a confusion whereby the question of violence invariably comes into the conversation. Many of those with whom members and senators have conversations seem to think that in X-rated videos there is a depiction of violence, which is not the case.

answer.para: In that situation the Parliamentary Labor Party considered that it would be best serving the community at this stage if it sought not only a clarification for the benefit of the community of those distinctions between X-rated and R-rated videos, but also sought to improve and tighten up the regulations relating to the depiction of violence in videos. Indeed, I believe the community would be well served by a focused attention being given to the question of the depiction of violence in videos. I know from the setting up of the National Committee on Violence, which attracted some publicity some three or four weeks ago, that most of the positive letters and remarks I have heard concerning the committee's examination of violence had to do with the possibility of that committee suggesting ways in which the depiction of violence could be eradicated from so much of the viewing of particularly young people who are at a formative stage. It is in relation to that confusion that I believe the decision of the Parliamentary Labor Party needs to be put in context.

talk.start.para: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, as I am further confused. Is the Minister saying that all the State Attorneys-General, all the State Ministers responsible for censorship, the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth and the majority of members of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material did not know what was contained in X? Is that the basis of this morning's recommendation? I ask the Minister to respond to my questions, which he has not responded to: Firstly, is it a fact that in the Government's own legislation this material is described officially as hard-core pornography, and, secondly, is it a fact that the decision that was taken in effect is the rejection of the request by all the States that this material be refused classification for the home video entertainment market?

—I have nothing further to add to my answer. The fact is that the Caucus made its decision on the grounds which I have indicated. There was no reflection on the decisions taken or points of view expressed by State or Territory Attorneys-General or those who made a contribution to the various parliamentary reports which have been tabled in this Parliament. Rather, as I say, what motivated the Parliamentary Labor Party's decision at this stage was the sense that out in the community generally there was a confusion and it was best to address the question of the confusion and the depiction of violence as a major priority rather than undertaking at this stage the course of action suggested by Senator Harradine.

—I refer the Minister for Justice to the proposed deportation from the United States (US) of the alleged Latvian nazi war criminal, Konrad Kalejs. Is it a fact that although Mr Kalejs is an Australian citizen, he has been a resident of the US for nearly 30 years? Has the Australian Government requested his extradition? Has there been any communication with the American Office of Special Investigations by the Government or any of its agencies concerning the timing of the deportation order? Does the Minister know why the United States is deporting Mr Kalejs rather than trying him in the United States for his alleged war crimes?

answer.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: —Konrad Kalejs has been a resident in the United States since 1959 but, as I understand it, he was granted Australian citizenship in August 1957. It is a fact that he has been found in United States deportation proceedings to have assisted in the persecution of Jewish and other civilians while a member of the Arajs Kommando in nazi-occupied Latvia. This allegation was dealt with by Mr Menzies at pages 102 to 103 of his published report on the entry of suspected war criminals into Australia. Senator Hamer asked whether the Australian Government has sought the extradition of Mr Kalejs. I believe that that shows a misunderstanding. It is the United States authorities which are seeking to deport Mr Kalejs. That seems to be the way in which the United States Government has chosen to deal with the presence of suspected war criminals in the United States.

answer.para: It should be emphasised-obviously, I do not want to do anything that would be prejudicial to Mr Kalejs should he be deported and returned to Australia-that United States deportation proceedings are civil in nature and the standard of proof is accordingly different from that which would apply under our proposed legislation where the standard is a criminal one requiring proof beyond reasonable doubt. It is important, for Mr Kalejs's sake, if you like, to emphasise those two different standards of proof and the fact that any trial to be conducted in Australia under the proposed legislation-that is, the War Crimes Amendment Bill, which is before the Senate at the moment-would be conducted in a quite different way according to the ordinary standards of proof pertaining to criminal trials in this country.

Senator Hamer asked whether there has been any discussion between government agencies both in the United States and Australia as to the timing of the deportation proceedings. I have no information as to that. I will seek to find an answer, if indeed there is one. But I would imagine that the matter has been dealt with in the normal processes of the United States judicial procedures.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer to the Minister's statement that the United States has chosen to deport suspected war criminals rather than put them on trial. Is it not a fact that the United States has no war crimes Act, and is not proposing to have one for legal and constitutional reasons; and that it is not prepared to enact a retrospective law allowing United States courts to try alleged crimes committed in foreign countries against non-Americans? Are not the Americans unwilling to try war criminals themselves, instead of deporting alleged war criminals for trial in countries which do not have the same restraints?

—The United States Government policy is a matter for its judgment and determination, and I understand it to be generally along the lines indicated in Senator Hamer's question. Quite clearly that differs from the point of view of the Australian Government. Indeed, rather than Australia deporting those in our midst who have allegations made against them-and certain suspects are said to be in this country, as was indicated by Mr Menzies in his report-to jurisdictions where the criminal justice system is not as adequate as ours, it has been the decision of the Australian Government that such persons should be tried in Australian courts, but according to the very same principles and standards as would apply in any other criminal trial held in an Australian jurisdiction.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence on the floor of the Senate of athletes and officials from the Australian Olympic and Paralympic teams. —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Aged Care. Will the Minister inform the Senate of initiatives that the Government is taking in order to tackle the problems of homelessness?

answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —The Government recognises that where homelessness occurs it is usually a symptom of a more serious problem. It maybe a problem associated with chronic unemployment in some form, extended illness, domestic violence, family breakdown or something of that nature. Because of the Government's recognition of that problem we introduced in 1984-85 the supported accommodation assistance program and the crisis accommodation program. I point out that the Fraser Government did not have a similar sort of program to help vulnerable people. Indeed, in that Government's last year of office it spent $14m on homelessness compared with our expenditure of $85m this year.
—Rubbish!

—That is not rubbish; them's the facts. The honourable senator might find it very inconvenient for those facts to be publicly revealed; nonetheless, publicly revealed they are. We reviewed the supported accommodation assistance program and on 3 November the Prime Minister, together with the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Mr Staples, announced a new package which will offer $40m to the States over the next three years, on top of the record expenditure that we are already providing. That extra money will enable 150 new services to be instituted over the next three years. It will assist over 15,000 people in need and it is aimed at stabilising people's lives and putting them back on their feet so that they can go on in the community. It is a priority of this Government under the social justice strategy.

answer.para: It is worth while noting that since this Government has been in office 220,000 households have had accommodation in public housing, 70,000 home loans have been made to low income earners and 70,000 rental dwellings have been provided. Of course, this sits alongside the other macro-economic successes chalked up to this Government in terms of one million extra new jobs, child care, Medicare and all of the other assistance that we have provided to tackle the problems of people in real need.

question.speaker: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

talk.start.para: —I refer the Minister for Finance to a statement which was made by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, and the then Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Evans, on 16 December 1986, when they announced that the Government had decided not to remove the exemption available to the goldmining industry. In that statement his colleagues say:

question.para: Government had concluded that the importance of encouraging active exploration and development, and of maximising production and the consequent export income generated by the gold mining industry, outweighed the arguments in favour of removing the industry's longstanding tax exemption.
I ask: Were the arguments advanced by his colleagues rational and what circumstances have changed to justify the Government's decision to change its attitude to the taxing of gold?

answer.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —This question, which I regard as another free kick in the square or a full toss down the leg side, emphasises the point I was making yesterday: these tax bludgers in the gold mining industry, who have bludged on the rest of Australian industry, which pays company tax, and bludged on the rest of the Australian taxpayers, probably with the exception of a few in the Liberal Party, have polluted Australian politics for as long as anybody can remember. They have blackmailed politicians. I am very proud to be a member of the Government which has finally stood up to the spivs and bludgers who have bludged on the rest of Australian industry and Australian taxpayers since 1924.

answer.para: I am very grateful to Senator Durack for asking this question because I have in front of me a comment piece written by the Senate leader, Senator Chaney, which appeared in the Australian of Friday, 17 February 1984. It is a comment piece, not something that is said by some politician who gets backed or painted into a corner or is bailed up by the press and, having a microphone shoved down his neck, is asked, `What do you think of this?'. This is a comment piece-it was volunteered. He said:
The special taxation situation of the gold industry is one of those features of Australian tax law which is not distinguished by its economic logic.
That is a mild understatement. It is somewhat of an understatement which in the next couple of paragraphs he corrected, saying:
Since gold no longer has any particular monetary significance, it is a commodity like any other, its price being determined by the market.
and this is the good bit-
Neither the magic and mythology of its history nor economic logic justify the special treatment of gold.

He was, of course, absolutely right. I hope that somebody in the Liberal Party will send me, anonymously of course, an account of the attitude Senator Chaney took on this matter in the party room this morning. I certainly hope that somebody does, just as somebody was kind enough to post to me in a Senate envelope, through the internal mail, addressed to me and marked `Confidential', the little account of the dirty tricks that Senator Bishop was organising in a pre-selection struggle with Senator Puplick a few weeks ago. I am very grateful to whichever member of the Opposition it was who sent that to me. I invite someone in the Opposition to send me another anonymous note about whether the position that Senator Chaney adopted in the party room and at the executive meeting was the one he put forward in 1984 or the politically oppportunistic proposition for which the majority of the Liberal Party and, so far as its Western Australian members are concerned, under duress from the spivs and bludgers who have been running this campaign in Western Australia in a particularly virulent way in the last few years--

talk.start.para: —What about poor old Gareth? You are embarrassing Gareth.
—Senator Boswell is interjecting. I have said to you before, Ronnie: the last time I saw a mouth like that it had a hook in it.
—Order!
—I withdraw that, Mr President.
—Order! I suggest that the Minister is ranging very wide in his answer to the question.

—I will not say any more about hooks. The fact is that, because this lobby has been so virulent for such a long period and has polluted Australian politics and policy making to the extent that it has, the history of political parties on this issue is riddled with contradictions. For example, I remember a State colleague of Senator Boswell addressing the Northern Australian Development Conference in Kununurra-I think it was in 1986--

—Now that the Minister has stopped talking about me, I take a point of order, Mr President, and say that you have already drawn the Minister's attention to the fact that he has given a very lengthy answer to this question. He is clearly debating it. It is an abuse of Question Time and I think you should call him to order and allow someone else to ask a question.
—Order! I ask Senator Walsh to stick to the question that Senator Durack asked him.
—I shall wind up very quickly, Mr President. But, relevant to Senator Boswell's interjection, if the National Party of Queensland thinks it is a bad idea to tax gold, why is it doing it?
—I take a point of order, Mr President. I ask the Minister to withdraw the statement and the obvious imputation in his claim that Senator Evans had succumbed to blackmail by bludgers.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask the Minister to get back to the question he was asked and I ask, by way of assistance to the Minister in that regard: Is the Minister saying in that longwinded reply that the arguments that were advanced by his colleagues on behalf of the Government, of which he was also a member in December 1986, were not rational? Is he also saying in his reply that he and his colleagues were blackmailed and bludgeoned-or some such phrase that he used; blackmail was one of the words he used-by the industry in December 1986?

—I repeat that I am proud to be a member of a government-the only government in the lifetime of probably anybody presently sitting in the Senate-which has had the courage to stand up to this lobby and to knock it over.
—I have never seen such a collection of miserable looking wimps.
—Order! I call Senator Vallentine.
—Mr President, I think you heard the Leader of the Government. I think he should withdraw.
—Senator Chaney, you have used that phrase many times in here.
—You keep out of it, Richardson.
—Order! Senator Walters. I do not regard the use of the word wimp as unparliamentary. It is used very many times in the chamber.

—My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I draw the Minister's attention to recent statements made by two well respected Australian Labor Party backbenchers, John Langmore and Gordon Bilney, calling on the Government to make a fresh start in its policies on poverty in the Third World by at least lifting aid to the level it was at when Labor took office. Given that the level of aid was then 0.51 per cent of the gross domestic product (GDP), that the Government originally promised to increase aid to the United Nations' recommended target of 0.7 per cent of GDP and that currently it is 0.36 per cent of GDP, is the Government now prepared to adopt a new strategy and start to significantly increase aid levels? I also ask whether the Minister is considering Mr Langmore's suggestion of making a comprehensive annual statement to Parliament on the Third World and, with the Treasurer, of getting Australia to play a more significant role in advocating new policies for handling Third World debt. Finally, I ask whether the Minister has read Mr Langmore's article on overseas aid in the Australian Financial Review of 31 October? Does he agree with the proposal that the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) should be added to his portfolio and that Australia, like most other Western countries, could also have a Ministry for overseas development.

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —It needs to be appreciated that there is substantial provision for aid in the 1988-89 Budget-in fact, for $1,093.5m worth. That is an increase of 1.2 per cent in real terms on 1987-88. It creates a situation where outlays are 0.36 per cent of gross national product, which is slightly above the average for developed country donors which are members of the Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. That is not to say that it is necessarily a figure that I am comfortable with or completely happy with or would not wish to see increased. But let us put it in perspective and acknowledge that this this is the first real increase in the aid budget since 1984-85 and it does, in fact, constitute a bottoming out of recent aid budget declines.

answer.para: So far as the general issue of poverty is concerned AIDAB has embarked on a study of ways to enhance the focus of poverty in the aid program. As announced by my predecessor at the World Development Debate in July, AIDAB is involving the Australian Council for Overseas Aid in that study. On the question of debt, to which Senator Vallentine referred, the Government supports the case by case kind of growth oriented strategy for debt resolution, noting that each situation should continue to be handled with care, showing sensitivity to effect on the well-being of low income groups. In this respect, we certainly endorse the catalytic role of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in the debt resolution process. I have taken seriously the suggestion of my colleague Mr Langmore. There are some attractions in principle with his proposal for a comprehensive annual statement on aid and its implications for world poverty. Certainly I will give consideration to following that suggestion.

As to the view in the article-at least in the form in which it was printed; I do not know whether it is in the form in which it was written-that Senator Vallentine has picked up with alacrity that AIDAB should become part of my portfolio, it is the case that it is already part of my portfolio and has been from the outset. I do not think that a separate aid Ministry is a realistic proposition, certainly not in an environment where we are engaged, in the interest of rational public administration, in amalgamating Ministries rather than further splitting them apart. Moreover, the provision of overseas aid is an integral part of any country's foreign policy. Its administration by a separate bureau within my Department ensures that it does nonetheless receive the kind of individual attention, both in policy and in administration, that something of this significance deserves. It also ensures that aid issues receive the priority the Government certainly attaches to the important humanitarian issues that are involved in them.

question.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —I preface my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs by drawing his attention to yesterday's Hansard. He may wish to affirm or correct the last sentence that is shown in his answer to Senator Brownhill. After a long answer detailing the many inquiries that the Government now has into its appalling Aboriginal affairs administration, he said:

question.para: Indeed, the fullest possibly inquiry will not be undertaken by means of the mechanisms which I have indicated.

That may be a misprint but I just draw it to his attention. As to my question, the Age newspaper reports, nearly accurately, that there are six separate inquiries into Aboriginal matters. It is not quite correct because there are seven. The Muirhead Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody has been left out. Four inquiries are being promoted by the Government and two by this Parliament. I ask the Minister: Is he prepared to concede today that there are significant problems, continuing real difficulties, in terms of the impact of this Government's policies on the Aboriginal community? Does he accept that the fact that there have been at least 13 further deaths in custody since the commencement of the Muirhead inquiry suggests that all is not well and that a difficult situation is, if anything, getting worse? Does he accept that the decline in Aboriginal employment is an indication that policies are not effective? To which of the inquiries instituted by the Government should those people who wish to put views on the damage being done to Aboriginal communities and individuals by this Government's policies submit that evidence? Which appropriate inquiry will have the task of receiving that sort of evidence?

answer.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: —I find it extraordinary that Senator Chaney should bring up the question of deaths in custody in this relation, when it is the fact--
—What do you think it is a sign of-success, do you?

—No, I do not think it is a sign of success; I think it is a great human tragedy, and it was this Government which addressed the matter by setting up a royal commission in order to inquire into not only the particular deaths involved but the underlying causes, and it is in relation to that fuller report by Mr Justice Muirhead that I expect that we would as an Australian community-with the support of the Federal Government, but at its initiative, and the State governments and the Northern Territory Government-reach a situation where those deaths of fellow Australians in custody and in detention will not occur with the same frequency and in the same way as it appears that they have been and are-yes, tragically-still occurring. Indeed, it is this Government, not only by setting up the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, but through other mechanisms such as the Australian Police Ministers Council, which has taken the initiative in addressing a problem which has been a shameful state of affairs in Australian society over many years, but particularly in the last several years.

answer.para: Of course, Senator Chaney made some point about the typographical error in an answer in the Daily Hansard. I hope that Hansard will correct that. I regard that as a completely trivial matter and I hope that it will be remedied to give the full sense obviously of the whole of the preceding answer. Senator Chaney pointed out that several inquiries are being undertaken, including the inquiry of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs.

talk.start.para: —Legislation.

—It is not only legislation; it is a wider inquiry than that, Senator. The Committee is a forum in which many of the sorts of matters which the honourable senator says should be raised can obviously be raised, because what he is talking about and alleging is widespread and gross maladministration, mismanagement and even corruption in a way which leads to a very severe detrimental impact on the Aboriginal community of Australia. Having sat through the various hours upon hours of Estimates committee hearings into the expenditures under the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio, I must say that whilst areas of concern were raised and in some instances correctly emphasised as matters that ought to be a cause of concern and further investigated-that is what the Government has undertaken to do with no stone unturned in those investigations-nevertheless, what was also portrayed was a very genuine effort by this Government to help many of the Aboriginal communities around Australia in their desired to achieve a healthy, productive, self-determining situation which has been not their lot due to many decades-indeed two centuries-of mistreatment and neglect. Much of the expenditure under the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio has been very well focused and properly directed to the Aboriginal people and the improvement of their situation within our Australian society.

answer.para: So, whilst indeed there have been some programs which have gone astray and where the impact of certain policies and programs has not been such as to bear the fruit that might have been desired by those initiating or undertaking them, nevertheless I do not think it is fair to paint a picture of this Government or, indeed, preceding Federal governments-after all, this is a process where one builds on the achievements of preceding governments-as having not shown a commitment which in many instances has brought about an improvement in the situation of many Aboriginal Australians.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. As in his answer yesterday, the Minister diverted the question onto the issue of maladministration. My question did not relate to maladministration, it related to failures of policy. It is not being claimed by the Opposition that all policy is being maladministered. Clearly there are areas where it is not, but there are many apparent policy failures. I ask the Minister: To which of the Government inquiries does he say evidence can appropriately be directed, not on maladministration but policy failure?

answer.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: —I believe there are many forums available for those persons who wish to make suggestions as to policy as opposed to maladministration or mismanagement, which has been the tenor of the whole debate in this chamber, in the other place and, indeed, in the community over the last several weeks. For him to say that I have not been alert to the fact that the whole debate has been about policy over the last few weeks, I believe misrepresents the situation as it has developed, and which has been the focus of community and parliamentary attention over the last few weeks.

answer.para: Policy matters have a forum, I believe, in the Senate Select Committee into the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, which is looking at the very fundamental policy of how we as a community provide for the special needs and opportunities which will improve the lot of the Aboriginal people of Australia. There is one very obvious forum, and it is perhaps best that the fundamental questions of policy are thrashed out in the committees of this Parliament and in the parliamentary chamber itself. The Government has undertaken the fullest possible inquiries, in relation to the implementation of policy, and they will be undertaken with vigour.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. What funding was given to community legal centres in this year's Budget, and what value does the Government place on those centres? Is their future assured?

answer.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: —I can answer the last question with a very affirmative response, because in a person such as Barney Cooney, who has taken a very keen interest in community legal centres since their inception, not only in Victoria but around Australia, those legal centres have a most able advocate. For example, at meetings of the Caucus legal and administrative committee he continually puts their case in a most vigorous way. In the last Budget an amount of $2,355,000 was allocated, and this represents an increase of 5.8 per cent on the preceding year's Budget. I must say that the Minister for Finance has played his part in ensuring that these centres maintain their ability to provide a very important service to the persons in the community whom they serve by being placed in those centres of population where access to legal advice is not otherwise readily available, and certainly not in the friendly, accessible and low cost way in which it is available from the 59 community legal centres throughout Australia.

answer.para: Tremendously dedicated work is undertaken in those centres by the members of the community legal centres who are employed either full time or part time. They provide an opportunity and a venue for legal practitioners to provide free advice through many hours of voluntary service as professionals. So the money put in by the Commonwealth and matched, sometimes only in part-in some instances it is not matched at all-by State legal aid commissions, is multiplied many times by the legal practitioners' services which are provided free of charge within the venue. The dedicated workers at these community legal centres not only provide advice in a way which is most appropriate to those who come in their doors, whether it is about tenancy or other matters, but also they produce booklets and easy guides to the law with are also of great use to persons in the community. All in all, the community legal centres provide a very important part of fulfilling the social justice strategy of the Australian Labor Party and, within the legal aid provisions of the Attorney-General's portfolio, I believe they have a most significant role to play.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —by leave-During Question Time Senator Walsh chose to quote a couple of sentences out of an article which I wrote on 17 February 1984 and which was published in the Australian newspaper on the subject of a tax on goldmining. The paragraph he quoted included the sentence:

speech.para: The special taxation situation of the gold industry is one of those features of Australian tax law which is not distinguished by its economic logic.

Not surprisingly, Senator Walsh left out a great deal of what I had to say, including the words which preceded that sentence, in which I quoted Sir Charles Court as once suggesting that not all problems were solved by logic. In that article I quoted Senator Walsh and a then recent statement of his on the issue of gold, and I would like to read a number of those sentences. I said, after quoting Senator Walsh as saying that there was negligible rational economic justification for gold's tax-free status:

Yet he also remarked subjecting gold to normal corporate taxation would nearly halve the return on shareholders' funds, investment would fall, and employment may be prejudiced. He went on to say, without commitment, a rent tax on gold would not affect investment.
I wrote, a few sentences later:

The key thing which must be borne in mind is that under any rational tax regime investors and producers should have some guarantee of consistency and predictability. That is particularly true of gold where there has been substantial new investment in recent years.
He went on to say:
There are strong arguments against changing the rules in a way which would invalidate investment decisions taken in good faith on the basis of the existing rules.
After some discussion about the alternatives that were available, I finished the article by saying:
Of course, rigorous logic might lead them-
that is, the rationalists in the Government-

in another direction altogether. For if the privileged tax status of gold mining is maintained to preserve investment, profit and employment, why logically should we not increase investment, profit and employment in the rest of the mining sector by reducing taxation? Some will see that as a logical reductio ad absurdum, but it's not as silly as it sounds.

When one hears those additional passages which, as I say, not surprisingly were not quoted by Senator Walsh because they would have spoilt his misrepresentation of what I had written, it is quite clear that the case I was putting was one which canvassed those matters but which made it quite clear that there are arguments both in terms of not invalidating existing investment decisions and in terms of maintaining investment, profit and employment. It is fairly typical of Senator Walsh that he quoted so selectively from that article.

speech.speaker: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The annual report of the Australian National Gallery for 1987-88 records the very considerable success which the Australian National Gallery had last year. It indicates, for example, that the highest ever attendance was achieved at the Gallery's travelling exhibitions throughout Australia. It indicates the successful launch of the Australian National Gallery Foundation and its receipt of almost $2.5m in donations and pledges. I understand that, in one of the taxation Bills to come before the chamber shortly, tax deductability will be provided for donations to that fund. It indicates the staging of the fourth major international exhibition, attracting almost 350,000 visitors to the three venues around Australia, the acquisition through purchase and donation of over 2,000 works of art for the national collection and the generation of over $3m from merchandise sales.

It is interesting to indicate the flow-on effect that activities such as those undertaken by the Australian National Gallery have for the Australian Capital Territory. For example, the Old Masters-New Visions exhibition, which was part of the Phillips Collection, drew more visitors to its eight weeks showing in Canberra than any travelling display of that collection in the United States of America. It generated over $20m additional tourist expenditure to the national capital during the course of its eight weeks visit. I think it is interesting therefore to put this within the context of the way in which this Government has been effectively starving and crippling the development of museums and national collecting institutions through the uncertainty introduced as a result of the internal secret review of museums and collecting institutions undertaken jointly by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and the Department of Finance. It is all very well for colleagues on the Australian Labor Party side, such as Senator McMullan, to indicate the extent to which they are great supporters of the National Gallery and the National Museum of Australia when, in fact, it is the deliberate policy of this Government to wind back the activities of those institutions and to cripple the future development of things such as the National Museum of Australia.

It is interesting to look at the foreword to the report which was written by the Chairman of the Council, Mr E. G. Whitlam, Mr Whitlam is quite scathing of the Government and, in particular, quite scathing of the former Minister for the Arts, Mr Punch, a person who has since been removed, thankfully, from that particular portfolio due primarily to his manifest incompetence as Minister. He has been transferred to another portfolio where he is currently displaying his manifest incompetence to handle it. In writing the foreword to this report, Mr Whitlam indicated the extent to which it had been a top priority for the gallery to acquire a representative painting from the Cubist period of Pablo Picasso. Mr Whitlam said:
There are few, if any, national galleries which would in recent times have been deprived by their governments of the opportunity to acquire works of such significance and quality.

In other words, Mr Whitlam indicates the extent to which the boorish and philistine behaviour of the then Minister for the Arts has been a significant setback to the collecting program of the Australian National Gallery. He indicates the extent to which direct interference-ministerial interference-in the arts is something about which we hear so much criticism from the Labor Party. It is something that the Government would never be part of and anybody who advocates any sort of arrangement which it does not like is automatically accused of ministerial interference in the arts. Yet Mr Whitlam is clearly nailing what was left of Mr Punch's miserable hide to the wall over this particular incident.

The gallery is to be congratulated, as is Mr Mollison, the Director of the gallery, on the great success it has had throughout the course of last year. It is a very fine institution. It is a great credit to Australia and to the foresight of previous governments which established it and which allowed it to grow and develop. It is one of the great disgraces of this Government's administrative arrangements and policies that the gallery is put under threat by the way in which Ministers behave and by the way in which this Government is taking the axe to collecting institutions and national galleries throughout Australia.

talk.start.para: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

speech.speaker: Jenkins Sen J.A.

talk.start.para: —I too would like to speak briefly on the annual report 1987-88 of the Australian National Gallery. Along with the new Parliament building, the provisional Parliament House, the High Court of Australia and the National Library, the Australian National Gallery has played a significant part in establishing Canberra as the nation's capital. Indeed, it is arguable that a national gallery is a reflection of the national psyche and therefore an essential element of nationhood. Page 9 of the report states:

speech.para: It would be a fundamental misconception to regard the Australian National Gallery as primarily a gallery to serve Canberra's residents and visitors. In fact, over 70 per cent of our annual visitors come from interstate. Like the National Library of Australia and the Australian War Memorial, the Gallery has to serve Australians everywhere. No other institution in its area of responsibility is accustomed or equipped to serve all the inhabitants of Australia.

The year 1988 has been especially exciting for the Australian National Gallery, with special bicentennial exhibitions in the gallery and around Australia. Many of the gallery's best known Australian works have been on tour as a bicentennial exhibition all over the country. The National Gallery has its own collection of the highest standard of international art. In addition, a very important contribution has been made by visiting major exhibitions, such as the British season of printmakers, the wonderful French photography in the exhibition `Joie de Vivre' and the Phillips Collection, `Old Masters-New Visions'. Such exhibitions give all Australians the chance to see the great masters not in reproduction but in the original. It is important to note that these major exhibitions are not only in the gallery in Canberra but also travel around Australia. I quote from page 44 of the report:

Despite the overall fall in tourism to the ACT during the period under review, the Gallery continued to be a focus for tourism to Canberra during the Old Masters-New Visions exhibition, attracting over 160,000 visitors during October and November, 81 per cent of whom were interstate visitors who had come to Canberra primarily to see the exhibition. An attractive exhibition program of wide appeal and regular tourism liaison have contributed to a general increase in the number of patrons.

Local patrons of the gallery have commented that it should be open at night and such a measure would in part answer those who would regard a casino as the sole answer to Canberra's lack of night life. Night openings, with film shows and other related activities, should occur, in addition to the very successful program of late night openings, at which such well known persons as Paul Keating, David Williamson, Germaine Greer, Jack Thompson and Fred Chaney, among others, have contributed as speakers.

As Senator Puplick said, funding for the gallery is under threat and commercial sponsorship has played a major role in maintaining funding. The Government should certainly address that issue. I refer honourable senators to page 14 of the report for a list of these sponsors. Congratulations are due to the National Gallery on a very successful bicentennial year. Attendance figures have risen from 254,000 to nearly 411,000 during the period 1 July to 30 June. The National Gallery has had a high profile at Expo, at Darling Harbour and at regional galleries. The gallery shop is doing a booming trade, and sometimes it seems that patrons are as happy to look at postcards of the great art works as at the works themselves. I commend the report.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

debate.title: SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE ADMINISTRATION OF ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (1) That the following matters be referred to the Committee of Privileges:

(a) whether false or misleading evidence was given to Estimates Committee E in relation to the attendance in Canberra on 1 and 2 September 1988 of Mr R. Robinson, Mr D. McCarthy and Mr N. Johnson; and

(b) whether, in relation to the appearance of those persons before the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, there was an attempt to manipulate the evidence laid before the Select Committee,
and whether a contempt of the Senate was committed in respect of those matters.

(2) That the provisions of the resolution of 3 November 1988 referring matters to the Committee of Privileges apply in respect of the Committee's inquiry into the matters referred to in paragraph (1).
I seek leave to make a short statement.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate. I do not wish to speak at length about this matter because I outlined the concerns which led me to raise this matter with the President in a speech on 4 November on the motion for the first reading of some taxation Bills. I indicated then the sections of the Estimates Committee Hansard which gave rise to my concerns. In those sections of Hansard, initially on 25 October, Senator Tate, the Minister responding to questions in that Committee, responding to advice given to him by Mr Perkins, indicated that public money had not been used to bring witnesses before the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs which is inquiring into the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation. I will not give the precise quotations; they are available in the Hansard.

speech.para: That matter was followed up the next day in the same Committee by Senator Collins, who asked questions which, in this case, were responded to directly by Mr Perkins. Mr Perkins's responses-which were, again, given by me in the speech I made on 4 November-indicated that the major purpose for which the three witnesses had come to Canberra was sport. Mr Perkins's response was: `The major purpose was sport'. He affirmed that a little later, using the words `consultations on sport'. The point that I made at the time was that on the information which was available to the Opposition, it appeared that those people had spent the great bulk of their time on matters relating to the ATSIC inquiry and we thought that it was certainly not the case that they had come here with the primary purpose of dealing with consultations on sport.

I bring forward that matter because, of all the inquiries which are available at the moment-I think that we have five government-sponsored inquiries and two parliamentary inquiries, the ATSIC inquiry and the inquiries of the Standing Committee of Privileges, which will flow from my earlier resolution and the motion before us-it is the ATSIC inquiry which actually goes to the substance of what is happening to Aboriginal people in Australia. It is the best and the only opportunity, on my understanding of the situation, for us to address the vital question of what impact government policy is having on both Aboriginal individuals and communities.

I do not believe that there is any room for any sense of satisfaction in this matter. Whatever might be said about the good intentions, hopes and aspirations of the Government, the previous Government or the bureaucrats concerned, the reality is that we have some very sobering difficulties to deal with. One of those is very hard to quantify, and I refer to the question of public attitudes. I have said before, and I believe it to be true, that the very broad community sympathy for the Aboriginal people which was evident in the 1967 referendum has been gradually whittled away and in many parts of Australia there is considerable animosity towards the Aboriginal community. I find that distressing but it is, to my mind, quite evident. I do not know whether the Western Australian Democrat senator, Senator Jean Jenkins, who is here and who has, I know, conscientiously applied herself to trying to ascertain the views of her Aboriginal constituents in Western Australia, would agree with me, but I have certainly found evidence of animosity as I have moved around Western Australia and, I think significantly, far more deep and readily voiced animosity against the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Government's programs. That is, in itself, a significant figure.

This is not a matter of a redneck reaction. I have quoted before and I quote again the last conversation which I had some years ago with the late Charles Rowley. Everybody who has any interest in Aboriginal Affairs would acknowledge the extraordinary contribution of Charles Rowley as an academic, researcher, author, head of the Aboriginal Land Fund Commission and adviser to successive governments, including the Government of which I was part. He was certainly a valued adviser to me, as I know he was to very many people in the Australian Labor Party. The point which he made in a conversation in Canberra was that in redoing the research which had been the basis of his publications in the 1960s-books such as Outcasts in White Australia-he had discovered that in some respects things had deteriorated. When I tried subsequently to examine his research, I found that the most dramatic example of what he was talking about was employment. It appeared from his research that, whereas in the 1960s he had found Aboriginal unemployment in rural areas something under 20 per cent, in the early 1980s he had found Aboriginal unemployment of 50 per cent plus. I give that as an example because, while I am not suggesting that this is a very recent problem, I do suggest that there has been a recent acceleration of the problem in both the attitudinal area and other areas of Aboriginal affairs. I believe it is time that we took a very close look at this matter. I mentioned it at Question Time and I think the Minister, in his response, was critical of my raising it in this context. But I raise it as a particularly dramatic barometer of how bad things are-the fact that, a year after the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody was established and after new guidelines were drawn up by it, the deaths continued and last July the Commissioner made in Perth what is described in the Australian newspaper as an impassioned speech in which he decried the continual flouting of the guidelines as distressing, both in human terms and for Australia's reputation.

Reading through the chronology of events since the establishment of the Royal Commission, it is deeply distressing to find that week by week, month by month these deaths continue. I mention them in this context because I believe that, for all the detailed work which will be done by the Royal Commission, in the end it will be found that the deaths are a combination of a number of things which can be readily identified if one spends time with the Aboriginal community; that is, that in too many circumstances Aboriginal people are in a situation in which they despair. I think the combination of despair and the contempt with which they are often regarded and treated has a fatal impact. The deaths in custody are simply one of the nasty indicators-perhaps the nastiest-of a thoroughly unsatisfactory situation.

This is not an issue to which anybody comes in a position of being smug or self- righteous. The difficulties are shared. But I think that the record of the present Government is worse in this area than in any other area of administration because-and this is not the time to labour the point-it has been continually distracted from the job in hand by the chasing of mirages. The Government has chased the mirage of national land rights as a solution; it has chased the mirage of the treaty as a solution; it has chased the mirage of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. ATSIC may not be a mirage; perhaps in the end it will go through. My preliminary view is that it is unlikely to advance the situation of Aboriginal people, but my fundamental point is that, in an area which requires, I believe, utter dedication to finding workable arrangements on the ground, within the communities in which Aboriginal people live there has been an excess of reliance on symbolism and a distressing tendency to allow spokesmen for Aboriginal people, both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal, to externalise the problems of Aboriginal people and to pretend that if only one of these wonderful things happens-national land rights, a treaty or ATSIC-in some way things will be better.

The ATSIC inquiry has to come to grips with whether or not the framework which is being put down is one which will contribute to an orderly situation for Aboriginal people within which they have some chance of living successfully, of advancing themselves and of making genuine choices about their lives. We cannot get genuine choice in a situation of social chaos. In many Aboriginal communities which have been left in the name of self-management without adequate assistance and advice there has been chaos; and tension, drunkenness, fighting, ill-health and a lack of education is what flows from that. This is the difficulty with which we are dealing.

What is the relevance of this to the motion? It is simply this: this is a situation of enormous difficulty in which honest men and women can differ. I had a discussion with Senator Coulter after lunch, and it would be fair to say, I think, that we had some points of difference on what the solution might be. I accept that in good faith one can have differences. I can have differences with Senator Tate, the Minister at the table, who I am not in any sense doubting is as concerned as any member of the Opposition to see these things put right. But how in the world can we as a parliament make the best decision possible-any decision we make is likely to be imperfect-if there is any blurring of the facts? That is why this reference is important and why I think the Privileges Committee has a particularly and unusually difficult task to deal with.

The Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs is trying to examine the ATSIC Bill so that an accurate picture of the Bill and what its impact might be can be presented to this Parliament in order that we do not make more mistakes. That will be a difficult thing to do. But if there is any bending or perversion of the evidence, what is difficult becomes impossible. This matter is being referred to the Privileges Committee because it is something which goes fundamentally to the processes that we have undertaken to try to legislate well in this difficult area.

We cannot prejudge this matter. On behalf of the Opposition, I have put before the Senate those matters which have given rise to our concerns. I say to members of the Privileges Committee that they must be on their mettle when examining these matters. Parliamentary committees are not very good instruments for examining wrongdoing. If there has been wrongdoing, there are better ways of going about conducting an examination, but this happens to be the instrument that we have available to us. I remind the Privileges Committee of the sorts of doubts and difficulties which were expressed by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure when it was examining the Aboriginal Development Commission in 1985. Some concerns were expressed in the final report of the Committee about the difficulties of trying to examine allegations of wrongdoing, disputed matters of fact and so on. Members of the Privileges Committee have to examine this matter in a very critical and careful way. I say that because if the Senate has been misled and if the Estimates Committee has been misled, members of the Privileges Committee have to accept that some people are prepared to mislead the Parliament, and they cannot deal with this matter in a casual or easy way.

I believe that the reference is a quite difficult one for the Committee. I think it will be very important for the Committee to take evidence from the public servants who performed the subsidiary services that were required to bring the relevant people to Canberra. Yesterday I picked up a piece of gossip that one of the public servants involved is retiring tomorrow. That sort of difficulty can arise. It is going to be vitally important that the Committee examine all of the relevant people who were part of the transaction of bringing the three witnesses to Canberra, primarily, we have been told, for the purpose of consultations on sport. The Committee needs to establish how it came about that they were to be brought to Canberra at that time; where the initiative came from; the actual period of consultation-I am sure there was some, but I suspect it was very brief indeed; how it was planned; when the decision was taken; how it happened that it coincided with the ATSIC hearings; and how it was possible that so much of the time in Canberra could be devoted to the ATSIC hearing. I think the Committee needs also to look at the publicly available evidence that has already been given, which must have been bothering the Government very much, because there was a good deal of Aboriginal disquiet about the ATSIC proposal. Suddenly, three jolly chaps came along and told us that ATSIC is a wonderful proposition. I think that matter needs to be examined, along with the role and the position of those individuals.

I offer that advice because, as I said, this is a matter of enormous difficulty. I do not envy my Senate colleagues who make up that Committee. I have a lot of sympathy with the views expressed primarily in the dissenting final report about the inadequacy of the parliamentary system to deal with the sorts of allegations which were made to the Committee. I simply commend a very careful consideration of the matters which are the subject of this motion.

Whilst the long term economic health of this country is probably the most significant thing that will contribute to our long term success or failure-our welfare or otherwise as a nation-in terms of our long term quality as a nation, understanding better how to order our approach to Aboriginal affairs and how better to provide a dignified and independent place within Australian society for Aboriginal Australians is as great a challenge as we face. That is why I, as an individual, express the deepest possible concern at the matters of privilege that we as an Opposition have raised. I think this is such an important issue that we cannot allow any possibility of the processes being distorted or sullied.

talk.start.para: —by leave-Although it was agreed last night that this matter should be put as a formal motion, I indicate for the record that the Government has no difficulty with the matter being sent to the Committee of Privileges and agrees that that is a proper course of action. It is not my intention to tell the Privileges Committee how to conduct its business. I am quite sure that it is competent and able to undertake the inquiry in the fullest and most proper manner to satisfy this chamber. The report, when it comes back to the chamber, will obviously be of great interest to us all. As I said, the Government has no difficulty in supporting the motion.

speech.speaker: Coulter Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —by leave-The referral to the Committee of Privileges of the matters raised by Senator Chaney is quite appropriate. The Australian Democrats do not oppose that reference in any way at all. I would like just to say a few words about what Senator Chaney had to say with respect to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). It is important that these matters be investigated at this time before the ATSIC legislation is debated by the Senate because if there are any matters of misconduct, mismanagement or abuse within any area of Aboriginal affairs it is important to bring those matters out into the open, excise them and deal with them. We have to ensure that when the ATSIC legislation is debated we are clear in our minds that by sufficiently improving that legislation, if necessary, that new structure can be protected as far as possible from assaults, even the sorts of assaults which might be made through the media or by politically motivated people who are part of the structure itself.

speech.para: Senator Chaney seems to have taken the view that Aboriginal people are not capable of the self-administration which is anticipated in the ATSIC legislation. Of course, we are not debating ATSIC now, but I think that is a rather sweeping assertion. I believe there are people in the Aboriginal community who are able to help their fellows in that community within a structure of self-management and self-determination. It is still my view that the ATSIC legislation, given the results which will flow from these several investigations being carried out by various committees, can be improved, can be made better able to serve the main purpose for which it has been designed. At this stage I would simply like to put on record that the Democrats are still supporting the main thrust of this legislation
Question resolved in the affirmative.

debate.title:
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (OPEN GOVERNMENT, PROBITY AND CITIZENS' RIGHTS) BILL 1988
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (PROTECTION OF THE NATIONAL INTEREST) BILL 1988
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (ESTABLISHMENT AND AMENDMENT OF NEW CONSTITUTION) BILL 1988

proctext.para: Motion (by Senator Jenkins) agreed to:
That the following Bills be introduced:

A Bill for an Act to provide for open government in the Australian Capital Territory, to protect the probity of that Government and to establish fundamental rights of persons in the Australian Capital Territory.
A Bill for an Act to provide for the protection of the national interest in relation to the government of the Australian Capital Territory.
A Bill for an Act to permit the establishment and amendment of a new Constitution for the Australian Capital Territory.
Motion (by Senator Jenkins) agreed to:
That the Bills may proceed without formalities, may be considered together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

speech.speaker: Jenkins Sen J.A.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard and to table the three explanatory memoranda.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (OPEN GOVERNMENT, PROBITY AND CITIZENS' RIGHTS) BILL 1988
This Bill is based on three clear propositions.
The first is that, in these modern times, communities expect governments to pay express attention to legislative concerns of the types dealt with in this Bill.
The second is that the convenience of citizens and the utility of the provisions are maximised if such legislative concerns are set out in a clear, brief and accessible item of legislation.

The third is that, in the case of the national capital, the wider national community deserves to know that high standards will apply to a self-governing Australian Capital Territory, and that these have been guaranteed by the measures adopted by this Parliament.
These are the reasons for bringing these provisions together in a succinct, self-contained Bill.

But it also has the fortuitous additional advantage of making it easier for this Parliament to focus on the provisions. It makes it easier for us to determine whether they adequately reflect the standards the governance of the national capital requires, and the aspirations the Australian Parliament has for the Territory.
The Bill addresses the three broad, and in many ways interrelated, issues of open government, probity in governmental processes, and civil rights.
I believe this Parliament will be prepared to say that we do indeed regard all three matters as being of the highest importance.
I hope we will also say that it is convenient and a matter of common sense to bring them together in a single, self-contained Bill.
What I put before the Senate is a coherent package of standards to apply to the new ACT government, in both the local and the national interest.

This Parliament has been so little involved to this point in the specific provisions to be made for ACT self-government that it would be appropriate for us to take a stand on the important matters dealt with in this Bill.
My colleagues and I therefore stand ready to further debate these proposals with maximum expedition if suggestions for their improvement are forthcoming.
What I seek from the Senate is endorsement of the principle that these matters are matters of a sort worthy of this Parliament's attention.
I also believe the actual package is one the Senate can and should now endorse.
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (PROTECTION OF THE NATIONAL INTEREST) BILL 1988
Two important matters are at the heart of this Bill.
The first is the fundamental proposition that there must not be intervention in the affairs or decisions of a legislature by the executive arm of another level of government.

The second is the need to recognise that the Australian Capital Territory is at the same time three things in one. It is a specific, discrete, State-type community.
