It is concurrently the centre of a wider region which relies on it for a number of major services. And it is also the national capital.
On rare occasions it may happen that the matters at the heart of this Bill are in conflict. The fact that it will be rare does not reduce the need for this Parliament to address the possibility.

Rather, it emphasises the need for the Parliament to set down the guidelines to be followed. It is convenient and proper to do this while the topic as a whole of which it is a part is before the Parliament.
What is to happen if the ACT legislature does something which is clearly inconsistent with the national interest?
The short answer is that the Parliament of Australia should, in the national interest, enact legislation overturning the decision of the ACT legislature with respect to the particular matter.

But what is to happen if the Parliament of Australia is not in session at that point, and the course of action decided on by the ACT legislature is to have immediate effect of a sort which it would be impossible to reverse subsequently?

The answer is that in such a circumstance the Governor-General should have a ``holding'' power-a power to issue an injunction, as it were, which protects the rights of the Parliament-a power which ensures that the rights of this Parliament in such an unusual case are real, not just formal.
This is the fundamental objective of this Bill. This is the mechanism it proposes, and the reasons for the mechanism.
It rejects absolutely the approach in the Government's Bills of permitting wholesale intervention by the Federal Executive in the ACT legislature.
It substitutes the important notion that in case of real need the Federal Executive shall have circumscribed and time-limited rights to protect the prerogatives of this Parliament.
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY (ESTABLISHMENT AND AMENDMENT OF NEW CONSTITUTION) BILL 1988
The Parliament is, in effect, in the course of setting down the first constitution of a self-governing Australian Capital Territory.
This is a heavy and complex responsibility. And we must ensure that we do it as well as we can.

But however well we do it, it will have a major flaw. It will not have been developed by the people to whom it applies. Nor will it have been developed in conjunction with the people to whom it applies.

In the circumstances, therefore, we must proceed to revise and improve the Government's Bills as best we can, on behalf of ACT citizens. Those of us who suspect that the bureaucracy, rather than the Government, has had an unduly large hand in developing the Government's Bills will feel a particularly heavy responsibility in this regard.

If we do our work well, the happy day will arrive shortly when the people of the ACT have a legislature of their own, chosen by fair and appropriate processes. The people of the ACT will then have territorial legislators through whom they can act.
At that point it would be appropriate for the people of the ACT, and the legislators through whom they act, to have the opportunity to develop a constitution of their own choice for the Territory.
Making arrangements for such a right to then exist is a matter we should address at this stage, as part of the larger debate on ACT self-government in which we are all engaged.

This Bill therefore seeks to supplement the wider self-government legislation currently before us. It seeks specifically to spell out processes by which the people of the ACT can ``repatriate'' their constitution.
Guarantees are built in to ensure that the ACT legislature will have full consultations with the ACT community in the development of proposals to put to this Parliament.

If either this Parliament or the Governor-General were to be of the view that these consultations had been insufficient, or were not adequately reflected in the ACT legislature's proposals, the proposals would be rejected.
Similarly, if either this Parliament or the Governor-General were to consider the national interest to be at risk or insufficiently protected, the ACT legislature's proposals would be rejected.

The Bill puts the onus on the ACT to develop proposals acceptable to this Parliament. It also puts the onus on the ACT to utilise processes which are to be scrutinised by, and found acceptable to, this Parliament.
If the ACT can rise to this challenge, should we deny the ACT the right to its own Constitution?
Debate (on motion by Senator Foreman) adjourned.

debate.title:
ANL (CONVERSION INTO PUBLIC COMPANY) BILL 1988
OTC (CONVERSION INTO PUBLIC COMPANY) BILL 1988
AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL RAILWAYS COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1988
SATELLITE COMMUNICATIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1988

proctext.para: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the Bills may proceed without formalities, may be considered together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

speech.speaker: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
ANL (CONVERSION INTO PUBLIC COMPANY) BILL 1988

The purpose of the ANL (Conversion into Public Company) Bill is twofold. First to establish the Australian Shipping Commission, which trades as the Australian National Line (ANL), as a public company. Secondly, to remove statutory controls over ANL's operations.
These are major steps towards implementing the reform package for ANL announced on 25 May 1988 in the statement ``Reshaping the Transport and Communications Government Enterprises''.

A major part of the Government's third term agenda is micro-economic reform. Ensuring that Government business enterprises operate as efficiently and effectively as possible is a major element of this reform program.

ANL provides an important transport link for Australian industry, both internationally and on the coast. Any improvement in its efficiency will therefore immediately be reflected elsewhere in the economy. But this will only occur if ANL is given greater flexibility and the ability to respond rapidly to changes in the market and to take up business opportunities as they present themselves.

In 1983, this Government introduced amendments to the Australian Shipping Commission Act that went some way in that direction. Those amendments removed bureaucratic restraints and instilled a more commercial approach into the Line.
The benefits of this approach are a matter of public record. ANL has been turned around from being a debt ridden loss maker into a profitable enterprise, regularly paying dividends and income tax.

This Bill completes the commercialisation of ANL started by this Government five years ago. The Line has long been required to operate in highly competitive markets, subject to the same taxes and charges as other operators. Incorporation will now give it the same business structure as most of its competitors. Removal of residual Government controls over its day to day operations will complete the process of giving it the flexibility to compete on truly equal terms with private shipping operators.
Removal of day-to-day controls will not, however, mean any lessening of accountability. The new Company will be required to:
provide regularly to the Minister for Transport and Communications strategic corporate plans for consideration and response;
work towards an overall financial target agreed in advance by the Minister;
ensure appropriate revaluation of its assets at least every five years, the first such revaluation to be settled before ANL's conversion to a company; and
recommend a dividend annually, after consultation with the Minister.
And of course ANL will continue to report on its financial performance through an Annual Report prepared on the same basis as any company.

In summary, ANL is being given the freedom to manage itself on a day-to-day basis without any second guessing from Canberra. But it will remain fully accountable to its shareholders, the Australian taxpayers, through their representative, the Minister for Transport and Communications.
I now turn to the provisions of the Bill itself.

The Bill will establish ANL as a company by providing for the Commission to be registered as a company incorporated in the ACT under the Companies Act 1981 on a day to be proclaimed. It is expected that the commencing day of the company (ie. the transition day) will be 1 July 1989, although it may be earlier than this if the Memorandum and Articles of Association and the other elements of the reform package can be completed earlier.

The approach embodied in the Bill is basically a refinement of that adopted for the establishment of Australian Airlines as a company. That is, the Bill provides for the continuity of ANL's corporate entity by deeming it to be incorporated under the Companies Act.

The main changes to the earlier approach reflect machinery refinements to ensure that ANL fully complies with public disclosure requirements of registration. These were requested by the Corporate Affairs Commission to avoid administrative problems encountered following Australian Airlines' registration as a company.

The Bill provides for there to be no change in ANL's corporate entity. The Commission will change its name (to ANL Ltd) and its form immediately before registration. This will facilitate its registration as an ongoing business enterprise while conforming, as far as possible, to the registration requirements of the Companies Act.

Continuity of the corporate entity dispenses with the need to transfer assets and liabilities from the Commission to a new body corporate. It ensures that all contracts, agreements and arrangements entered into by or on behalf of the Commission and which are in force immediately before transition will apply to the new Company.

There should be no ambiguity about this point. ANL will change its form because of this legislation. But ANL Ltd retains the full obligations and responsibilities of the Australian Shipping Commission, and before that, the Australian Coastal Shipping Commission. Its heritage is clear. ANL remains Australia's national shipping line.
The Bill provides for the Commission's capital (totalling $196,391,000) to be converted to $1 shares and for all shares in the new Company to be held directly by the Commonwealth.

The Bill provides that on transition, each staff member of the Commission will become an employee of the Company on the same terms and conditions as applied to his or her employment by the Commission. Entitlements such as long service and recreation leave, and eligibility for sick leave, applying at transition date will be preserved. Those staff who have rights under Part IV of the Public Service Act 1922 will retain those rights.

The Bill provides for the repeal of the day-to-day controls over ANL contained in the Australian Shipping Commission Act, effective from the time of registering the Commission as a company. This is done in the context of the other elements of the reform package which ensure proper and full accountability. Any minimum levels of control which the Government decides should remain over ANL will be specified in either the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the new Company or in the Guidelines to Directors.

Finally, the legislation we are proposing will make no calls on the revenues of the Commonwealth or, of itself, immediately provide additional revenue to the Commonwealth. The Bill has been drafted to ensure that the transition from body corporate to company status will be ``tax neutral''. However improvements in the performance of ANL Limited that result from the implementation of the reform package, of which this Bill is a part, will benefit the shareholders and all users of the Commission's services.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
OTC (CONVERSION INTO PUBLIC COMPANY) BILL 1988

The OTC (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1988 is part of the Government's reform package for OTC as announced by the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans on 25 May this year.

The reforms to Government Business Enterprises are central to the Government's micro-economic reform agenda to restructure the public sector. In the present difficult and fiercely competitive international trading environment public sector efficiency is especially important. Many public business enterprises-particularly those in the Transport and Communications portfolio-produce not only final goods and services for the consumer, but also provide intermediate inputs for the rest of the economy, and thus influence the nation's overall cost structures.

OTC is established under the Overseas Telecommunications Act. This Act was passed by Parliament in 1946, following the acquisition by the Federal Government of the radiocommunications assets of two companies, Cable and Wireless, and Amalgamated Wireless (Australasia), which had hitherto operated cable and beam wireless communications systems between Australia and the rest of the world. Since then OTC has operated as a separate body. The 25 May ministerial statement affirmed the Government's decision to retain each of the telecommunications carriers-Telecom, OTC and AUSSAT-as a separate entity.

Given the increasing competitiveness of international telecommunications, the importance of telecommunications to our economy, the growth in this sector and the fact that OTC serves no explicit social obligations, the Government has decided that OTC will be renamed the Overseas Telecommunications Corporation and it will be incorporated under companies legislation as OTC Limited.

OTC is an organisation which already operates in a commercial manner. It is subject to all Commonwealth taxes and charges and pays substantial dividends to the Commonwealth. It has an effective monopoly over the central core of its operations, but it faces competition in other areas such as delivery of value-added services and consultancy services. OTC has a sound financial structure with a debt to equity ratio of around 65:35. On conversion to a company, there will be no need to alter OTC's financial structure nor will the ownership change, ie. OTC will continue to be owned by the Commonwealth.

In future the Government will be less involved in scrutinising the day-to-day activities of OTC. Instead, it will focus on planning, through corporate plans and financial targets, and accountability for results with strategic aspects monitored on an on-going basis. The emphasis in future will be on the bottom line, on how successfully the goals and targets are met. A myriad of unnecessary Government controls over day-to-day management decision making will be removed.
The Government aims, through this approach, to establish a clearer distinction between the ownership of the enterprise, the Board and management.

The OTC (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1988 amends the Overseas Telecommunications Act and deems OTC to be a public company. Like the ANL (Conversion into Public Company) Bill 1988 introduced by my colleague the former Minister for Transport and Communications Support, Mr Peter Morris, this approach is consistent with that adopted for Australian Airlines' conversion to company status. As the same legal entity is transferred to company status there is no need to re-write existing contracts and the like. The date for conversion is set by proclamation-at this stage intended to be 1 January 1989.

OTC Limited will be expected to operate like other companies under the companies code. This means most of the provisions of the Overseas Telecommunications Act will not be needed and can be repealed. Included among these are provisions which deal with staffing matters.
The Bill includes provisions to ensure continuity of employment and the maintenance of existing accrued entitlements for each employee on conversion of OTC to a company.

In future OTC will be responsible for terms and conditions of employment. OTC is currently consulting staff associations on how existing terms and conditions will be dealt with in awards or agreements. The Government expects OTC to make arrangements to transfer terms and conditions and to ensure that no current staff member loses any entitlement or classification on transfer to OTC Limited. The Government will not proclaim the Bill until it is satisfied that the interests of OTC employees are protected and terms and conditions are satisfactorily transferred.

The Bill minimises day-to-day Government controls in line with the enhanced responsibilities and accountability of the Board. There will be appropriate mechanisms to allow the Minister to exercise strategic oversight, through the corporate plan and financial targets. OTC will be free to engage, on its own authority, in such standard business practices as entering into contracts, partnerships, joint ventures, and normal business investment arrangements. In some cases, such as establishing subsidiary companies, the Board will be required to notify the Minister in writing before business activities are expanded. Subject to overall Loan Council scrutiny, OTC will not be required to obtain Ministerial approval to the terms and conditions of individual borrowings.

Finally, the Bill does not involve any additional expenditure by the Commonwealth or, of itself, additional revenue for the Commonwealth. However, improvements in the performance of OTC that result from the implementation of the reform package, of which this Bill is a part, will benefit the shareholders and all users of OTC's services. I commend this Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL RAILWAYS COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1988
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983 to implement the Government's reform package for the Australian National Railways Commission (AN).
The major elements in the package of amendments proposed in the Australian National Railways Commission Amendment Bill are
to widen AN's powers to expand the scope of its business activities
to extend the planning and accountability mechanisms which apply to AN, and
to remove most of the remaining day-to-day controls over AN's activities.

Reform of its business enterprises is an important element of the Government's third term agenda. The Government recognises that its transport and communications business enterprises must operate as efficiently and effectively as possible if Australia is to succeed in reshaping key sectors of the economy and in improving our international competitiveness.

The Federal Government's railway, AN, provides an important element of both the east-west transport service linking our major manufacturing and export centres of Sydney and Melbourne to Adelaide and Perth, and of the north-south corridor through Alice Springs to Darwin. On the mainland, AN operates non-metropolitan freight and passenger services in South Australia, extending from South Australia to Kalgoorlie in the west, to Alice Springs in the north and Broken Hill in the east. In Tasmania, AN operates freight services.

AN's mainland business competes for freight traffic with the road operations of the major freight forwarders, independent `truckies' and with coastal shipping. It also competes with coach and bus passenger services. Interstate transport accounts for more than 75 per cent of AN's commercial freight business.

Changes to AN's legislation in 1983 designed to promote AN's role as a business undertaking have already done much to put AN on a more commercial footing. Over the past five years, AN has greatly improved its performance-its call on the taxpayer has been reduced in real terms by 66 per cent, and it is expected to break-even on its mainland freight operations this financial year.

In relation to AN's Tasmanian operations the Government announced in May 1988 that it would continue to support Tasrail for the next five years. AN expects to break-even on Tasrail operations by 1993-94.

The reform package is designed to consolidate the achievements to date and provide AN with an environment in which it can achieve the highest possible level of operational and financial efficiency while continuing its move to profitability. It will continue the process of commercialisation initiated in 1983 allowing AN greater freedom to manage and greater flexibility to compete in the market place. The Government considers that AN should have a further opportunity to consolidate its position and improve its performance before more changes are made.
Greater freedom to manage means that AN should be freed from most of the remaining day-to-day controls over its activities.
Thus the Bill amongst other things:
removes the requirement for AN to obtain ministerial approval to enter into contracts
removes the requirement to obtain the Treasurer's approval for the terms and conditions of individual borrowings, investments or banking arrangements
empowers AN to recommend an auditor of its choice.
AN will remain subject to Loan Council processes for its borrowings.
Removal of day-to-day controls will not, however, mean any lessening of accountability. AN will continue to be required to:
provide regularly to the Minister strategic corporate plans for consideration and response; and
work towards an overall financial target agreed in advance by the Minister.

In addition, this Bill will require AN to advise the Minister of any matter which significantly affects the outlook as established in the corporate plan as soon as possible after such matters become known.
Any additional costs arising from Government ownership for items such as superannuation and auditing requirements will be taken into account in determining AN's financial target.
AN will continue to report on its financial performance through an Annual Report.

AN must be able to consider offering the same broad range of services as its competitors and have the ability to respond rapidly to changes in the market and to consider business opportunities as they arise. Accordingly this Bill widens the scope of associated or supplementary business activities into which AN might consider expanding.

Commissioners will now be subject to dismissal for on-going underperformance (in addition to current grounds such as misbehaviour, mental illness etc), in line with the emphasis on accountability for results.

The Managing Director will be appointed by the Minister after receiving a recommendation from the Commission. Terms and conditions of employment for the Managing Director will be a matter for the Commission. The Commission will consult with the Remuneration Tribunal about the remuneration package for the Managing Director in line with the amendment of the Remuneration Tribunals Act introduced in the Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous Reforms) Bill (Part V).
The transition to the new arrangements is expected to be completed by July next year.

Finally, the legislation we are proposing will make no calls on the revenues of the Commonwealth. Improvements in the performance of AN that result from the implementation of the reform package, of which this Bill is a part, will benefit taxpayers by further reducing AN's call on the Budget.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
SATELLITE COMMUNICATIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1988

The Satellite Communications Amendment Bill is part of the Government's reform package for AUSSAT as announced by the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, on May 25 this year.

The reforms of Government Business Enterprises are very important for the Government's overall micro-economic agenda. Public sector efficiency is especially important in the current economic and international trading situation because many public business enterprises produce intermediate inputs for the rest of the economy and have an influence on Australia's overall cost structures.

AUSSAT was established in 1981 for the purpose of establishing, owning and operating a national satellite system. Commercial operations commenced in 1985 with the launch of AUSSAT 1 on 27 August 1985. From its beginning AUSSAT was established on a sound commercial basis. It is incorporated under the Companies Act and has a Board of Directors, a commercial financial structure and relatively few unnecessary Government controls over its day-to-day managerial decision making. Since July 1984, the Commonwealth has held 75 per cent, and Telecom 25 per cent, of the company's shares.

Since AUSSAT is a company, most of the steps needed to implement the May 25 reform package can be achieved by amendment to the company's Memorandum and Articles of Association. Consequently this Bill contains only a relatively small number of amendments.
One amendment modifies the definition of neighbouring regions to allow AUSSAT more scope for selling its services.

Telecom owns 25 per cent of shares in AUSSAT and is entitled to nominate up to 25 per cent of the Directors. The Bill makes two minor technical amendments to the provisions relating to the AUSSAT Board. The first ensures that a Government Director appointed to both the Telecom and the AUSSAT Boards does not affect Telecom's entitlement to nominate AUSSAT Directors. The second provides that any Telecom employee appointed to the AUSSAT Board falls within the 25 per cent limit.
Provisions have also been included to exempt AUSSAT from the Public Works Committee and Lands Acquisition Acts.

In future the Government is to be less involved in scrutinising the day-to-day activities of AUSSAT. Instead, the Government will focus on planning, through corporate plans and financial targets, and accountability for results with strategic aspects monitored on an on-going basis. The emphasis will be on the bottom line, on how successfully the goals and targets are met.
By this approach, the Government aims to establish a clearer distinction between the ownership of the enterprise, the Board and management.

Finally, the Bill does not involve any additional expenditure by the Commonwealth or, of itself, additional revenue for the Commonwealth. However, improvements in the performance of AUSSAT that result from the implementation of the reform package, of which this Bill is a part, will benefit the shareholders and all users of AUSSAT's services. I commend this Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I had gone on to explain that this, in part, results from a failure by this Government to vary taxation rates with inflation, which is resulting in taxpayers, particularly middle income taxpayers and lower income taxpayers, paying massive additional taxation that has been estimated at about $8 billion. At the time of the adjournment I was referring to an article appearing in the Melbourne Herald by the well respected financial journalist Terry McCrann. I had quoted the first paragraph before the adjournment of the debate. In this article Mr McCrann advised:

speech.para: This stark reality makes a mockery of Mr Keating's attacks on `tax cheats' for there has been no bigger cheat in the past few years than the Government itself.

Not surprisingly, the Government was somewhat outraged by that article and unfortunately the retort of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was to abuse Mr McCrann rather than to debate the matter on the issues, and it was necessary, therefore, for such respected tax lawyers as Dr Ian Spry, QC, to come to the rescue of Mr McCrann, and he did so in an article also in the Melbourne Herald a day or two after Mr McCrann's series. He stated:
The Herald is to be commended for publicising the enormous tax increases recently imposed on almost all taxpayers by the Hawke-Keating Government by relying on bracket creep.
A little further, he continued:
Bracket creep has been the main cause of the reduced after-tax purchasing power of wages and salaries.
Finally, he stated:

Mr Keating, who has done so much to make Australia's tax system harsh and unworkable, is to be criticised for refusing to accept the obvious correctness of Terry McCrann's recent articles on this subject.
It is not tolerable that an Australian Treasurer should, as Mr Keating has done, deny what is clearly true.

Those words, as I said, are from Dr Spry, the editor of the Australian Tax Review; not from an Opposition politician, but from an authority of that note. Of course, it is that type of sentiment, that obvious fact of the enormous cost to Australian taxpayers of bracket creep, that has led the Opposition to move the second part of its amendment in relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). It reads:
. . . the Senate notes that:

(2) the Government has mainly relied on bracket creep through the various personal income tax brackets, and also on the introduction of new incentive-sapping taxes such as the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax to fund its Budget surplus;

I wanted to continue in setting the scene for the contents of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) by also drawing to the attention of the Parliament the fact that the result of this rapidly increasing taxation toll is that Australian families on average weekly earnings, with a dependent spouse and two children, would need a minimum tax cut in July 1989 of $56 a week to restore real household income to its 1983 level. So the effect of this rapidly increasing taxation has been to reduce significantly living standards of middle and lower income earners in this country. I also wanted to remind the Government of the distortions that are present within its taxation system and which it should be addressing before it moves to legislation of this type. For example, I remind the Government that a family with one income earner, a dependent spouse and two dependent children on average weekly earnings pays significantly more tax than the same family with two equal income earners and no dependants bringing home the average weekly earnings between them. This is something that the Opposition has addressed on a number of occasions, but which has not been answered by this Government, resulting in a tax prejudice on single income families.

I also want to remind the Senate that these massive increases in income tax have also got to be put in the context of massively increasing indirect taxation under this Government. Indirect taxation in the form of sales taxes, excise duty and customs duties has increased significantly. In fact, in the six years of the Hawke Government there has been a 147 per cent rise in sales tax-three times the rate of inflation. Of course, it is probably unnecessary for me to tell the Senate that that hits hardest on lower income earners, particularly families with young children who are consumers of foods such as orange juice, ice cream, flavoured milks and snack foods, on which this Government has, for the first time, imposed a consumption tax, despite Mr Hawke's repeated promises not to impose such a tax.

When one compares the cost to lower income earners of this taxation system with the costs applying in comparable countries such as the United States, Japan, Canada, France and West Germany, in all cases one finds that the effect is that at lower income levels people are paying proportionately more taxation. Add these faults within the system to the methodology of the Government in enacting its taxation laws, the methodology of taxation changes by announcement and by press release, and we again see a most unsatisfactory state of affairs. It has always been accepted that in some cases it is necessary to make an announcement of change and that the change in taxation laws should take effect from the date of the announcement. However, what was never envisaged was the incredible delays that would take place between such an announcement and legislative enactment. We see it demonstrated aptly in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) that is before us, which includes some changes that were announced some 3 1/2 years ago-an intolerable situation, I would have thought, in the eyes of anyone who is looking for a reasonable system of taxation law. Not surprisingly, the Government's failures in this area have been condemned not only by the Opposition but by Senate committees, most recently by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, and by the Law Council of Australia. I remind the Senate of a recent release of the Law Council of Australia of 19 October. In referring to the criticism of the Government in this area by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, the Council stated:

The Law Council, like the Committee, has repeatedly urged the Government-and particularly the Treasurer-to stop using media releases to usurp the legislative role of the Parliament in a way that makes a mockery of the rule of law.

It is a particularly strong indictment, I would have thought, from such a highly respected body as the Law Council of Australia, but of course it continues to be ignored by the Treasurer and by this Government.

Unfortunately, the policy of this Government in relation to taxation law and the effect of bracket creep has arisen not by accident; it is part of a design and part of the Government's election strategy. This we all learnt from the Treasurer's advice to the Labor Caucus before announcing the May statement of this year, which was recorded for the benefit of us all in the following morning's Australian Financial Review. This was when he briefed his Caucus colleagues on the tax cut strategy which he put to the Caucus in these terms, or so we understand it from the Australian Financial Review:
Well, here it is folks. All of you people who thought you were going to lose your seats at the next election, this will save you. This will get us back into Government.

What did the strategy involve? It involved real wage reductions in 1987-88 and 1988-89 while reaping higher taxation revenue from bracket creep, and that is proving effective, as I have demonstrated, to the extent of some $8 billion a year; using the additional taxation to build up a substantial budget surplus in 1988-89 and 1989-90; and using this revenue fed surplus to provide large personal tax cuts in July 1989-just in time for the next election. So, it is a deliberate strategy and it has been at considerable cost to the Australian taxpayer-I repeat, to taxpayers on middle income levels and taxpayers in lower income areas.

The complexity of the taxation laws and their confusion is particularly demonstrated by these Bills. The complexity in the laws that they are seeking to amend has been demonstrated so well by those who have criticised the capital gains taxation package. I will use just one example although, of course, it has been criticised by many. Mr Matt Walsh, a partner in the legal firm of Mallesons Stephen Jaques, when he was delivering the Harold-Irving endowed lecture earlier in the year to the national conference of the Taxation Institute of Australia, said that the capital gains tax has brought confusion to the business world because of a lack of clarity and ambiguities in the drafting of legislation. He said that the consequences of the legislation imposed considerable hardship on taxpayers and that the confusion arising out of the legislation was in stark contrast to a promise made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) after the ill-fated Australian Taxation Summit of 1985. That confusion and those ambiguities have led us to move the third part of our amendment in relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), and that is:
. . . the Senate notes that:
(3) such new taxes represent increased complexity and uncertainty in the administration of the taxation system and so decrease efficiency and equity;

I move quickly, because time is against me, to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4). As I said in passing a moment ago, I want to make specific mention of the fact that amendments included in that Bill, particularly those to clauses 12, 13, 24 and 54, implement, subject to some minor variations, proposals that were announced on 4 February 1985, that is, over 3 1/2 years ago. I stress the attitude on this side of the chamber, that such methods of making law by announcement, are not only unfair to taxpayers but also unsatisfactory for the professionals who have to work in the tax area. They should not have to wait over three years for specific definitions of general principles that are contained in press releases. I would have thought it was about time that the Government took some note of continuing criticisms in this area and did something about them.

In an environment of unsatisfactory law the Government goes one step further and requires, it seems, the Commissioner of Taxation to enforce the law according to subjective assessments of fairness. I have to say to those on this side of the chamber that that is a most worrying precedent. We remind the Government that no-one under our system should be above the law, whether it is the Tax Commissioner, the Treasurer or anyone else. This growing practice has received widespread criticism. It is unnecessary for me to do more than just mention a few criticisms. An editorial in the Australian Tax Review of March 1987 said:
`What has now developed is in the nature of a witch hunt . . .'
More recently, the President of the Law Council of Australia, Mr Dennis Byrne, referred to Mr Boucher in the following terms:
an over zealous official pursuing a crusade collecting revenue according to his own standards of fairness instead of according to law.

It is easy to blame Mr Boucher, but the real responsibility for the task that is set for government officials rests with the Government and the Treasurer. It has been clear from questions that have been asked in the Senate in the last few weeks that what the Government thinks is important, more important than acting according to the law in enforcing taxation, is that the law be enforced according to subjective judgments of what is fair. I regard that as one of the most worrying precedents to develop in the seven years that I have been in this place. We give the Taxation Commissioner wide and unique powers on the basis that he, acting under the authority of the Government, will not abuse those powers but will always act according to the law rather than according to what he or the Treasurer might think is the spirit of the law. I suggest it is about time that state of affairs was put right.

Since this Government came to office it has introduced some 295 taxation measures. I would have thought it was about time that the Government paused and tried to put the taxation laws of this country into some sort of order rather than simply piled amendment upon amendment. When I look across the chamber at my friend Senator Messner sitting with two massive volumes of the Income Tax Assessment Act and compare them with its size not very long ago, I see a demonstration of, as I said last night, the literally thousands of extra pages of law that the Government has produced in this area. Of course, it is not just the problems of interpretation that have to be endured; with them go the time and effort of government instrumentalities, lawyers, accountants, business owners and the staff of businesses. The management and administrative costs in relation to taxation law in this country are now enormous. If one speaks to people in business, one is made aware of the fact that there are now few days left in the working calendar in which some sort of taxation action does not have to be taken, such as lodging returns for group tax, prescribed payments, withholding tax, sales tax, provisional tax, company tax and the fringe benefits tax, or to lodge tax stamp sheets, group certificates, reconciliations and returns. In fact it has been estimated by some that up to a quarter of the working year is taken up with the lodging of returns or meeting the requirements of the Australian Taxation Office. I again say to the Government that it is time to pause and to look at the cost of this ever-growing burden of taxation and to start putting the house in order.

Within the last 24 hours we have again had a demonstration that these matters of particularly serious note are not simply matters of political moment that have been raised by the Opposition. I remind the Government that within the last 24 hours it has been told by its own advisory body, the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC), that it is heading down the wrong track. We, on this side, have been arguing that the taxation system discriminates against families on average weekly earnings and middle income earners generally by a hidden indirect tax that hits consumers hardest and through the effect of bracket creep. Now the Government has been told the same thing by its own advisory body. It has reminded the Government that many low income earners face the highest marginal tax rates in Australia's post-war history. The EPAC report shows that the marginal tax rate for a single taxpayer on 75 per cent of average weekly earnings has increased from 30 per cent in 1983-84 to 40 per cent in 1987-88, a period of just five years. Clearly that is evidence, even for this Government, of the effects of bracket creep.

In particular EPAC has found that the current marginal and average rates of tax are appreciably higher for most taxpayers in the 1960s and 1970s; that increases in average marginal tax rates have generally been greater for taxpayers with dependants than for single taxpayers; and that the political, social and economic ramifications of high marginal tax rates are so persuasive as to suggest that careful attention needs to be paid to marginal tax rates. I would have thought that was an understatement. EPAC also states that a family on average weekly earnings was facing an effective 35.33 per cent marginal tax rate when the Hawke Government came to power and it is now hit with a 40 per cent rate. That means that instead of keeping 65c in every extra dollar earned, it is now keeping only 60c. Those who have benefited under this Labor Government have been the highest income earners-an astonishing fact of life. That is why the Opposition has moved its amendment. I have mentioned three parts of the Opposition's amendment in relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988. The fourth one is:
. . . the Government has lost sight of the needed direction for Australia's future;
The fifth is:

. . . the Government should accept that the highest priority needs to be given to reducing the enormous tax burden, so that the standard of living of Australians can be improved while at the same time addressing the nation's external economic problems.
The Opposition also has moved an amendment to the second reading motion on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988. I now seek leave to move two amendments to that amendment.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: 1. Paragraph (d), at end of paragraph, leave out ``and''.
2. After paragraph (e), add:
``(f) supports a more certain and predictable taxation system for all taxpayers;
(g) notes that the government is creating widespread uncertainty and confusion in the minds of taxpayers through its blatant use of ``legislation by press release'';
(h) expresses the view that, in the interim period before legislation is introduced, press announcements should be as clear and precise as possible; and

(i) resolves that, where the Government has announced, by press release, its intention to introduce a bill to amend taxation law, and that bill has not been introduced into Parliament within 3 calendar months of the date of that announcement, the Senate shall, subject to any further resolution, amend the bill to provide that the commencement date of the bill shall be a date that is no earlier than the date of introduction of the bill to Parliament''.

If the amendments to the Opposition's amendment are passed we will have a much improved situation and much greater certainty in relation to the unsatisfactory practice that the Government has adopted of changing the tax law by press release and allowing the legislative enactment to follow many years thereafter.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —I reiterate the very strong argument put forward by my colleague on my behalf concerning the amendment moved by me at an earlier stage. The whole point of the issue is simply that this Government has abused the practice of legislation by press release. My colleague Senator Hill drew attention to statements by various authorities, such as the Law Council of Australia and others, which have drawn attention to this most undesirable practice, which has reached the highest form of art, the Government having tried to introduce tax legislation 3 1/2 years after the date of a press release back in February of 1985. It is intolerable that such a thing should occur, and it is wrong and unjust in the interests of taxpayers of this country. For that reason the Opposition felt obliged to move the amendment that it has moved.

speech.para: The import of Senator Hill's main amendment to the second reading amendment is quite clear: In the event of the Government announcing by press release that it intends to legislate certain taxation matters and failing within three months to produce that legislation, the Senate will automatically take the date of the introduction of the Bill as the date of its commencement. There will be no backdating of the legislation to the date of the press release unless the Senate so resolves. That is always within the power of the Senate. That is the import of the main amendment moved by Senator Hill.

I believe the amendment to be perfectly reasonable in light of the great abuse of this system by the Government. Senator Hill referred to the enormous amount of legislation that has been introduced since the Government came to power-some 259 pieces of legislation. As he mentioned during his remarks, we now have an Income Tax Assessment Act which is utterly unintelligible even to the Commissioner of Taxation. From time to time he is forced to put out draft rulings before he actually comes to a conclusion as to what the ruling is. That shows how unintelligible the language of the Act is now becoming. Consequently, this is a very well reasoned and reasonable issue to push at this time. It is time that the Government had this matter drawn to its attention.

Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), which is before the Senate at the moment, is just another example of what has happened in the past. We all know that the Government failed to bring forward its legislation on the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax at the time the legislation was announced back in September 1985. We had to wait nearly nine months before that legislation appeared. That is totally unreasonable. As I say, this latest example of a delay of some 3 1/2 years is absolutely intolerable.

Another example of the kind of situation that has arisen in recent times and to which the Government needs to pay specific attention is its announcement on 25 May in the mini-Budget that the Government is to introduce the taxation of superannuation funds' income. That legislation, as announced at the time, will now be subject to the rule set out in our amendment, if this measure is passed by the Senate. It means that we will apply the Bill providing for the taxation of the income of superannuation funds from the date of its introduction.

During the Estimates Committee debates we heard from the Commissioner of Taxation that that Bill would be introduced some time between now and the end of the sittings before Christmas. We have certainly had no signs of it, and unless it is incorporated in some legislation that does not give away its name, we do not see it on the list of measures to be introduced before the end of this period of sittings. We are therefore looking to 1989 before we can debate this measure and have an opportunity of going through it. As we all know, the Government's new proposal for the taxing of superannuation funds is likely to be extraordinarily complex because of the way in which the Government has gone about its job. It would seem, therefore, that the earliest time the Parliament will be able to debate that legislation will be almost 12 months from the date on which it was announced by the Government.

That is an intolerable situation, given the enormous complexity of the sort of law that will need to be applied in the case of superannuation funds. Therefore, the Opposition feels thoroughly justified in moving the amendment that Senator Hill has now moved to the second reading amendment that I moved previously. It will have the effect, as I say, of bringing the date of application of future taxation laws handled by the method of legislation by press release to the date on which the Bill was actually introduced into Parliament. I understand that Senator Hill's amendments will have the support of the Australian Democrats.

speech.speaker: Powell Sen J.F.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in this particular debate because, as much as anything, of the report of the Government's Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) referred to by Senator Hill not too long ago and by one or two other speakers in this debate late yesterday. I rise also to address some remarks to the amendment proposed by the Opposition in relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1988 which Senator Hill also addressed some of his recent remarks to in the debate today. I do so because I think the release of the EPAC paper is very significant in the context of the debate on this package of taxation Bills and also because I find some of the remarks of Senator Hill and others in the debate lacking in the focus that they have put on bringing out issues from the EPAC report.

speech.para: In the press comments on the EPAC report, and subsequently in the short time that I have had to look at a copy of the report overnight, I found great heart, and indeed even some hope, for those groups of Australian citizens about whom I have been speaking in the context of taxation and other debates since I came to this place over two years ago. Other groups in the community, such as the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS), the Brotherhood of St Lawrence and so on have long been speaking about those groups in relation to the effects of poverty traps. Many of these poverty traps are generated specifically by the relationships which are explored by EPAC between taxation and income support mechanisms and, of course, the whole question of incentives, which is the issue addressed by the paper.

The issue of equivalent marginal tax rates, which is a term used throughout this paper, is a major issue and one with which we need to come to grips, particularly if we subscribe-as certainly the Australian Democrats do-to a social justice strategy. It must be taken account of. The terminology has more generally been termed `effective marginal tax rates' but I am happy to use EPAC's term-if I can remember it-of `equivalent marginal tax rates'. Unless we do so we cannot achieve social justice and the taxation system as it applies will remain an impediment. The equivalent marginal tax rate is defined by EPAC in its report. Just to make sure that people are aware of what we are talking about, that tax rate relates to the reduction of Government benefits as private incomes rise within the tax system. For a great many people-and, indeed, as EPAC points out, for an increasing number of people-this is a major problem. As I said, I took some hope from the EPAC paper and certainly some hope from the Australian Financial Review headline which said something which I and others have been saying for many years. The headline in the Financial Review yesterday was, `Welfare recipients pay more tax than top-rate executives'. This is a problem which has been compounded over the past year or so with what tax cuts we have had being more effective for the high income earners. This is a point which Senator Hill alluded to.

Some moves have been taken on the issue of poverty traps, but I would have to say that they have been puny attempts so far. We must remember the delay of six months in the first of those puny attempts to remove poverty traps. In the 1986 Budget the Government decided that the move from $30 to $40 of permissable income level before the cut-off began of the Government benefit would be delayed until July 1987. The other headlines in yesterday's newspapers on the EPAC report also brought to the public's view those concerns which we have held over a long time. From the Australian we saw, `Welfare payment locks in poverty', and from the Melbourne Age, `More people are living in poverty: report'. This article went on to detail some aspects of the report. The Australian Financial Review pointed out that the study finds poverty traps so severe for some pensioners, beneficiaries and low income families that there is little incentive to work beyond a few hours a week.

I think it is important that we note that here we have the Government's economic advisory committee pointing out that there are built-in disincentives through the combination of the income support system and the tax system for pensioners, beneficiaries and low income families. We hear a lot about this from the Opposition, and quite properly so. There is no disagreement that we have problems in this system and in the tax system generally for people who are not welfare recipients. There are problems of disincentives and equity in the tax system and in many respects they are increasing. Of course, that is a challenge for the Government with the next round of tax cuts. But we hear too little about the built-in disincentives for those people on pensions or benefits. Unfortunately, the response to the disincentives, which is very often to stay on those benefits and not to seek work as the EPAC report points out quite clearly, in many places can actually be at a financial cost to those people. Too often the reaction to that response to stay on benefits and welfare rolls is to hit those people, to blame those people, to call them dole bludgers and to label sole parents as ripping off the system. That is the unfortunate trend which I hope this EPAC report will be able to stem.

I will address that trend with regard to sole parent families-the group specifically mentioned and about which some individual cases were given in this report. This is not just a matter which came up yesterday. I would like to refer to a letter from Susan Barclay of the Council for the Single Mother and Her Child which was published in the Age on 1 September this year. It reflects the sort of comment that has been made in the welfare sector and by the Democrats for a long time. Susan pointed put:

There is clearly little incentive to work when a sole parent receives a net gain of only $15 a week from 20 hours work because of the combined effect of taxation, the costs of working, loss of concessions, and income tests on child care, pension and, in some cases, public housing.
Poverty traps, together with the generally lower wages received by female sole parents-
we are talking of a vast majority of females in this situation-
means that work can only be rewarding personally but not financially.

I venture to suggest that Susan Barclay is actually being a little charitable because as we all know many of those low-paid jobs which women get if they are fortunate are all too often less than personally rewarding. Susan went on to point out that while the child support scheme is welcomed the fact that it continues not to have a maintenance guarantee for all children of sole parent families means that it in itself is deficient and will remain so in terms of the Government's social justice strategy and its child poverty strategy.

A comprehensive report has been made by the Brotherhood of St Laurence pointing out the specific problems of sole parents. That report was put together before the implementation of the child support system but many of the problems are still not addressed because of that deficiency within the child support system. A report in the Financial Review yesterday also referred to an increased emphasis on targeting and means testing to improve benefits resulting in severe and intractable poverty traps. Of course, it is a real dilemma for the Government-or for any government-following this EPAC report that targeted welfare benefits may be detrimental to the very people for whom they are designed in all good conscience to benefit. Sole parents are among those people who are increasingly targeted and in perhaps a different way. I noticed in this year's annual report of the Department of Social Security in the section which is talking about the increased effectiveness of the new mobile review teams that the rate of overpayments that had been identified amounted to $2.3m whereas in the annual report of the previous year the overpayments identified amounted to only half a million dollars. Clearly, that group has been targeted and nobody would stand here and say that people should be able to rip off the welfare system, but I urge all senators to look at the annual report of the Department of Social Security and to listen to all the debates on this topic.

I ask senators to look at what has been finally revealed by the high status EPAC report-things which have already been said by many other organisations; I have mentioned the Brotherhood of St Laurence, ACOSS, welfare rights units and centres in Melbourne and Sydney-and in other groups, such as sole parent groups, widows groups and so on. I ask senators to look at those and wonder about the $2.3m overpayments and about the targeting. We should wonder about the poverty traps and the built-in disincentives that are in the system. We should consider how much of that was genuinely ripping off the system or was simply the result of the built-in disincentives in the system and the disadvantages, both economic and personal, that face sole parents-largely women-in attempting to get themselves off the welfare roll and into secure employment. That is the only way for people to get out of poverty in the long term and is certainly the desirable course for the vast majority of people in the community. The question is as to how much of the targeting and suspicion in the community is justifiable. Even if it is legally justifiable-although I have often in this place questioned the workings of field officers and the way things are operating under the more draconian powers of the Department of Social Security-the question must be asked whether it is morally justifiable in the context of the sorts of problems outlined in the EPAC report.

I address specifically the question raised in the Opposition's amendment in relation to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), particularly the second point which complains about the Government mainly relying on bracket creep and which talks of the introduction of new incentive-sapping taxes. I reiterate the point that in the community there are people other than employed taxpayers whose incentive is being sapped by the taxation system in its relation to their income support systems. In regard to bracket creep I wonder whether the vehemence with which Opposition members are supporting that part of their amendment is any indication of proposed Opposition policy in this area. I note that the only way we shall avoid bracket creep in a progressive taxation system-a system which the Democrats support-is through indexation of marginal tax rates. One gives credit to the Fraser Government for introducing such indexation in 1976 and maintaining it through to 1977-78, but then one has to come up a little short and note that in 1978-79 indexation was reduced, shelved in 1979-80, reduced to half indexation in 1980-81, and abolished from 1 July 1982. One wonders whether, despite the Opposition vehemence on this issue in this chamber today, things would be any different under an alternative government, which I imagine the Opposition in this chamber sees itself to be.

Obviously any government-the runs are on the board-will be reluctant to introduce taxation indexation purely and simply for the reason that if it does it will not get the credit for the automatic tax cuts that apply under that sort of system. If there is one thing that we know about the members of governments or alternative governments it is that they want to get the credit for everything they possibly can, whether it is gold medals at Olympic games or tax cuts. In this case they have it within their power to ensure that they do get the credit. Therefore, they do not give us indexation and when not in government they complain about the fact that their opposite numbers have not taken that step either. Therefore, it has about it a hollow ring. One would be very interested to see whether the Fraser campaign in the 1975 election promising tax indexation is likely to be renewed in the next Federal election campaign.

The Opposition's amendment goes on to complain about the complexity and uncertainty of new taxes. I assume that the Opposition is talking about the just taxes introduced by this Government, to its credit, supported by the Democrats-the fringe benefits and capital gains taxes. The amendment also talks about the decrease in efficiency and equity in the tax system. I exhort Opposition members to go to the EPAC report and to recognise the areas of particular inequity, which I am pointing out on behalf of the welfare recipients, in terms of disincentive in the relationships they have with the taxation system, which is impeding their ability to get out of that system.

If the Opposition is talking about equity in the tax system, one has heard a great deal in recent days about a gold tax, a tax which the Opposition is opposing vehemently. I am told that it is designed to bring in $300m in a full year, which is roughly the same amount as the tax file number is said to bring in. The Opposition will support that proposal willy-nilly along with the Government at the risk of invading people's privacy. Nevertheless, that is the position. If we are talking about equity, as indeed the Opposition is in its amendment, it seems odd to the Australian Democrats that we could not obtain the Opposition's support a day or so ago to amend a sales tax Bill to prevent increased sales tax on soy milk, which would have cost the Government only a few hundred thousand dollars. In earlier years one has in mind the Democrats' amendments to stop sales tax on flavoured milk and increases in the sales tax on juice, and so on. Therefore, if we are talking about equity in the tax system, I do not know that the Opposition can expect too much support on that general basis from this corner of the chamber.

As I try on this occasion to represent the position of people who are outside the full employment sector in our economy but who are affected by the tax system, it is a matter of concern that the challenge before the Government of tax cuts for next year does not look very promising. I hope that the Government will take a great deal of account of EPAC's comments in this context. There is enough evidence around to show that there is a lot of pressure on the issue of tax cuts. There is, of course, the Treasurer. I noted an article by Laura Tingle in the Australian early in October this year which raised some issues which are of concern to the economic rationalists who too often prevail on both sides of the chamber. She pointed out, for instance, that cuts to lower income earners flow through to higher income groups as well, and that the majority of taxpayers-and this is a political problem-are now in a higher tax bracket. Therefore, it is difficult politically to give breaks to a minority of people. Laura Tingle said in her article:
These problems suggest that next year's tax cuts will be much more of a middle-class affair than the Government's rhetoric suggests.
Perhaps we should say `Senator Walsh's rhetoric suggests'. He is standing up, so far at any rate, to pressure on this issue.

I wish to interpose another area of pressure which comes from Senator Stone, the epitome of economic rationalism, perhaps neck and neck with the Treasurer. I happened to be at a conference of the Royal Australian Institute of Public Administration a week or so ago in Melbourne at which Senator Stone and Senator Walsh were attempting to put a different economic view, which in itself was a challenge, and I could not resist being in the audience. On that occasion Senator Stone-I have with me the notes I took in the audience-said that he considered Senator Walsh to be one of the more rational economic minds in the Government, except in his attitude to the tax cuts, on which so far I congratulate Senator Walsh. There is pressure that the tax cuts that are to come will not necessarily go to low income earners. They need to go to those people.

What we need most of all, at least for the groups of people I am talking about and also for single income, low income families, is a change to the tax-free threshold. That is a very expensive exercise for the Government. I acknowledge that it has gone some of the way in terms of the pension rebate, but all that means is that a pensioner can earn $10 a week above the permissible free area given by the rebate and that pensioner is into the tax system. It is a major problem and it is one which the EPAC report has brought out. It provides a great challenge to government, especially a government which says that it is committed to social justice and which publishes on the issue of social justice. Rhetoric is fine but we need action.

Laura Tingle pointed out in yesterday's Australian that the welfare lobby had had something of a significant win in the EPAC paper because it endorses those arguments that `social security payments have positive economic implications, such as reduced crime rate and preventing the loss of skills or educational standards'. I would add there `health and other issues'. That is an important message for a government which says that it is committed to social justice. However, looking at performance, how can we have social justice when major initiatives in housing have to do with increasing benefits for those who are in employment and in a position to purchase and do not add assistance to those people who are not in employment and desperately need public housing? For instance, last year $12m went back into Consolidated Revenue from the attendant care program because the guidelines are so strict. One has to question social justice in that context.

Clearly, there are two strands to any strategy which is directed towards achieving social justice. One is to address the current inadequacies, some of which the EPAC report talked about and others of which I have mentioned. Those current inadequacies must be addressed in the system delivering assistance to people in need. That is called targeting. It is a comment on our current priorities that most of the Government's actions so far-I mention also the Victorian social justice strategy, which is somewhat in advance of the Federal Government's strategy-are devoted to those remedial targeting-type measures.

The other strand which is necessary and which will have to be carried out if we are to get social justice is the strategic or developmental element which should be designed to produce structural changes and increase the capacity of people to break the cycle of disadvantage; that is, changing the nature of the system itself. That is the challenge that EPAC puts up to us in the context of taxation policy in the broader policies of government in general; that is, changing the system itself. In that context I commend to the Government a change to the system which the Australian Democrats are seriously examining-that is, the development of a more reasonable approach to the sort of guaranteed minimum income approach which was put as far back as the poverty inquiry in the 1970s. It is a national support income policy which has been put to us by Allan McDonald, currently of Queensland. This national income support system is not paid on top of existing incomes but replaces part of those incomes and is available to all people in the community. It was first developed in the context of the rapidly increasing unemployment of a decade or so ago. It is very much a system which does away with incentive-sapping overlaps in the current system, which the EPAC paper points to, and is perhaps the only system by which we can achieve social justice in reality. The author of the abridged paper which I have before me, and which I am very happy to give any honourable senator a copy of, asks:
Why must we continue to maintain our separate compartments for industrial relations and welfare?
He was referring to the nature of this exercise as part of the wage structure system. He continues:
why can't we consider preventing poverty rather than relieving poverty?

That is a very important question. I was interested to hear Julian Disney of ACOSS comment on the EPAC report on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio last night. He put the view that the way out of the problems that EPAC draws to our attention, problems which are inextricably linked to the taxation system, was perhaps to increase the number of people receiving some kind of social welfare support, other forms of assistance-not just pensions and benefits, but general social goods. It is the sort of concept that is embodied in the social wage. He advocated other forms of assistance, such as child care, being more broadly available perhaps so that people do not see themselves as separate from the social support systems which are inherent in our society. I thought that he used a very good example when he said that people somehow see payment for the family allowance, which we have very strictly income tested, as different from payments, for instance, that the Government puts into roads or other infrastructure. Why should we? We all benefit from the one and the question is whether we all, as members of the community, should not benefit from the other.

I think that those are the broad issues raised in the EPAC report in the context of the current debate about retirement incomes policy. They are very important and they are issues which this Government, the Opposition and all people making relevant decisions in this community need to bear in mind. Those are the major points that we can take out of the conjunction of the events of the EPAC report coming out and our dealing with a range of taxation Bills, as we are in this debate. Hopefully, we can come out with some rational approach which will avoid the disincentives, the poverty traps, for that group of people who may not be in full time paid employment but who may very well be trying earnestly to get there and finding all of these barriers in their way and, even worse, being condemned for the fact that they have to face disincentives which we have built into the system and which it is almost impossible for them to surmount.

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —There are a number of amendments, including some to be moved by the Government, to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) and a couple of amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). I will not go into the detail of those amendments at this stage; I will reserve that for the committee stage. In the second reading debate proper there have been numerous assertions, some of them so generalised that they were almost meaningless, some exaggerated, untrue or irrelevant. I will not waste a lot of time dealing with those.

speech.para: However, there were a couple of quite specific comments made in the second reading debate on which I want to set the record straight. Senator Panizza appears to be under the impression that the option to choose either the prime cost method of depreciation or the diminishing value method is an option which must be exercised at the time a piece of plant or equipment is purchased. That option can be exercised at the end of the year. In fact, it increases the options available to the taxpayer because the taxpayer may now make such a choice at the end of each year for plant purchased within that year, whereas previously a choice had to be made for one of the two methods on all existing and future assets or on all assets first depreciable in the year of election and in future years.

The second point relates to comments made by a couple of people at least about the uplift factor in the provisional tax. By the way, for the benefit of Senator Panizza, the first point related to plant depreciation. I do not know whether he heard what I said. Of course, the uplift factor is related to the very large increase which is anticipated in farm incomes for this year. The objective of the uplift factor for provisional tax is always for the provisional tax which is applied to be the best approximation of the actual income which the taxpayer will receive. But all taxpayers, of course, retain the option to vary that provisional tax assessment, which is based on the previous year's income adjusted by the uplift factor.

Amendments to the second reading motions have been moved in respect of both the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). I will deal first with the amendment in relation to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) because that is the way we will deal with them at the committee stage. That amendment, even with the most recently proposed amendment to it, is still a Clayton's amendment in so far as the last paragraph says:

(i) resolves that, where the Government has announced by press release its intention to introduce a bill to amend taxation law, and that Bill has not been introduced into Parliament within 3 calendar months of the date of that announcement, the Senate shall, subject to any further resolution . . .

I will not read any further but, as I interpret it, it is still a Clayton's amendment in so far as it does not-and, I expect, could not-bind the Senate in the way in which it deals with any future legislation. However, I do want to make some comments about it. It requires an extraordinary amount of chutzpah for the Opposition to put up an amendment which says that, because right off the top of my head I can recall the 5/3 depreciation measure, which is the subject of one of these Bills, being announced in July of 1982 by the then Treasurer, Mr Howard, and the Labor Government ultimately enacting it in May of 1983-a full 10 months afterwards. Indeed, the Fraser Government, though announcing the changes to 5/3 depreciation in July, over five whole months-over most of July, August, September, October, November and part of December-did not even bother to introduce legislation, much less have it passed. So it requires an extraordinary amount of chutzpah for the members of the then Government which did that, and which had even longer time lags on other occasions which I cannot specifically cite, to have the effrontery to propose something like this. I will be saying something about the more specific amendment regarding the date on, I think, Taxation Laws Amendments Bill (No. 4). That might surprise the Opposition, too. So, of course, the Government will not accept that second reading amendment, a Clayton's amendment though it is.
I will make just a brief comment on the proposed amendment in relation to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). The first paragraph says:
. . . the Senate notes that:
(i) this is the highest taxing Government in the post-war history of Australia.

I want to make this comment about that: the figures in this year's Budget Papers show that total taxation as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) is higher than in any other year recorded in that table-marginally higher than it was in 1982-83, the last year of the Fraser Government. However, there was no Medicare levy in 1982-83, and if allowance is made for that in fact the total taxation as a proportion of GDP in 1982-83 was marginally higher than it is predicted to be this year. But, much more importantly, the Fraser Government did not have a taxation policy so much as a borrowing policy, particularly in its final years. In 1982-83, it left a deficit of almost 2 1/2 per cent of gross domestic product. It is easy to get tax levels down if we pile up debts instead-and that is exactly what the Fraser Government, under John Howard's treasurership, did. By contrast, in this financial year, we are budgeting for a surplus of around 1.7 per cent of GDP. That is a total difference of more than 4 per cent of GDP in the effective, or properly measured, level of taxation once adjustment is made for whether a government is substituting a debt policy for a tax policy or running a tax policy in conjunction with a redemption of debt policy, as this Government is doing. When those adjustments are made, in fact the Fraser Government in its last year had an effective level of taxation, adjusted for debt and for Medicare, more than four percentage points of gross domestic product higher than is budgeted for this year. So, again, I can say only that it takes an extraordinary amount of chutzpah for the Opposition to move an amendment to the second reading motion such as that. Of course, we will oppose that as well when the time comes. Otherwise, I do not propose to delay the passage of the Bill any further.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (1) Page 13, clause 13, after proposed subsection 21a (2), insert the following new subsections:
`` `(2a) Where:
(a) a non-cash business benefit is income derived by a taxpayer in a year of income; and

(b) if the taxpayer had, at the time the benefit was provided, incurred and paid unreimbursed expenditure in respect of the provision of the benefit equal to the amount of the arm's length value of the benefit-a once-only deduction would, or would but for section 82a, and Subdivisions F and G of Division 3, have been allowable to the taxpayer in respect of a percentage (in this subsection called the ``deductible percentage'') of the expenditure;

This amendment was proposed by, I think, some private accountants and taken up by the Opposition. The Government agrees that the original clause left open the possibility of double taxation.
