talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: 1. Page 13, clause 13, proposed subsection 21a (3), proposed definition of `non-cash business benefit', lines 31 and 32, leave out ``4 February 1985'', insert ``31 August 1988''.

This amendment has the effect of altering the date of commencement of the Bill from 4 February 1985 to the date of the introduction of the Bill into the Parliament, 31 August 1988. As we discussed during the second reading stage of the debate, the origin of this piece of legislation was an announcement by the Government in a press release put out by the Treasurer on 4 February 1985. Since that time we have seen people going on in what basically is blissful ignorance of the law. Non-cash benefits of the kind that have been set down, or considered to have been set down in that press release some 3 1/2 years ago, have been accruing taxation as they have been received in the hands of taxpayers. The press release back in those times was not at all clear in its terms as to exactly what kinds of benefits were to be covered by it. In fact, the purpose of the amendments which we have just been discussing in the committee stage, and which have now been passed, were in respect of what might be loosely termed the `Avon ladies situation', where benefits of relatively little value which were being covered by the terms of this legislation were apparently going to be caught. However, there was no indication in the press statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) back in February 1985 that such benefits would be caught. Indeed, the press statement was almost misleading in that sense in that it seemed to indicate that the kinds of benefits that would be caught by the legislation were benefits which were the subject of the Federal Court case where the Commissioner of Taxation took issue with Cooke and Sherden. I understand the facts of that case were in relation to the provision of overseas travel for winners of trips overseas; that is, those kinds of benefits which were not convertible to cash. That being so, that was apparently the loophole which the Government was seeking to catch by the press statement that it made back in February 1985. However, the situation that we have with the so-called prizes for Tupperware ladies, Avon ladies and so on involves benefits--

talk.start.para: —Aren't there any Tupperware gentlemen?
—I suppose there are, now that the Minister comes to mention it.
—Tupperware persons.

—Tupper-persons, perhaps. The situation is that by the terms of this Bill, as distinct from that press statement, one would have believed that those persons would not have been caught. The reason I assert that is that small prizes such as saucepans, coffee mugs, or whatever they might be, that are being provided for people in those circumstances are the kinds of benefits which could be convertible to cash and consequently were not mentioned in the press statement as being the kinds of benefits that would otherwise be caught; yet when the legislation was brought down it indicated that such benefits could be caught. Therefore, that has been the purpose of the very useful negotiations we have had with the Treasurer's office to seek the amendments which have now been supported on all sides of the Senate. We welcome that kind of cooperation from the Treasurer. It is not something that we have seen much of over the last several years. It might have been very helpful, for instance, in relation to the passage of the capital gains tax through this Senate in 1985. The reason we are seeking for the date of the introduction of the legislation to be the operative date for the commencement of the new Act is simply that we believe that people were not on proper notice from 4 February 1985 in the terms of the press statement issued by the Treasurer then and, consequently, could not have known what the Government had in mind as to what exactly it was intending to catch by that legislation. In those terms it seems blatantly retrospective and consequently we oppose it on those grounds.

speech.para: The point has to be made that, back in the days of the tax schemes, it was a practice adopted by the former Government, the Fraser Government, and carried on to some extent by this Government, that a type of scheme, a type of series of transactions that had been identified by the Tax Office, was proscribed in a press statement with notice that any further schemes of that kind being undertaken would be subject to legislative proscription. That was indeed the practice that the former Government adopted. Clearly, in the case of avoidance, and where there are specific schemes being used in the community, there is every justification for that kind of approach because, quite clearly, those people who have indulged in those sorts of schemes should be put on notice that the Government intends to take action against them. Surely that is a totally different situation from that in which an announcement is made by the Government that it intends to legislate in particular cases according to its own whim. This statement of 4 February 1985 is in that category rather than being in the category of relating to those kinds of tax schemes that we saw in force around Australia in the period up to about 1984.

That is the reason, therefore, for our moving this amendment in order to make the application of the legislation come into force from 31 August 1988, that being the date of the introduction of the legislation. It seems to us to be perfectly consistent with past practice of both governments and of the Tax Office in former times. It is also perfectly consistent with the Liberal and National parties' approach to retrospective legislation now that we have identified that that legislation is retrospective.

talk.start.para: —It changes depending on whether you are in government or not.

—No, not at all. I think we have just explained that. The situation really is that this Government changed the rules as it came to draw up the legislation. That is the significant difference between our approach and the Government's approach.

speech.para: I simply wanted to indicate that we have a very sound basis for moving this amendment at this point. I would not be surprised if the Government used all kinds of specious arguments which might lead us down other tracks in defence of its position on this matter, but the principle is crystal clear: the Government has legislated retrospectively and that is the point of principle upon which we stand. I hope that we will have the support of the Australian Democrats.

speech.speaker: Haines Sen J.

talk.start.para: —I am a little puzzled as to why Senator Messner should have offered us that last sentence since I thought I made it perfectly clear in the debate on the second reading on this matter that not only were we just as concerned as members of the Liberal Party were over the Government's increasing habit of legislating by press release, but that I had, in fact, last month written to both the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) pointing out that we were not going to tolerate this sort of thing any longer, particularly when we have a situation, such as applies here, where something like 3 1/2 years passes between the time that the press release is put out announcing the proposed legislation and the time that it is introduced. I will read from a copy of a letter that I wrote to the Prime Minister. It states:

speech.para: I am writing to you and the Treasurer on the vexed subject of legislation by press release. The Australian Democrats have raised their concern about this on numerous occasions in the past and we remain convinced that the practice is not acceptable. Individuals and businesses have no choice but to adjust their transactions immediately-

I interpolate here that that is assuming they know about it and frequently people selling Avon or Tupperware products and so on are not aware, but those that are have no choice but to adjust their transactions immediately-

despite the fact that the merits of the legislation have not been considered by the Parliament. Furthermore, the parliamentary debate itself is affected by the press release declaring the immediate effect of the proposed law.

We certainly had a problem there-again I interrupt myself to point this out-with some legislation affecting the operation of insurance companies last year. It was announced by press release months and months before the Parliament actually got to look at it. I went on to point out to the Prime Minister:

. . . the Law Council of Australia has devised guidelines on legislation by press release. The Australian Democrats endorse those guidelines with the exception that legislation must be available to the public within 3 months after the date of the announcement (as opposed to the one month time frame proposed by the L.C.A.).
I attached a copy of those guidelines in the letter to both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. I then went on to say:
The Australian Democrat Senators have agreed that, unless these sensible and moderate guidelines are adhered to we will amend legislation of this kind by inserting a new starting date.

We believe that many of the problems that have occurred in the past could be avoided if your Government adopted these guidelines. In the interests of the Australian citizens and businesses adversely affected by the practice of legislation by press release, we hope that you will accept the guidelines and avoid the necessity of the Australian Democrats addressing the problem in the way I have outlined.

The guidelines for legislation by press release that were attached to those letters to the Treasurer and the Prime Minister were, as I said, those of the Law Council of Australia, with the exception that its point (g) was changed by us to say that:

The legislation must be available to the public within three months after the date of the announcement either by its introduction into Parliament or if Parliament is not sitting, by public release of the Bill by the Treasurer.

That is so that people actually know what they are getting themselves into. The Government can say `We told you that in the press release'. Well, press releases are two or three pages long at most, and some of this legislation is extremely complex. Until we actually sit down and look at clauses in Bills, we are not in a position to know precisely how the legislation is going to affect us, our business, our employees and so on, or whether it will have any unintended consequences. Heaven alone knows, we get unintended consequences in legislation all the time.

What makes the situation worse on this occasion is that first of all it was, as I said, some three and a half years between the press release being issued and the legislation being issued. But more importantly, some changes were made in the legislation so that the proposals that were announced three and a half years ago were not accurately reflected when the Bill was finally produced. When we have a three and a half year time gap and then the legislation differs from the announcement, there is a very real problem. In fact, the Government admitted this by including transitional provisions in clause 54. Then we find, according to submissions from Arthur Young, that the transitional provisions also differ from the announcement. It argues in a letter to us that the proposed legislation will, in its opinion, apply to benefits received after 4 February 1985, even though the benefits may have been provided under contracts entered into on or before that date.

The Treasurer's announcement did not make it clear that the legislation would apply to benefits provided under contracts entered into on or before 4 February 1985. In addition, the February 1985 press release says `The amendments which are to apply to benefits given or granted after today . . .'. In the legislation, clause 13 states `non-cash business benefit' means property or services provided after 4 February 1985', while the transitional provisions in clause 54 state `The section applies to non-cash business benefits provided on or before 31 August 1988'. One is left very much up in the air wondering whether the legislation applies to benefits provided under contracts entered into on or before 4 February 1985.

All of this highlights the real problem we have of legislating by press release, a problem which is exacerbated by the fact that there is such a huge time frame between the press release and the legislation that is finally produced. That is why I think that last guideline from the Law Council of Australia is such an important one, that there be a maximum period between the announcement and the production of the legislation, either in the Parliament or by way of draft to the general public. We will certainly be supporting the amendment moved by Senator Messner. The only reason we are supporting him instead of his supporting us is that, as usual, the Opposition gets precedence when it comes to amendments in this place. We had already signalled our intention to make these moves.

I would like to make one other point. When the Government issues press releases which announce legislative changes, whilst it is certainly not going to be able to dot all the `i's and cross all the `t's-to do that it really has to produce a draft of the legislation, and if it could do that it would not have to worry about the press release-it should at least make those announcements in the press releases as clear, precise and understandable as possible, so that the people who are to be affected know they are to be affected, know how they are to be affected and know from when they are to be affected. We should not get to the situation where we have announcements that do not match legislation, and transitional clauses that do not match the announcements.
We will certainly be supporting the amendment to clause 13 to change the starting date of this legislation on non-cash benefits from 4 February 1985 to 31 August 1988.

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —Non-cash benefits which were convertible to cash have always been taxable in the hands of the recipients, and still are, and until the Cooke and Sherden case of 1980 so were non-convertible benefits of an income nature. But the court in 1980 ruled that non-convertible benefits could not be subject to tax. This legislation seeks to ensure that in future they are.

speech.para: The present Opposition, the then Government, had at least a couple of years between 1980 and 1982 in which to do something about the Cooke and Sherden decision, but it did not do anything. Because of that anomaly, interpretation, writing of the law in the courts, or whatever one would like to call it, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) made the statement in 1985 that benefits which were not convertible to cash would be taxed as they had been prior to 1980, in the same way that benefits which are convertible to cash continued to be.

I concede that it is a long time between 1985 and the introduction of legislation in 1988 and the Government is vulnerable to criticism on that ground. However, that does not justify the action proposed by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats or the amendment moved. I understand-indeed, Senator Messner has made this fairly clear-that the Opposition was activated by approaches on behalf of Tupperware and Avon agents and people who had been receiving benefits. However, it appears that the benefits they received were in fact of a convertible nature rather than a non-convertible nature and, therefore, probably would not be affected by the provisions of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4). However, since the attention of the Commissioner of Taxation has been drawn to the convertible benefits received by these agents, they are effectively inviting an audit and assessment of the convertible benefits they have received going right back to 1936, if they have been receiving them for that length of time. Whether that will actually be done is a matter for the Commissioner of Taxation to decide. This could well be an exercise that will backfire rather heavily on the people who originally made the representations because, irrespective of what happens to this legislation, even if it is thrown out altogether, if benefits of the type which have been described have been received, they are, according to the advice I have, likely to be taxable as convertible benefits. Drawing attention to the fact that they have been received is an invitation for an audit.
I have received a note from the Australian Taxation Office that I ought to read out because it is very important. It reads:

It should also be highlighted that there is, among a few, a serious misconception that non-cash benefits of a kind that can be convertible into a value have only become assessable as a result of these amendments. On the contrary, these non-cash but convertible items have always been assessable since 1936 under ordinary concepts of income. Examples of items taxable since 1936 are motor cars, television sets, microwave ovens, jewellery received by taxpayers in lieu of cash income. The new law merely provides a valuation rule for all non-cash business benefits and extends the net to include non-convertible non-cash business benefits.

That is relevant to the point I was just making. The advice received by the Government from the Taxation Office is that the revenue resulting from and the effect of the amendment Senator Messner has just moved will be negligible because the announcement back in 1985 put an end to the practice which was rapidly developing of paying benefits of a non-convertible kind and thereby avoiding tax. Our advice is that the 1985 announcement virtually stopped that practice stone dead, so the revenue losses will be negligible.

However, the Government will not accept the amendment, because if it is carried it will mean that announcements that taxation rorts will be knocked on the head will no longer be a viable threat to the people who have been doing the rorting. Indeed, it will be tantamount to an invitation to lay one's ears back and get right into it as far as one can and as quickly as one can. If the three-month provision which the Australian Democrats now propose to move, as I understand it, to the next piece of legislation as a Clayton's amendment-still with the idea that the Senate will impose a three-month rule-actually receives some credence, that will exacerbate the problem. I have already conceded that the Government is vulnerable to some valid criticism for this piece of legislation, but I have been sufficiently involved in taxation policy over the last few years to realise that certain pieces of legislation and, in particular, legislation that is designed to stop tax avoidance frequently require some very complex drafting. Even if the parliamentary draftsman, the Taxation Office and the tax policy branch of the Treasury had nothing else to do, which is never the case, it would take a considerable length of time to draft such measures.

I appeal to the Opposition: What it is doing here is potentially very dangerous if it goes ahead with it. It is even more dangerous if there is an expression of opinion-and it would be no more than that-of the Senate that three months is the longest period that will be allowed between an announcement to close off a tax rort and the introduction of legislation into the Parliament. Let me give an example. Normally the Parliament adjourns in the first week of December and resumes in the third or fourth week in February. That leaves a space of nearly 2 1/2 months, which is normal. If the Government becomes aware in the beginning of November, say, of a serious tax rort and makes an announcement that it is going to close it off, unless it can get the legislation into Parliament within a month-which, if it is at all complicated, is a completely unreasonable expectation-then the three months rule will not be complied with unless a special sitting of Parliament is called in January. I suppose that is an option that is available; it is not one that would be welcomed by the people in the Parliament at the time.

I say again that, according to the advice I have received, the revenue consequences of this amendment are negligible, but if the Opposition proceeds with the amendment it will be setting a precedent which could well undermine the effective closing of taxation rorts and loopholes in the future.

talk.start.para: —I wish to bring to the Committee's attention another matter which has been the subject of some discussion with the Government in recent times. It was referred to during the course of the debate at the second reading stage. This is bringing to light the situation where a partnership changes its constitution for one reason or another. The underlying property is the subject of the depreciation laws as they have applied up until now and since 1982, but as I understand the provision of the law, after the application of this change, the new less liberal system of depreciation rates will apply. As such, it would cause the partnership, as reconstituted, to lose the benefit of the previous rates. This would apply notwithstanding that a change to a partnership, be it a professional partnership, a joint venture or perhaps a property development, might only be of a very minor kind. It may be, for instance, with a professional partnership, as I understand it, a change of, say, 10 per cent of the total ownership of the underlying asset. That is something that obviously is unfair where the benefits of the previous depreciation rates structure have been lost, notwithstanding a very minor change to the overall constitution of a partnership.

speech.para: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

talk.start.para: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner we were discussing clause 37, which deals with the new system of depreciation as announced in the Treasurer's statement of 25 May. The effect of this is noted in an article in the Australian Financial Review today which summarises the story quite well. The matter I raise affects partnerships where there is a reorganisation of the constitution of a partnership. As a result the previously more generous depreciation taxation regime applicable to the underlying property of the partnership before 25 May may be lost because of that minor change. Following 25 May a vastly less generous system of depreciation deductions was made available to business. This may well affect the situation where there has been a relatively minor change in the ownership or construction or constitution of a partnership, whereas the underlying property itself had not been changed at all-that underlying property being the subject of tax deductions for depreciation. There could be changes in the partnership of, say, 10 per cent where a partner comes in and takes over the partnership of another. The percentage may be less, or it may be more. Concern has been expressed in the business community, as pointed out in the article to which I have referred, that significant tax benefits may be lost arising from what is a very technical change.

speech.para: Partners under the tax law, as I remember it, where there is a continuing ownership of a property by the partnership, are deemed to have sold the property to the new partnership at what might be determined as an agreed value for the property. The question is what value has been agreed, and therefore there is some question as to what the Australian Taxation Office might consider as being a reasonable value in these circumstances. It means that in each individual case of partnership reconstitution since 25 May this year there will have to be individual negotiations with the Taxation Office to determine how the new depreciation regime might apply to each individual circumstance. This is said by the article in the Australian Financial Review to be because of the lack of clarity in the law. Therefore, I ask the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) whether he is prepared to give his views to the Committee about how the system might operate within the Taxation Office as a result of this matter being brought to his attention. In other words, is he prepared to give an undertaking that the benefits of the previously owned property under the old taxation rates before 25 May would continue to apply after a change to the constitution of a partnership where that partnership change is relatively minor?

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —Whether the change was minor or not, as I understand the position, the answer to the question is no-that the new tax depreciation rates would apply. I have a more comprehensive answer from the Australian Taxation Office on this question. It says:

speech.para: In response to the question regarding 5/3 depreciation, I have been advised that the Commissioner does not have a discretion to allow a taxpayer to `rollover' 5/3 depreciation in circumstances where there is a disposal-that is, after 25 May 1988-of a part interest in an asset that is currently being written off under the 5/3 regime.

Special provisions of the income tax law apply whenever there is a disposal of a depreciable asset. If there is a difference between the sale price of the asset and its depreciated value, the resultant gain or loss is treated as assessable income or as an allowable deduction, as the case may be, of the vendor. This treatment ensures that a taxpayer receives a deduction for any decrease in the value of an asset in excess of that already allowed as a deduction, and conversely that the revenue recoups tax lost where a deduction has been allowed for depreciation in excess of the actual decrease in its value.
The income tax law also has specific provisions designed to apply the same rules where there is a disposal only of a part of an interest in a depreciable asset.
That is the case to which Senator Messner referred.

In these cases, the whole asset is treated as having been sold from the old owner or owners to the new owner or owners. This ensures that any taxpayer who disposes of an interest in a depreciable asset includes in their taxable income the gain or loss arising from their portion of any difference between the sale price of the asset and its depreciated value, at the time of change.

There is not discretion in the Commissioner not to apply these rules in the case of a partial disposal. Further, it would be inconsistent to apply the existing rules on a partial basis only, that is to treat the disposal as a full disposal, without also applying the current rates.

It should also be noted-and this is very important-that when the 5/3 regime was first introduced in 1983, disposals of part interest in a partially depreciated asset operated to apply 5/3 to that asset. In other words, at the time of the 5/3 change for the great majority, if not all, depreciable assets the rate of write-off would be accelerated following the introduction of the 5/3 regime. For most, though probably not all, under the provisions of this legislation the rate of write-off would decelerate. There were windfall gains in 1983 when the 5/3 regime was introduced, and there will be windfall losers when the new regime is introduced. I should qualify the term `windfall gainers and losers' because it is the action of individuals in making their decision to change the structure of the partnership which will affect whether they are gainers or losers, and not the legislation per se.

talk.start.para: —I would like the Minister to confirm that his argument is correct. I was under the impression that the 5/3 scheme, as it applied from whenever it was in 1983, was applicable to new plant. Is the Minister saying that it applies to all plant on hand at that time?
—That is what the note I have in front of me says. I am advised that there is a mild clarification of what is written here. Primary production plant had to be new, but other did not.

—I am thankful for the Minister's correction of that point, and for restoring my memory. I do not wish to take a lot of time over another point, but I wish it to be placed on the record. When there is an agreed value after a change in the constitution of a partnership, will that agreed value-irrespective of the level; whether higher or lower than the original cost of the plant-definitely have the new depreciation regime applied to it after the date of the change?
—I understand that the answer is yes, as long as it does not exceed the market value and is below the appreciated value.
—Which is a matter of assessment by the Commissioner.

—I assume that the market value would be a Commissioner's discretion matter. If the value claimed was, prima facie, greatly at variance with what some knowledge told one it should be, it would be at the Commissioner's discretion to vary it. That has just been confirmed by a nod from one of the officers.

—Will the Minister consider the matter more deeply? Will the Government consider further amendments if this is demonstrated to be a matter of hardship in what might be regarded as the ordinary course of business with the reconstitution of professional partnerships, et cetera, from time to time?

—I think that I can give an undertaking to consider, but my intuition tells me that it is unlikely that the Government would be persuaded. However, if there are particular cases, I am willing to give an assurance that we will look at them with a view to amendment should we come to the conclusion that there is a valid case for doing so.

talk.start.para: —The effects of proposed new section 45, which seeks to insert new subdivision H, were announced in the May mini-Budget and preclude the immediate up-front deduction of amounts that have come into existence through the trading in of contracting plant, transport equipment and so on where an amount received for the traded in plant is well in excess of the residual value of that plant as described in a lease agreement. Past practice in the transport industry and other industries for the refinancing of new equipment in these circumstances has been to use lease arrangements. As I understand it, the surplus over the residual balance has been treated as a one-off payment to the financing institution and, as such, has represented a part of the total rental payment on the lease of the new equipment. That payment has, therefore, become a tax deduction where the plant is used for the earning of assessable income.

speech.para: The point I raise with the Minister was raised at the second reading stage and has been raised with the Treasurer by certain accountants and interests associated with the transport industry. Is a deduction denied for such an up-front payment, which represents a surplus earned on the trading in of a property or item of plant and which, logically, has been gained over a much longer period and therefore should be spread over the whole of the period of the lease? I think I know what the answer to that question is. However, the point is whether the Minister can confirm that a tax deduction will be denied in those circumstances, and whether that is consistent with the Government's approach in this legislation. In other words, did it intend such financing arrangements for the re-leasing of new equipment and the offsetting of surpluses gained in that way by the trading in of old equipment to be caught by this part of the Bill?

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —Personally, I do not have the faintest idea what the answer is, but I have been given some advice. I quote from a letter from the Acting Treasurer-which means that it must have been written some time last month-to an accountant in Adelaide:

speech.para: The changes announced were designed to ensure that prepaid expenses, which in the past had been immediately deductible, would in future be deductible over a period more in line with the period over which the related services were provided.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —I draw the Committee's attention to the obvious hardship that that will create in some parts of industry. It will certainly have an impact in the trucking industry, where this is a very common practice in dealing with the surplus gained in the situation I have outlined. It will obviously have an impact on future freight rates charged to customers for carting wheat, wool and other primary produce, and will lead to higher charges in future. The other question is whether it will have an impact on an industry which, generally, has been regarded as being in a state of financial crisis for quite a long time.

speech.para: It is not only in the transport industry that such an effect could be felt. It will also impact on the earth-moving industries and thereby have a major impact on building costs at a time of rapidly rising prices for housing which the Government has, I understand, been seeking to combat. Yet it is driving further costs onto builders and those engaged in that industry and that must be reflected in higher inflation rates. That is notwithstanding a 4 per cent increase in the housing index announced only about a fortnight ago with the most recent consumer price index figures. I wonder what the Government is really on about in these circumstances since it will have major impacts on not only individual operators but also the economy as a whole.

This is not just some kind of tax gimmick or way of avoiding tax. It is a result of the inflationary circumstances in which people with this kind of equipment find themselves when they trade into newer equipment. Let me give an example. A trucking rig that might have been purchased five years ago for $100,000 might cost $200,000 today. The residual value of a plant item purchased that long ago as described in the lease at the time might have been $25,000. If one were to trade in that item of plant today, because of inflation and the increased value of the new item of plant one might receive, say, $75,000 for the value of that old plant, which is well in excess of the residual value of the lease. That means that that surplus of $50,000 is really just an inflationary adjustment; it is not really reflective of a real gain. For that reason it has been dealt with in the way described and has been the subject of comment in the last few minutes.

I believe the Government ought to consider amending the legislation so as to take account of the situation, because quite clearly it will have an inflationary impact right where we do not want it. We do not want increases in building and housing costs. We do not want increases in trucking rates that will impact on farmers in drought areas. Of course, this is a factor in my State of South Australia, half of which is in drought. That is the sort of problem we will see in the next few months as a result of this kind of policy. I am sorry to hear the Minister's answer, and I disagree strongly with his views.

speech.speaker: Haines Sen J.

talk.start.para: —Due to a slight misunderstanding among an assortment of senators earlier today, it was not made possible for the chamber to amend the second reading motion for the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) to express the Senate's concern about the Government's use of legislation by press release. I now move:

speech.para: At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate-
(a) supports a more certain and predictable taxation system for all taxpayers;
(b) notes that the government is creating widespread uncertainty and confusion in the minds of taxpayers through its blatant use of `legislation by press release';
(c) expresses the view that, in the interim period before legislation is introduced, press announcements should be as clear and precise as possible; and

(d) resolves that, where the Government has announced, by press release, its intention to introduce a Bill to amend taxation law, and that Bill has not been introduced into the Parliament or made available by way of publication of a draft Bill, within 6 calendar months of the date of that announcement, the Senate shall, subject to any further resolution, amend the Bill to provide that the commencement date of the Bill shall be a date that is no earlier than either the date of introduction of the Bill into the Parliament, or the date of publication of the draft Bill''.

This amendment has been amended slightly from the one that was circulated earlier, at the request of the Opposition. The request took place as we were crossing the floor to have the original division. Part (d) of the amendment has been amended. During that earlier division, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) indicated that three months was likely to be an inappropriate length of time and that, in the case of excessively complicated pieces of legislation-which, I hasten to point out, the one under debate earlier today is not-three calendar months was not sufficient for the Government to present a Bill to the Parliament. So, at the suggestion of Senator Messner, we have now given the Government six calendar months, six times the length of time recommended by the Law Council of Australia and twice as long as the period we had earlier thought reasonable. Also, we have given the Government the opportunity, in the event of the Parliament not being in session at the time, actually to produce draft legislation for discussion. That, of course, is something that has happened in the past. Governments of all persuasions regularly release draft legislation for debate in the community, particularly if it is likely to be about contentious issues.

The dates relevant to the commencement of the Bill will relate either to the date of the introduction to Parliament of the Bill or to the date of publication of the draft Bill. Furthermore, written into the last paragraph of the amendment is a proviso that all of this is subject to any further resolution. So I cannot see how we could have done any better than we have in at least expressing the opinion of the Senate that members of Parliament and the public generally are getting increasingly disturbed and concerned at the way in which governments operate legislation by press release, expecting people to know what is in the press release and somehow to divine what will be in the subsequent legislation and to arrange their matters of business, income tax payments and so on accordingly. I remind the Senate that this expression of opinion is being done in a way which is not binding, since it is only an attachment to the second reading motion. I think this is not an unreasonable second reading attachment.

In the event of a government other than a Labor government ever being in power, I am quite sure that Senator Walsh, if he is shadowing the Finance or Treasury portfolio, will be more than pleased not to be confronted with a piece of legislation that has been 3 1/2 years in gestation following the original seed planting exercise of the press release. I hope this amendment will get the support it deserves from both sides of the chamber.

talk.start.para: —In the interests of glasnost, perestroika and everything else, I indicate that the Liberal and National parties will support the Australian Democrats on this amendment. I feel a little peeved in that we did not get the Democrats' support for our amendments of a similar kind.

—Yes, but only with our assistance is it better. We had a debate about this at an earlier stage. I think it is time for the Parliament to speak about it. Here is the opportunity for that to occur. I hope that the Government will see fit not to oppose this amendment.

speech.para: 1. Page 24, clause 37, proposed subparagraph 160zwa (13) (b)(ii), line 3, leave out ``and''.
2. Page 24, clause 37, after proposed subparagraph 160zwa (13) (b)(ii), insert the following new subparagraph:

`` `(iia) if land (in this subparagraph called `the excepted land') that formed part (whether a minor part or a significant part) of the original area is not included in the new area but land (in this subparagraph called `the new land') that did not form part of the original area is included in the new area-the circumstances that gave rise to the exclusion of the excepted land from, and the inclusion of the new land in, the new area and, in particular, the circumstance where the taxpayer sought, but was unable to secure, the inclusion of the excepted land and agreed to the inclusion of the new land only as a substitute for the excepted land; and'.''.

The Australian Democrats have circulated three amendments relating to two concerns that I raised during the second reading debate that took place what seems like quite a long time ago. One concern related to marital breakdowns between 1985 and the subsequent period in 1988, and the other related to the section of the Bill relating to roll-over relief from capital gains tax for land converted from a crown lease to freehold. The first two amendments deal with the latter-that is, crown leases. The first amendment is, I guess, a consequential amendment or a preceding amendment to the major amendment to clause 37.

The main case that has been drawn to our attention is that of E. L. Yencken and Co. Pty Ltd, which currently leases some land from the Crown in South Melbourne. The Victorian Government informed this company on 6 October 1987 that, to achieve the Government's planning, redevelopment and financial objectives, it would not be offered the whole site it presently occupies under a crown lease but part of it and an adjoining piece of land in substitution. That, I gather, is where the problem arises.

Under the amendments to the roll-over provisions relating to capital gains tax contained in the legislation before us, the company will be able to retain only about 56 per cent of its capital gains tax free asset; that is, the ownership of the new land will be treated as a post-19 September 1985 purchase which is subject to capital gains tax when it is sold in the future. The relevant proposed new subsection in this Bill provides that, where the original area differs from the new area, the Commissioner of Taxation may treat the new asset as relating in whole or in part to the old asset. The Commissioner is directed to have regard to all relevant circumstances in reaching such a decision, including those specifically set out in the legislation.

However, we run into a problem with the explanatory memorandum, which suggests that proposed new subsection 13 is to be read restrictively so that it will apply only where there are marginal differences between the original and new areas of the land. In Yencken's case, and because of a decision made by the State Government, the new area accounts for 44 per cent of the total land area. This was not a decision that was made by Yencken. It was not requested by that company; it was a decision which was made for the convenience of the Victorian Government.

With the assistance of Freehill, Hollingdale and Page, the Democrats have had drafted an amendment which seeks to include in the legislation another relevant circumstance that the Commissioner in exercising his or her discretion must have regard to concerning old and new assets-in particular, the circumstance in which a taxpayer has sought but has been unable to secure the old asset unchanged. The amendment will protect not only Yencken but also taxpayers generally in this class of situation where an unequal taxation treatment would otherwise result because the old and new assets are not `substantially the same' as presently defined in the Bill.

I think it is important that these sorts of-I presume-unintended consequences are not allowed to go through. This company-and it is probably not the only one-has been leasing land for some time. It would have quite happily taken over, more or less, the site it presently occupies but it simply did not suit the Crown for it to take over that land. So an alternative offer was made by the Crown-that is, by the State Government-to Yencken. Under those circumstances, it seems unfortunate that the Commissioner is to have discretion only to take into account marginal variations, when it is, as I said, not the company but the Crown that is making the necessary changes.

I do not want to go on at length about this matter. I think it is a perfectly straightforward case. The site had one lot of boundaries when it was leased. The transfer suggested by the Victorian State Government has another set of boundaries. There is a significant change in the boundaries although part of the property is the original leased land. If I and everybody else are reading the legislation right, the Taxation Commissioner is given no discretion because marginality certainly cannot be extended, under anybody's definition, to mean 44 per cent. I ask the Government, as well as the Opposition, to look kindly on these amendments because this matter is something that is out of the hands of the group that originally leased the land.

talk.start.para: —I just want to indicate that we in the Liberal and National parties will be supporting these amendments. The point at issue concerns a person who, ever so briefly, loses control over property in the conversion of a crown lease to freehold, a situation which the Yencken case exemplifies, and has conditions forced upon him which were not contemplated at the time the crown lease was originally granted. The effects of the law as it is set down presently would be unfair to any person in that situation. That is why we support this amendment. We believe that the Government would be otherwise taking advantage of what is a temporary condition whereby a crown lessee has lost control of his property in the legal argle-bargle of receiving his freehold. He has no bargaining position with the crown lessor and as a result is not able to negotiate from a position of strength in terms of what shape the property he originally contracted for might end up. There is an element of compulsion in this which in the case of Yencken and no doubt others is exercised by a State government. In that event, given those circumstances of compulsion we believe that it is totally unfair for the Government not to grant relief from capital gains tax in a situation where people could literally be caught with their pants down.
—I hope not literally.
—Metaphorically speaking. Senator Haines would not subscribe to that?
—My personal feelings on the matter are not relevant; the other person's might be.
—That summarises our position. We will be supporting Senator Haines's amendment.

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —The Bill already allows roll-overs, in cases where a piece of leasehold land is converted to freehold and where land is offered in lieu of land which has been compulsorily acquired and land offered in lieu of land that is under threat of acquisition; that is, when there are negotiations between a State government, usually, and the previous landholder. In addition, there is a discretion available to the Commissioner to allow roll-overs for exchanges of land-non-compulsory-if the differences in the land are marginal. As I understand it, Senator Haines is correct that that is the intention of it-that the differences would have to be slight before the Commissioner would exercise that discretion. The Government believes that that has gone far enough. It does not accept the amendment, for the reason I have given; that is, we believe we have gone far enough, and also because it could be used as a lever for further extensions of roll-over provisions for changes of ownership of shares following takeovers or mergers of companies. I know that that is not in the amendment but it is a step in that direction which somebody at some time might try to use as a precedent for further extension, which I presume the Australian Democrats at least-I am not so sure about the Opposition-do not support.

speech.para: In the Yencken case, it is not clear from the representations made to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) whether the surrender of the lease was voluntary, whether it was compulsory, or whether there was a threat of compulsion behind it. I understand that in that specific case part of the lease has been or will be surrendered and an alternative area of land immediately adjacent to the other part of the lease will be provided in lieu. The portion of the original landholding which was retained would, of course, be rolled over but the new portion would not be. I guess that will change if this amendment is carried. It is quite clear that the Opposition and the Democrats are supporting it. The Government does not accept it, but I will not bother to call a division for the reasons stated before.
Amendments agreed to.

speech.speaker: Haines Sen J.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: 3. Page 34, clause 46, proposed paragraph 160zzma (1) (a), line 30, leave out ``after 28 January 1988'', insert ``on or after 20 September 1985''.

Again, this relates to a matter I brought up in the second reading debate. Clause 46 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) extends the roll-over provisions to assets indirectly owned by the transferors. It actually affects people whose marriages broke down during a specific period, namely, between 20 September 1985 and 28 January 1988. Any transfer of property that took place prior to 20 September 1985 would not have attracted a capital gains tax because no capital gains tax applied in these sorts of areas pre-September 1985. Post-28 January 1988, which is the period this legislation covers, the same will apply. However, obviously some marriages have been dissolved in the intervening period. Court orders have been made for the transfer of property wholly owned by one spouse to the other spouse by way of distributing the property as a consequence of that divorce.

This is where the problem has arisen. Some people have been caught up in this situation. If the owner of the property-we are talking about property owned prior to the introduction of capital gains tax-disposed of it, no capital gains tax would accrue because the property was in the hands of that individual when capital gains tax was not applicable on the sale of the property. If between 20 September 1985 and 28 January 1988 a court order required that that property be transferred to the other spouse in the marriage that has now broken down and that spouse disposes of the property, a capital gains tax will apply because, although the marital property is being shared up through the Family Court system, the transfer is regarded as a change of ownership and hence capital gains tax accrues. Presumably, if the owner of the property sold it and the money was then handed over, no capital gains tax would apply and everything would be fine. But because the property is being handed over and then sold, the spouse-it is usually the wife in this case; when an individual owns property it is usually the male rather than the female--

talk.start.para: —Don't bet on that.

—I am prepared to bet that in 99 per cent of the cases that is so. So we are leaving a woman with less value because the capital gains tax will accrue. I do not know whether the court takes that into account and says, `We will give her a bit extra because when she disposes of this property it is going to be taxed'. In any event, the roll-over provisions as they apply have left this anomaly. Our amendment simply corrects this, so whether it is pre-20 September 1985, post-28 January 1986 or any period in between, any property which has been owned prior to the September 1985 date and is transferred through court orders in marital breakdowns will not be subject to capital gains tax. That means that three groups of people now involved in these transactions in the case of marital breakdowns will be treated fairly, equitably and, indeed, identically.

speech.speaker: Panizza Sen J.H.

talk.start.para: —I support this amendment. I raised this point last night in the second reading debate. It is the first time I have supported anything the Australian Democrats have brought up.
—You supported the amendment they moved 10 minutes ago.

—That is right, but I did not speak on it. There is a famous case in Western Australia, which I will not name as it would embarrass the woman concerned. I spoke about it last night. A marriage broke down after 40 years. The woman could have hauled a lot of money out of a business and probably could have taken her husband to the cleaners, which would have wound the business up, but she decided to have mercy on him and take some property that was in a trust or some sort of equity. She took that instead of hauling money out of the business. She was happy, and the business kept going. But, obviously, such a matter, as Senator Haines has pointed out, is caught in the status of a losing capital gains situation. I understand that if there had been a court order to the effect that property owned by the husband be transferred to the wife, that would not be covered. In other words, it would still remain in a status free situation.

speech.para: For some unknown reason the Government has now sought to fix the situation up with roll-over relief on all the other things we have spoken of and has taken it retrospectively to 1985-except the case that has been mentioned in this chamber, the Yencken case in Melbourne, where the boundaries did not quite fit. That has been fixed up retrospectively to 1985. Strangely enough, with the breakdown of marriage, where the spouse took out property from some sort of equity, the Government did not seem to address that. I ask the following questions: Did the Government simply not think about this? Did it see it but choose to ignore it? Or did it do it deliberately?

talk.start.para: —I would say it was a genuine oversight.

—Fair enough. Senator Haines kept saying that this was because of a court order. I might be ignorant of the case, but I would like to be assured that this provision does not cover even property that is not the subject of a court order; in other words, two human beings sitting down, after 40 years, and deciding to split the property that way without a court order.

speech.para: Outside of that, I think this is probably the biggest anomaly in any taxation amendment Bill that I have seen since I have been a member of this place. It certainly needs addressing, because, as I said last night, the marriage concerned broke down after only about 2 1/2 years. It is bad enough that marriages break down, anyhow, without the parties having this sort of matter hanging over their heads in time to come. It will only come to a head when the property is disposed of. If that spouse I mentioned, the woman-it could have been the husband who got the settlement-hangs on to the property for the rest of her life, she may not suffer the consequences. But in all probability, people in such a position may wish to dispose of the property. I think that that problem should be lifted from them. I would like to hear what the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has to say about what the Government will do about the situation. Also, how did the Government miss this anomaly?

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —Firstly, the amendment will only be applicable pursuant to either an order of the Family Court of Australia or a maintenance agreement approved of by the court, because that is what is written in clause 46 in the Bill. The Government is opposing this proposed amendment on a number of grounds, not the least of which is that it introduces a further significant complication into the administration and application of a capital gains tax law and because there are potential winners and losers on a fairly arbitrary or chance basis.

speech.para: For example, a spouse would gain under these circumstances where an asset to be transferred was acquired by the company before the commencement date of the capital gains tax in September 1985 and was transferred to the spouse on 1 January 1988. Clause 46 as drafted in the Bill provides that the company is not liable to capital gains tax at the time of transfer to the spouse and the spouse is taken to receive the asset at market value and liable for gain on subsequent disposal. That is a circumstance where the spouse could be disadvantaged, I suppose. If it were to operate in accordance with the proposed amendment, the company would not be liable to capital gains tax at the time of transfer to the spouse and the spouse would not be liable to capital gains tax on subsequent disposal. The reaction to that might well be, `Well, that is a good thing; they are better off as a pair'. Senator Stone once said that all other taxpayers are worse off. He said it in a slightly different context, I might add.

talk.start.para: —Slightly different?

—Does the honourable senator remember it? I can tell him exactly what Senator Stone said, I think. It was the averaging in and out of averaging provisions with which the Fraser Government had rorted the primary producers' tax averaging provisions. Senator Stone, as the Treasury Secretary, said publicly, `This is a system under which, heads, farmers gain and, tails, all other taxpayers lose'. He was absolutely right.
—He wouldn't have said that, would he?

—Oh yes; I am sure he will not deny it either. Even if he does deny it, it is not only on the public record, it is published in the proceedings of the Agricultural Outlook Conference of 1981, I think it was. I do not want to be held to the complete accuracy of the date, but the accuracy of, I think, the quotation, or certainly the sense of it, I am willing to be judged by. However, there are conceivable circumstances under which applying clause 46 retrospectively, from 20 September 1985, will disadvantage a spouse-for example, where an asset to be transferred was acquired by a company on or after 29 September 1985 and transferred to the spouse on 1 January. As the clause is drafted in the Bill, the company would pay capital gains tax on the excess of market value over indexed cost base at the time of transfer to the spouse, and the spouse would acquire the asset at market value and be liable to pay capital gains tax on subsequent disposal. The spouse is not liable for capital gains tax on the accrued gain, if there is any, during the period the asset was held by the company.

speech.para: Under the Australian Democrats' proposed amendment, the company would pay no capital gains tax at the time of transfer to the spouse and the spouse would acquire the asset at the indexed cost base and be liable to pay capital gains tax on subsequent disposal. So it can break either for or against the spouse depending on the circumstance of the particular case.

There is also the position of the taxpayers who have an interest in the company or the trust which has transferred the asset to the spouse. I want to stress this point because it shows that the acceptance of this amendment would impose in a retrospective way the capital gains tax liability on some shareholders or equity holders which does not at present exist.

talk.start.para: —Can you explain that?

—I will. Clause 46-that is, in the existing Bill-proposes to reduce the cost base of any interest in the company/trust to account for the loss of the asset; the company/trust is less valuable because the asset has gone. The cost base is used to calculate any gain on disposal for capital gains tax purposes. But retrospectively applying clause 46 from September 1985 could result in an increase in the capital gains tax liability of a taxpayer who disposes of the interest in the company or trust, where that interest of the individual was acquired on or after September 1985, and the asset is transferred from the company or the trust between September 1985 and 28 January 1988-I am not sure whether that should be 1 January, but it does not really affect the point. The cost base otherwise used in the capital gains tax calculation would, in all probability, have to be reduced by the operation of clause 46, thereby increasing capital gains tax liability. This could be particularly unfair if the taxpayer had disposed of the interest before 29 January 1988.

speech.para: That might sound a bit complicated. I think there is a more simple way of expressing the point, which was put to me yesterday. Let us assume there is a family company, which owns a valuable yacht, and there is a marriage break-up. If the spouse took the yacht out of the company, it would devalue the shares in the company because one of the company's assets would have gone. Under the provisions of the Bill, and given the stipulated timing of acquisition and disposal, the values of the remaining shares in the company would be deflated for capital gains tax purposes or for establishing a capital gains tax base. Therefore, any ultimate capital gains tax liability would be assessed from a lower base. If Senator Haines's amendment were to be carried, a consequential or potential capital gains tax liability would be assessed from a higher base, that is, the valuation of the shares before some of the assets of the company escaped from the ownership of the company, thereby effectively imposing retrospectively either a capital gains tax liability, where none would previously have existed, or a higher capital gains tax liability than would otherwise have applied. For all of those reasons the Government will not accept the amendment. I regard it as being important enough to call a division on the question if the Opposition and the Australian Democrats persist in pursuing it.

speech.speaker: Stone Sen J.O.

talker.name: Senator STONE
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: —As you are aware, Mr Chairman, I referred in my earlier remarks on the second reading debate of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) to my intention to speak at the committee stage on the clause which the Committee is now considering. I listened with great attention to the remarks of the Minister for Finance. The first thing I would ask the Minister to do is to table the advice from which he has just been reading.
—I was not reading it all.
—I thought the Minister was reading most of the time.

—I am quite willing to table it on the condition that the honourable senator realises that I have underlined a few things and stuck a few arrows in, which can be ignored. There are also passages that I did not read out and there are things which I said that did not come from it.

—I thank the Minister. I would like to get away from what I might call the convoluted logic of the Australian Taxation Office on these matters. I do not say that with disrespect. The Taxation Office has its job to do, and it does it. I am not here to criticise it for doing so, but it is the job of this Parliament to do rather more than the job of the narrow interpretation of the law as it stands. That is the job of the Taxation Office. What this clause is directed to is a very distressing-I think that is the best word to use-situation which has arisen as a result of defective drafting in the initial drafting of the capital gains tax legislation. As a result, a situation has arisen where transferee spouses in situations where family breakup has occurred, and where the Family Court of Australia has ordered that a transfer of assets should be made-assets in this case held indirectly as distinct from directly by the transferor spouse-have not been covered by the original capital gains tax legislation.

speech.para: The Government to its credit-and I acknowledge that fully-in the light of representations it has received has agreed to amend the law to rectify that initial drafting oversight. So far, both sides of this chamber would agree on the proposed course of action. But what has been pointed out by Senator Haines who has moved an amendment which the Opposition is supporting, and both the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia, is that the Government's amendment simply does not go far enough. It leaves a most unfortunate lacuna in the law. It does not cover the period between 20 September 1985, the date from which the capital gains tax became effective, and 21 January 1988, which was the date on which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced that this rectification of the initial oversight would be made.

What the Opposition has been arguing and what Senator Haines's amendment puts forward-I give her full credit-is that that lacuna should itself be removed and that the situation of unfortunate spouses-I think it would mainly be women but let us be neutral and say spouses--

talk.start.para: —Ninety-eight per cent.

—It would be almost entirely women as Senator Haines, I think accurately, interjects and that is why I hesitated about whether I would use the word `women'. I thought it might not be entirely women, but let us say it is women in 98 per cent of cases. I agree with Senator Haines. They might be affected by this initial gap in the Government's legislation. What should be done about that situation?

speech.para: The Minister has read at some length from a briefing document-I am sure it is a perfectly good briefing document-provided to him by the Australian Taxation Office, as to why in the Government's opinion this should not be done. In doing so he has pointed to the fact that if Senator Haines's amendment were to be carried there would possibly be some people who would actually be adversely affected by that outcome. I must confess, because this is a new thought to me, as I imagine it is also to Senator Haines-I see her nodding-that I have not addressed my mind to the very hard cases because, after all, these are all hard cases covered by the points made by the Minister. But I am prepared to accept, for the sake of the debate, that there are such exceedingly rare but nevertheless very hard cases. But the Minister is seeking to persuade the chamber that because these exceedingly hard cases exist we should not adopt Senator Haines's amendment, which is entirely supported by the coalition parties, because if we did so we would in fact disadvantage a few cases. The point of the amendment, of course, is to advantage the majority of hard cases.

I suggest we should keep our eyes on the main game, to use a phrase much beloved by the Treasurer. The main game so far as this clause is concerned involves unfortunate spouses, mainly women, who have been severely disadvantaged by the Government's defective drafting of the initial capital gains tax legislation. The purpose of the amendment is to rectify that disadvantage in the case of the majority of such disadvantaged people. The Minister has said to us that, if we carry that amendment, while it will certainly rectify the situation for those unfortunate spouses, mainly women, it will have-and I accept the Minister's technical advice-the effect of disadvantaging a few particularly hard cases.

The Minister says that the Government will oppose this amendment, and it will be to its shame if it does. I say to the Government, `Do not come in here and tell us that we should not support this amendment because a few people will be disadvantaged if we do'. Why does not the Government come into this chamber with its own amendment, better perhaps, I hope Senator Haines will not mind my saying, and technically more perfect than the one she has put forward, which will not only achieve the objective we want to achieve, but, in doing so, not produce a deleterious consequence, the unintended consequence-again, a phrase much beloved by the Prime Minister of this country-to which the Minister has just pointed?

If the Government persists in its decision to oppose this amendment, not only will it do great damage to the cause of a number of disadvantaged people-the Minister for Finance having left the chamber, I see that the Minister at the table is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Reynolds), who above all people in this chamber ought to be sympathetic to the cause being pursued by this side of the chamber-but also it will rebound most unfavourably on the Government in terms of the public perception of where the Government stands on this matter. I should like to hear further on this matter from the Minister who is now at the table.

speech.speaker: Haines Sen J.

talk.start.para: —I congratulate whichever Treasury officer or Australian Taxation Office guru it was who came up with the rather tortuous, complicated example showing who was likely to be disadvantaged should this amendment be passed. I am merely a humble politician; I do not have access to all the information that tax officers do, and so, although I did not quite come to terms with what I was being told, I accept that there may be, as Senator Stone said, one or two rather extraordinary cases in which some disadvantage will accrue. However, again as he said, if that is the case and the Government has realised this, it is surely up to the Government to come into this place and give us the correcting mechanism. We can be absolutely sure, however, notwithstanding fanciful examples which, as I said, I accept to be correct, that if clause 46 is enacted in its current form it will be clearly discriminatory.

speech.para: At the moment we are looking at three groups of people. Under clause 46, if it is passed in its present form, two groups will be winners and a group which is currently losing will continue to lose. There are the people whose marriages broke down prior to 20 September 1985. They do not face the problem of capital gains tax (CGT) being paid when the property transferred from one spouse to another spouse is disposed of, because no capital gains tax applied prior to that date. Then there are the people whose marriages are breaking down and who have court orders distributing property post-28 January 1988. In the event of the resale of such property because the person receiving it needs cash rather than simply an asset, those people will not be disadvantaged because the law covers them as clause 46 stands.

The people who are going to be affected are the people whose marriages broke down or, more accurately, whose divorce proceedings were concluded, between 20 September 1985 and 28 January 1988, because in the event of property owned by one spouse that was owned by that spouse prior to September 1985, when CGT was introduced, being transferred to the other spouse and then disposed of, the recipient spouse is going to be facing capital gains tax.

So we have three groups of families whose marriages have broken down, only one of which will be subject to CGT. That is clearly discriminatory. I am not at all sure that the Government did this intentionally. I cannot believe that it would. I do not believe that there are hundreds of thousands of families so affected, but there are some, and they deserve to be treated as equitably as people whose marriages broke up both before and after theirs. As I said a moment ago, in concert with Senator Stone I would say to the Government: if clarifying clause 46 to end the discrimination which is patently there is going to cause an even smaller group of people to be disadvantaged, the onus is on the Government to come into this chamber and say how that can be fixed up. Frankly, I would be very surprised if more than two Western Australian multimillionaires were likely to be picked up under clause 46 as amended by the Australian Democrats amendment, but one must have sympathy, if not for the multimillionaires, at least for the spouses left with a broken marriage. If there are such people, and if the Tax Office knows of cases in which people will be disadvantaged by this amendment, the Government should amend the amendment, produce its own additional amendment. The matters I have outlined should not be used as an excuse to oppose this amendment, which ends a clear discrimination against a group of people who were unfortunate enough to be divorced and to have their property settlements arranged between 20 September 1985 and 28 January 1988.

speech.speaker: Panizza Sen J.H.

talk.start.para: —I think I can remember what the Minister for Finance read from the notes that he had, even though it was a full 10 minutes ago.
—Memory training!

—This is a serious matter. The Minister gave some examples to show that, if a marriage breakdown occurred between 20 September 1985 and 28 January 1988-for instance, in 1987-property forming part of the equity and bought after 20 September 1985, when the capital gains tax came in, which was gained by a trust between those dates would be liable for capital gains tax when it was sold. I think he gave the example that it was taxable in the hands of the equity, with the trust. If that is the case and if that is what the Minister is worried about then surely, as I told Senator Haines earlier, someone from the Australian Democrats or the Government can come up with a different amendment even if it means adjourning this debate until tomorrow until someone can work it out. Surely they can come up with an amendment to cover the marriages that broke down between capital gains day and 28 January 1988 and make sure that the property was held before the capital gains day of 1985. If that is what the Minister for Finance is worried about-and I can see his point that there can be some rorts made out of it when a marriage broke down in 1987-surely it is not beyond the ability of some draftsman to come up with the right amendment to cover those whose marriages broke down after capital gains day and whose property was owned in that trust before capital gains day. I repeat that this debate should be adjourned until someone comes up with the right amendment.

speech.para: I move to the question of tax rorts. I have seen tax rorts used and they have been reported in the papers. But surely no-one is going to break up a marriage for a tax rort. I cannot see any rationale in that.

talk.start.para: —People break up marriages for the strangest of reasons.

—Yes, but I put on record-as it is not a broadcast tonight-that I would rather keep my wife than go into a tax rort. It is a good choice. I had better wipe that out of Hansard. I am dinkum about this situation because surely no-one on this earth will use a contrived marriage breakdown. I know it is quite easy to have a matter brought in front of a divorce court these days because one does not even have to appear. One can virtually make one's own arrangements. But surely a court has to make the final dissolution of a marriage and a tax rort is not considered. I appeal to the Government to look at it again. It has been pointed out by Senator Stone, Senator Haines and Senator Messner that there will be a lot of people disadvantaged in this situation who should not have been disadvantaged.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —In his own pithy way Senator Panizza has put his finger on the issue here. This matter is about people being caught in a circumstance which is apparently now being well and truly used against them in this tax legislation. They are in circumstances over which they have no control. On the other hand, the Government does have control and does have the power to amend the legislation so as to release these people from the situation into which they have fallen. The key point is that we have people who have come to an agreement in the financial settlement of their affairs in some belief-mistaken as it may have been-that the roll-over provisions of the capital gains tax legislation applied to all assets whether they are directly or indirectly held at the time of the distribution when the marriage was dissolved. That is the critical point. That is what the Government ought to be acknowledging here tonight. It fails to do that.

speech.para: The Government has come up with, to be fair, a very detailed and comprehensive argument that defies immediate analysis on the spot in this kind of situation. I believe that it does require time to contemplate what has been made available by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). Therefore, I suggest that we report progress on the Bill and seek leave to sit again. Accordingly, I move:
That progress be reported.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Progress reported.

proctext.para: Consideration resumed from 2 November.

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: Page 3, subclause 3 (1), definition of ``new borrowing'', lines 4 to 6, leave out the definition, insert the following definitions:
`` `Loan Council' means the Australian Loan Council constituted under the Financial Agreement referred to in the Financial Agreement Validation Act 1929;
`new borrowing' means an amount of a borrowing that is received in the grant year but does not include an amount of:
(a) a borrowing from the Commonwealth;
(b) a borrowing for the purposes of refinancing debt outstanding on 30 June 1988; or

(c) a borrowing that would not have been affected by a resolution relating to global borrowing limits proposed at the meeting of the Loan Council on 12 May 1988 and supported by the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania;''.

Earlier in the debate on the committee stage of the States Grants (General Revenue) Bill 1988 Opposition senators argued that the Bill should be amended to clarify the powers of the Treasurer under clause 7 of the Bill. Clause 7 of the Bill is intended to make it a condition of the payment of general revenue grants for the States that all States should adhere to the global borrowing limits agreed to at the May Loan Council meeting by all States except Queensland. The Treasurer may reduce grants to any State exceeding those limits. The Government believes that the clause as drafted fulfils that intention and will not allow the Treasurer to reduce grants to a State unless it exceeded its global borrowing limits in respect of those types of borrowings covered by the Loan Council arrangement. As I have already indicated to the Senate, the Government has given its assurance to the States that the Bill would be interpreted in that way. However, I am now prepared to propose an amendment which I believe would put the matter beyond doubt.

The amendment expands on the definition of new borrowings given in clause 3 of the Bill to indicate that the new borrowings which are the subject of clause 7 firstly exclude any borrowings from the Commonwealth and secondly include only borrowings that were the subject of the global approach resolution moved at the May Loan Council meeting and agreed to by all States except Queensland other than borrowings for refinancing purposes. This would ensure that new borrowings exclude borrowings by government-owned financial institutions except when those institutions undertake borrowings for the purpose of on-lending to bodies subject to the global borrowing limits.

speech.speaker: Watson Sen J.O.W.

talk.start.para: —I would like to thank the Minister for Finance for coming up with those amendments.
