debate.title:
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (TAX FILE NUMBERS) BILL 1988
PRIVACY BILL 1988

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —The Senate now has before it the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax Files Numbers) Bill 1988, to which the Opposition will not be raising objection. In fact we will not oppose it. The history of this piece of legislation is long but it bears consideration by the Parliament as we have reached this stage here tonight. We all know the attempts by the Labor Government back in 1985 at the time of the so-called RATS proposals, the reform of the Australian taxation system, when it was announced that there would be introduced an Australian identification system, known as the Australia card, which would have imposed enormous burdens on the Australian people. This national identifier would have had to be used in just about every financial transaction throughout Australia. It would have been required to be produced in all kinds of ordinary everyday situations in which Australians find themselves. In other words, it would have become very akin to a national passport. We know that that Bill was defeated twice in the Senate, having been sent here by the House of Representatives. The Government thereby caused a double dissolution election to occur last year. Finally, the Bill was reintroduced by the Government but before it was put to the vote in the Senate again it was withdrawn by the Government because of technical failures in the legislation.

speech.para: The Bill we now have before us relates to a tax file numbering system. This is an entirely different approach which the Government has outlined. It is different because it does not require people to carry with them any kind of card that indicates their tax file number (TFN) whenever they are carrying on their ordinary everyday affairs. It does not require them to produce a tax file number in respect of ordinary bank transactions, for instance; it does not require them to produce it in respect of buying and selling any kind of property. The tax file number system, as envisaged by this legislation-and the history of how this legislation came to be is a story in itself which I shall come to in a moment-is in no way a copy of the Australia card.

There was a time, when the Government was first proposing this legislation six or eight months ago, when one could think that it was to be that kind of `son of ID card' legislation. We could see that the Government had in mind achieving the same end that it failed to do with the ID card legislation by the substitution of that with this tax file numbering system. For instance, the Government proposed that if a person did not produce a tax file number to a bank when withdrawing money or transacting on the account, the bank account would be frozen, that people would lose access to their own funds. That kind of nonsense had to be dealt with and it fell very early in the race as a result of discussions between Senator Stone, Mr Peacock and Mr Tuckey, on behalf of the Opposition, and the Commissioner of Taxation in about June this year. The Government was prepared to look at alternatives, and that point was established at that stage. Quite clearly, the TFN system, which was seen at that point to be a copy of the ID card, was rapidly adopting another face.

When the Government first announced that it would proceed with a tax file numbering system in substitution of the ID card system, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, laid down three conditions which had to be met for the tax file numbering legislation to gain the support of the Liberal and National parties. Those three points were: firstly, the Government would need to demonstrate that the tax file numbering system would effectively eliminate tax fraud and welfare cheating; secondly, the new system would be cost-effective-quite clearly, the ID card system was not cost effective; we all remember that it was going to cost about $2,000m to set it up-and, thirdly, the tax file numbering system did not unreasonably intrude upon personal privacy and individual civil liberties. Those were the three conditions laid down by the Leader of the Opposition then and they have been the guiding principles by which we in the Opposition have determined our attitude on this legislation.

Looking at the first guideline, on effectively eliminating tax fraud, we can see that the Government has an argument for instituting a system whereby a number can be traced, within the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) and through other arms of government, in order to prevent welfare cheating and tax fraud. We believe that that could and would be used within those restricted and confined circumstances to ensure that people are not able to rip off the system.

talk.start.para: —It will be used on tertiary students as well. There is another Bill under which it is to be used on tertiary students.

—Let us deal with one thing at a time. The audit practice adopted within the ATO is becoming more and more a part of the ATO's effort to stamp out tax evasion, as distinct from tax avoidance, and the numbering system appears, on all the evidence that has been produced to Estimates committees and in other forums, such as the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, to be a reasonably effective way of ensuring that the ATO has a far more effective audit system. That point came out particularly in the Estimates committee debates in recent times.

speech.para: On the question of cost-effectiveness, obviously the institution of this system will cost a great deal less than the $2,000m monster identified with the Australia Card. It has nothing in common with the Australia Card in terms of its widespread nature. At the time the Government was talking about introducing such legislation there was considerable concern, and there still is, among people about individual civil liberties. Obviously, the Government had headed down the wrong track when it announced that it intended to introduce a tax file numbering Bill without the accompanying privacy legislation. In other words, it intended to set up the TFN system and then at some future time, when it had had time to think about it, it would bring in a privacy Bill. Quite clearly, that had to be thrown out as being an attempt to sell the people of Australia a pig in a poke. The Australian people would not buy that kind of chicanery from the Hawke Government given its present standing. Consequently, we would have moved to oppose the legislation had not the Government acceded to many of the conditions that we brought to bear in the course of discussions with it on the format of the proposed privacy legislation.

Mr Neil Brown, the shadow Attorney-General, undertook long negotiations with the Government on the privacy legislation to ensure that the new tax file numbering system would be quarantined to those very specific purposes for which this legislation now shows itself to be designated. It is designed to attack tax and welfare fraud and is not to be used or to become in any way, possibly, a kind of internal passport. That privacy legislation will be discussed in this place by my colleague Senator Hill. It is separate legislation but will be debated cognately with the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill. Suffice it to say that what the Opposition was able to do in achieving significant changes in the privacy legislation has assured the Australian people that the tax file numbering system will not affect their civil liberties, that it will be limited and quarantined to a narrow range of circumstances and that, as a result, it will not become the kind of monster that the ID card was designed to be.

It is interesting to note that the proposed system differs significantly from that which the majority of members of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card recommended about 18 months or two years ago. The tax file numbering system recommended by those members of the Parliament at that time was designed to be a replacement for the ID card-a simpler, less costly version of the ID card, if you like. It was not designed along the lines of the proposed tax file numbering system, which has a very different approach and a purpose totally different and much more limited. For that reason we cannot even compare the outcome of the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card with what is before us. They are two different things and in no way can we seek to argue from the point of view adopted by those four or five members of that Committee who recommended the acceptance of a tax file numbering system in place of the ID card.

However, there are one or two dangers that need to be watched in the course of this legislation being implemented. We all know that section 16 of the income tax law, which is a very important section, defines the duties of officers of the Taxation Office and provides for the distribution of information from the Tax Office to other government departments, and vice versa, including the Department of Social Security, the Department of Employment, Education and Training and, I think, the Department of Community Services and Health. Quite clearly, for means testing purposes and other purposes associated with the detection of fraud, those organisations will have and should have access to that kind of information from the Taxation Office. The fear I express tonight is that once that information is provided by the Tax Office to those outside organisations, the secrecy systems of those organisations may well be breached in the way that information originating with the Tax Office flows out to other people in the community. In other words, there may not be the same concern on the part of departments outside the Tax Office as there is within the Tax Office over matters of secrecy and civil liberties. I think the privacy legislation extends significantly to cover those situations, and I hope that all people can guarantee that that will be so. It just seems to me that we must be extraordinarily vigilant about that aspect in case there is any leak of information from those sources.

A similar circumstance may apply in relation to the private sector, where information comes into the hands of private sector organisations such as banks and other financial institutions. They must comply with the present legislation. The privacy provisions must extend adequately to ensure that there can be no leaks from those organisations. If the law fails to be properly applied or it is not enforced properly, dangers may arise. Again, I emphasise that we must be vigilant in that area to ensure that those circumstances do not occur and that we do not end up having funnels for people's private and personal information to be channelled out of the Taxation Office into other areas of the community. We in the Liberal and National parties are satisfied that the privacy legislation covers these situations adequately. As a result, we are prepared to give support to the legislation. That deals with the three main factors which the Leader of the Opposition announced last November we would be taking into account in assessing whether or not we would give support to the legislation.

In debating the legislation it is perhaps necessary to consider some of the alternatives that might be available to the Australian Taxation Office and the Government in seeking to stamp out welfare and tax fraud. Perhaps other measures could be put in place, rather than relying on what may be only a partially effective system using the tax file number. The alternatives that could possibly be adopted include such things as a mandatory withholding tax on all capital sourced income. There would be some technical difficulties in relation to dividends which are fully franked and other matters like that, but it is not necessary to consider those details here. The general point is that such a tax could be applied and that, of course, is the system that applies in some other countries of the world, particularly Britain. Perhaps ultimately that would be the most effective system. However, I do not believe that it is feasible in this country, given its widespread geographical nature and the difficulties of instituting such a system.

Another alternative would be simply to build up the computer capacity of the Taxation Office so as to ensure that there was better matching of individual transactions as they are recorded in the books of individual financial institutions with those amounts that are declared as income in the hands of various taxpayers. But a very large scale operation would need to be instituted in order to achieve that. There is also the question of whether it could be effective. Some countries have very good matching systems. The British system is a typical example. But those systems are not necessarily foolproof or cost effective.

Perhaps another solution to this problem would be simply to limit the application of the tax file number to only internal activities within the Australian Tax Office, and not to apply it more generally to other agencies of government. That again has its limitations, quite obviously, because it would fail on one of the criteria we laid down; that is, seeking to control welfare fraud. Obviously that is no easy answer either. Another possibility emerged, I think, from the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I refer to the minority report of the Australian Democrats. They envisaged some kind of paper system whereby reports of individual transactions in quadruplicate form would be forwarded by the financial institutions to the Australian Taxation Office. In that way there would be a capacity for the Taxation Office to match directly those individual transactions with the affairs of the taxpayer. Quite apart from the fact that this seems to miss the point of the tax file number, I do not believe such a system could be managed. It would result in literally mountains of paper being transferred from one office to another and coping with such a proposal would require a massive effort on the part not only of government but also of the private sector. I do not believe that one stands up.

There does not seem to be readily available the kind of practical alternative that could be easily implemented in order to attack capital sourced taxation fraud and also, of course, employment fraud where there are multiple registrations of the same person under different names. The tax file numbering system offers the advantage of ensuring that, with proper identification in the first place, people can be traced in the event of their defrauding the taxation system.

The Bill proposes that there be no requirement on the part of any individual to quote his tax file number in any circumstance; nor is there a requirement for any financial institution to request or require any individual to quote his number. In other words, in relation to capital sourced and employment areas, there is no compulsion on individuals to disclose their numbers. That is, of course, totally different from the approach that was adopted with the Australia Card legislation, under which this was mandatory.

There is, however, the requirement for financial institutions and employers who are paying wages or capital sourced income to taxpayers, in the event that the tax file number is not quoted, to apply a withholding tax at the maximum marginal rate of taxation for individuals. We support that for two reasons: firstly, the withholding tax is ultimately the only really safe anti-fraud device, and, consequently, this answers the first point in the statement of the Leader of the Opposition last year; that the system should be shown to be effective. Secondly, people have the choice of not paying tax at the maximum marginal rate by simply quoting their tax file number if they so wish. However, in the event of their not wishing to disclose their number, for various privacy reasons or whatever, a withholding tax will apply.

Some people might argue that somehow there is a penalty in tax being deducted at the maximum marginal rate, but I think we have to remember that it is not so much a question of the tax deducted going into a black hole and never being seen again. Rather, it is, if you like, a prepayment of tax because a taxpayer's liability will be ultimately decided when he submits his taxation return. He will then receive credit for the withholding tax that has already been taken out in respect of either employment earnings or capital sourced earnings. That kind of concession, if it is regarded as such, takes the sting out of the situation. It is simply a matter of a timing difference, of tax being paid in advance rather than being applied per se in circumstances over which taxpayers ultimately have no control. In fact, they will be able to have control by submitting their income tax returns. They will then receive a credit for whatever tax has been paid.

I point out-and this is the most important point of all as far as the Liberal and National parties are concerned-that we have negotiated long and hard with the Government over this legislation to attain success with the three objectives that have been laid down. We had a good look at all the alternatives to the tax file numbering system. We negotiated with the Government and obtained its agreement for a voluntary system and for all compulsion to be removed from the legislation. Sure, the sanction ultimately lies with the application of the withholding tax but, ultimately, the only alternative is the kind of system that we are seeing applied here in this legislation. That is why we have given our support to the Government. We put the Government on notice that we will be watching vigilantly for any breaches of privacy and for any failures in the systems that are being written to the privacy legislation. We will be examining very closely any representations from people who feel aggrieved by the Government's system. I hope that the privacy legislation, which will be dealt with later in the debate by my colleague Senator Hill, adequately covers the circumstances in which people can find redress for any complaints they may have.

Finally, I point out that this is the most effective system to stop tax evasion and welfare fraud that we have yet seen put forward. It is a shame that the Government did not adopt a far more cooperative approach in relation to a system such as this, quite distinct from the shameful identification card system that it announced off the top of its head back in 1985 after the tax summit. This kind of system could well have engendered a great deal of different feeling in the community from that which the identity card created. We have to note that the new system will not represent an internal passport in Australia. Function creep, if you like, will be significantly protected by the privacy legislation. That privacy legislation has been put in place because of pressure from the Liberal and National parties and the negotiations that have been undertaken with the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown). The system will be entirely voluntary-again, an initiative of the Liberal and National parties. People can choose either to disclose their numbers or not. There is no penalty-no offence is created-as a result of the number not being disclosed. A person can make a decision whether to pay tax now through the withholding tax system or to pay it later by disclosing his tax file number. In that way there is no intrusion, no interference with people's rights. People are left in a circumstance they were in before, except, of course, for the timing of the situation.

Overall, we believe that this system will improve the operation of the Australian Taxation Office. We believe that it will improve the effectiveness of the Tax Office's audit system which it is moving to very rapidly. We believe it will counter tax evasion and welfare fraud. For those reasons we support the legislation. As I indicated earlier, we will look very vigilantly for any breaches of the undertakings given by the Government.

speech.speaker: Giles Sen P.J.

talk.start.para: —It is with great pleasure that we on the Government side note the generally constructive approach that has been taken by Senator Messner and, presumably, his colleagues, towards the introduction of a tax file number which, in its present form, apparently meets with the approval of the Opposition and overcomes its previous objections to at least some aspects of the use of this identifier. It has never been claimed that the tax file number is a fool proof system or that it would rake in every cent of avoided tax. As we know, the tax file number was the preferred option of members of the Opposition who served not so long ago on the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card.
—No, it was not; entirely different.

—Despite Senator Messner's claim to the contrary, I think there is enough similarity between this proposition and what was being advocated in general terms at that stage as a tax file number for me to make that claim. In any case, I believe that it is an opinion which is shared by the vast majority of Australian taxpayers, who have had a tax file number for years and who are not aware of any great disadvantages as a result. Some of us have actually had a tax file number for decades; and fewer still possibly for generations. The extension of use of the tax file number seems to me to be a commonsense measure. I believe it will even more cut down the capacity of individuals to avoid their obligations in respect of the income tax they should be paying.

speech.para: Of course, this is one of many of the measures that have been taken by this Government. I remind the Senate that the Cash Transaction Reports Act took effect from 1 July. As a result of that legislation, it is now obligatory for banks and other financial institutions to report cash transactions of amounts over $10,000. There is an obligation also to report large amounts of money leaving or entering the country. Perhaps most significant of all, it is now illegal to open or operate an account in anybody's name but one's own. An indication of the extent to which that piece of legislation was needed is the anecdotal evidence of up to 10 per cent of accounts being closed in a great hurry towards the end of the last financial year. A few people in the community still have a philosophical objection towards any numbering system, but that seems to me to ignore the facts of life. We have been using numbers as identifiers for a very long time because of their utility value.

In the course of the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs into the feasibility of a national identification scheme-the tax file number-we had it put to us that it was somehow dehumanising to identify people by substituting numbers for names. Of course, this proposal does not substitute numbers for names; we keep our names, with all their lack of utility. It was interesting that some of the people who put these positions most forcefully were those with names that would be replicated quite a number of times, even in a country such as Australia with its small population. There are probably at least a dozen Pat Gileses in Australia. I have met about half a dozen of them. I am very happy to have the taxation, social security and whatever other records are actually mine pertain to me-those which are legitimately mine. I believe this is a commonsense approach taken by the majority of Australians, who have nothing whatsoever to fear from being clearly identified for who they are, for how much they earn, and for how much they are obliged to pay in income tax.

In the course of the Committee's discussion about identification we received some evidence in relation to the regularisation of our births, deaths and marriages records. Some of the criticism I have seen of the report of the Committee goes to the fact that we were not making any firm recommendations about ways in which those registers might be upgraded and standardised across the nation. It is a particular wish of mine to have a far more reliable system whereby births, deaths and marriages can be recorded much more accurately than they are at present and access for individuals with legitimate reasons for access made a great deal easier.

Along the way we have noted with great interest the concerns expressed that a tax file number should not be used for purposes other than those related to the collection of taxation. As we said in the last recommendation of the Standing Committee, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988, if enacted, should be strictly limited in its terms so that it applies only for taxation purposes and that those purposes be so framed as to prevent a progressive extension of the ambit of the Bill. As I understand it, the Government is perfectly happy to accede to that recommendation, with the clear understanding that other purposes for which it is considered completely legitimate to use the tax file number in its proposed form would be very closely related to income and to ways in which that income is legitimately a concern of the Government, not only for income tax but also to assist with the assessment of incomes for means testing Austudy payments to assist students in secondary and post-secondary education, and to assist in the implementation of our child support levy.

This latter levy is one that can work a great deal more effectively in conjunction with a tax file number. Once again, speaking personally, ever since we started to discuss the possibility of introducing a universal tax file number-I should not use that word `universal' because it is not obligatory-it has been my sincere hope that such a number would be introduced in order to make it a great deal more efficient within the taxation system to collect maintenance from non-custodial parents in a scheme whereby we pass on that maintenance to custodial parents. Obviously, where the tax file number is as widely used as we could possibly anticipate, we would be in a far better position to assist custodial parents to track down the errant non-custodial parent. We would also be in a position to know exactly how much income was available for distribution to the non-custodial parent, to collect it, and to ensure that the welfare of the children involved was being attended to in the best possible way we could manage within that system.

There has been concern expressed too about the secrecy of the number and its integrity as far as human and technological factors are concerned. We have taken every possible precaution in this legislation to ensure that the much vaunted and highly regarded secrecy of the Australian Taxation Office is maintained. There are very heavy penalties for disclosure by anybody who has access to the tax file number in the course of his or her employment in the Taxation Office or any other government instrumentality. Those penalties will also apply to people who have access to the tax file numbers as a result of their employment in banks and other financial institutions.

Of course, there is no way that we can ensure with 100 per cent certainty that nobody will ever breach these laws, but if people do break the law they are up for heavy penalties and they will be taking a very great risk with their reputations. This is one of the points that should be made in relation to all the measures we are taking for the much more effective collection of taxation. We cannot be certain that laws will never be breached, but we can be certain that we are making that window of opportunity smaller as we hedge these measures around with very heavy penalties.

Reservations were expressed by both Opposition and Government members about the amount of money that would be collected as a result of introducing a tax file number. We found that the Australian Taxation Office could not be precise; did not have particularly large samples from which to work and seemed to be making a few assumptions that could be questioned. We discussed with the Taxation Office other ways of making its records more accurate, more useful, without using numbers. The point was made very clearly that computer-based name and address matching was very difficult for a whole range of reasons, one of the most important being, as I have mentioned, that names are not so different as to be easily picked up. In the same families the same initials keep cropping up time and time again. People are not always identified by their full given names. For companies, and particularly partnerships and trusts, it is considered too difficult and no attempts have been made to devise a computer-based matching program. Thus in excess of one million business taxpayers who derive interest income are excluded from the interest reporting and matching element of the income matching program, with very large implications in dollar terms.

It was also estimated that at least 400,000 to 500,000 taxable persons failed to report group certificates and it was not practicable to include the bulk of unreported group certificates in the income matching program for several reasons, one of them being that in many cases there would be no tax payable-there might even be a rebate waiting for a whole lot of those people who failed to report their group certificate-but in many cases, as we are coming to realise more clearly, a high proportion of those group certificates would be in false names. In addition, a high level of income reports-that is, over four million in the 1986 program run in November 1987-captured by the income matching program could not be uniquely matched and require labour intensive follow up action.

Taking into account this range of limitations for any sort of computer based matching, or the manual matching and the enormous cost and labour intensiveness of that type of matching, the tax file number was seen to be not only a great deal more effective, but also more cost effective than the estimate that was given to us of 1 : 8.07. Despite the fact that we were not convinced of the accuracy of the Australian Tax Office's calculations, they must be weighed up against the Tax Office's past record of significantly underestimating the revenue yield of base broadening measures such as that now proposed.

I have a table illustrating the original estimate of the revenue yield for the 1985 base broadening measures announced by the Government and the actual outcome. In every case the revenue yield has been substantially greater than first estimated. It could be estimated that, if anything, the Tax Office's calculation of the costs of implementing the upgraded tax file number is likely to have been overstated for two reasons. Firstly, as a consequence of the ATO's tax modernisation project it is expected that major productivity improvements will be possible when new systems on new equipment become operational in the early 1990s, and this particularly applies to the income matching activity which is at the heart of the tax file number legislation. The other reason is that since the Cabinet decision to proceed with the tax file number legislation, the scope of the proposals has been narrowed by decisions varying the tax file number quotation requirements in respect of pensioners.

One result of these decisions will be to reduce our previous cost estimates, but with minimal impact on the revenue estimates. We believe that the upgrading of the tax file number will produce a cost benefit ratio of 1 : 8 at least in its first 10 years; that is, revenue over 10 years to 1998 are $2.258 billion, whereas costs over 10 years to 1998 are $280m. Moreover, when the system is fully operational from 1994 it is likely to return a cost-benefit ration of 1 : 13, annual revenues of $337m versus annual costs of $25m, bearing in mind that we expect the system to become more efficient all the time. All evidence and past experience suggests that the actual results achieved will be significantly better than this.

I have a copy of what we calculate to be the results of the estimates of the base broadening measures introduced by the Government which shows quite clearly that the actual result has considerably outweighed what was originally estimated. I seek leave to have that document incorporated in Hansard.

talk.start.para: —In summary, this is another reform in a long list of reforms by the Hawke Government, which has made our taxation system a great deal more efficient. We inherited a demoralised Taxation Office 5 1/2 years ago. It was desperately short of staff, reeling from years of uncorrected avoidance and evasion and was not seen to be a viable institution except in a very minimal way. In the intervening years we have been able to make an enormous improvement in the morale of the Tax Office. We have increased the staff by about 40 per cent. As I pointed out in the course of my speech, computerisation has greatly increased the effectiveness of the Tax Office.

speech.para: I believe that the community perception of the Tax Office has changed quite remarkably in that time. I am not saying that everybody in the community is absolutely delighted to pay income tax, but what I do believe is that people on lower and middle incomes feel a great deal better about paying tax when they can be assured that it is not quite so easy for other individuals to avoid their taxation obligations, whether those individuals are people that low and middle income people can identify with easily, or whether they are wealthy or have been able in the past to disguise their incomes as a result of companies or trusts or using false bank accounts or false names. We are gradually reducing the ways in which those people with a great deal of ingenuity have been able over the years to avoid their obligations. The vast majority of Australians approve very strongly of the fact that we have been able to do this, and we have their support.

As I said before, it is extremely gratifying to know that members of the Opposition have taken a position which is essentially in line with what we plan to do. We have been able to agree to some amendments that satisfy some of their concerns. The privacy legislation, which will certainly also be discussed in the course of this debate, has been improved, I believe considerably, on what was proposed at the time of the ill-fated Australia Card legislation. What we are offering to the Australian public, what we believe has been our responsibility to develop in response to years of expectation from the public, is a taxation system which has a great deal more integrity and a great deal more respect from the community as a whole.

We greatly welcome this bipartisan approach for these means of eliminating tax fraud and welfare cheating. Provided that they are cost-effective and allow for protection of personal privacy and civil liberties, the Government believes that it is entitled to the Opposition's support for the tax file number legislation currently before the House, and we welcome that support.

talk.start.para: —I am quite disturbed at a media report earlier this week that the Premier of Queensland, Mr Ahern, has promised a Hong Kong-style commission with wide-ranging investigative powers to probe all aspects of corruption in Queensland after the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct concludes. I have no objection to moves to rid Queensland of corruption, not only in the police and justice areas as currently are being thoroughly investigated by the Fitzgerald inquiry, but also at the administrative level in the Queensland Government. Moves to clean up what has become a rotten administration in the State that I represent are well overdue. What I do object to are the suggested wide-ranging powers that could be handed to any investigative body. Queensland is not exactly regarded as a place where civil liberties are safeguarded and promoted. Any further assault on civil liberties in that State must be resisted.

speech.para: The suggestion has been made that new powers to fight corruption will include search and seizure, power to probe personal finances and bank accounts, detention without charge for up to 48 hours and compulsory answering of questions. Instant dismissal of employees without reason has also been suggested. If society is to counter corruption, there must be significant powers to carry out the task. But we must have curbs to ensure that any expanded powers are not abused. Unless there are safeguards, there will be excesses and abuses. I shall turn to that matter later. If some officers-police officers or other government officers-are to be allowed to search and seize and are given a power to probe personal finances and bank accounts, they cannot be allowed to do so of their own volition. They must be compelled to convince responsible persons that such search, seizure and probe of finances is essential. Who should such responsible people be? To my mind they should come from the judiciary-magistrates or judges. And even there, safeguards must exist. It would probably be unreasonable to expect the judiciary to provide a public report of the details of permission given over a particular period, for example, a year. But I do not consider it unreasonable for elected leaders, including the Leader of the Opposition to sight such a report.

I have heard far too many assertions by young people in Queensland that the power of search and seizure under drug laws is being abused by some police officers. It is not difficult to imagine how such abuse could occur. All a police officer has to claim is that his or her investigation relates to drugs, and it follows that powers to search, and perhaps seize, virtually have no bounds. Detention for 48 hours without charge should be unacceptable in Australia. It is far too open to abuse. If citizens are to be deprived of their liberty, they should be aware of the reasons for their incarceration and, if necessary, obtain legal assistance. Any suggestion that such a provision be introduced in this country, albeit in one State only, should be resisted with vigour. The suggestion that it should be possible for employees to be dismissed without reason is also totally unacceptable. In the interest of justice, any person who loses his or her job should know the reason for the loss of the job.

I earlier mentioned the possibility of excesses and abuses occurring if additional powers were provided to police or other government officers without adequate safeguards. It is my opinion that the vast majority of police officers in the State that I represent are hardworking, dedicated officers who know how far to go with the powers at their disposal. But there are some who, in the heat of the moment or quite deliberately, go beyond the bounds of their powers. I worked in a police department-as a public servant-for only a few years and in most of that time I worked at a desk. Even so, I saw excessive use of power, or perhaps it would be better to say I saw behaviour which went beyond what was acceptable. I saw personal property deliberately damaged; I saw civilians being assaulted without any provocation. I, too, was assaulted by a police officer after I left that department and was a senator. When I complained, one of the knights in shining armour, a certain high ranking officer named Vern McDonald, refused to take action on my complaint. By chance, a photographic record was available of the incident, but it made no difference. I mention these few excesses to illustrate that there must be safeguards to protect ordinary citizens. The introduction of powers such as the ones I mentioned would be a disturbing development. Let us, by all means, fight against corruption at all levels, but in doing so let us have in mind the rights of those whom we intend to protect from that very corruption.

speech.speaker: Schacht Sen C.C.

talk.start.para: —I take this opportunity in the adjournment debate to make some brief remarks about a recent visit I made to Eritrea, where a civil war has been fought for the last 26 years. I am, as I understand it, the first Australian parliamentarian to go into what is called the liberated areas of Eritrea which are under the control of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front (EPLF). A couple of members of parliament from other countries visited in the early 1980s, but I am the first Australian member of parliament and I think I am the first parliamentarian from a governing party to visit.

speech.para: I made the visit privately and unofficially. I do not wish to go into the details of the difficulty of travelling into Eritrea, over rough roads, for a couple of days. But I would like to mention that also travelling to Eritrea at that time was a film crew from the Channel 10 network current affairs program, Page One, and that crew worked under very difficult circumstances to record what was happening in Eritrea. I believe its efforts will be seen on Channel 10's Page One this Thursday evening at 8.30 p.m. It is certainly a program I look forward to watching.

I have been a patron of the Eritrean Relief Association for some months and have been interested in the issue for a number of years. The Australian Labor Party, at the last two national conferences, carried resolutions in support of an act of self-determination for the Eritrean people. The dispute started in the 1950s, when the Emperor Haile Selassie, who was then the ruler of Ethiopia, illegally incorporated Eritrea into Ethiopia contrary to a United Nations mandate. That has been the centre of the dispute. The Eritrean people have ever since been fighting for their independence. They wish to have a political settlement but the Ethiopians refuse to negotiate, so for 26 years this forgotten war has been going on.

The war is not just an independence movement. If it were, it could possibly be more easily dismissed. What I was impressed with in my visit to Eritrea of some 10 days is that it is much more than a separatist movement. The Eritrean revolution is about changing existing society. A number of people described it to me as being about the transformation of mental attitudes and the way people think. In an area of Africa where there has been a long history of traditional and feudal thinking, this really is a remarkable effort by the Eritrean people. The other thing that was most marked about the philosophy of their revolution is that they do not use terms such as a Marxist or Leninist revolution. They do not look to the Soviet or Chinese examples or to any other examples. They are making their own revolution. A number of Eritreans I spoke to quite openly said that, when they achieve independence for their country, they will have a multiparty system, a pluralistic system, and a mixed economy. They will not follow the Soviet model, which they see as unsuitable for their circumstance. I point out that from 1962 to 1975 the Soviet Union was supportive of the EPLF, but when the Mengistu coup took place and Haile Selassie was overthrown in Ethiopia, Mengistu, the present leader, declared himself a communist, the Soviet Union swapped sides and is now supporting the Mengistu regime in its war against Eritrea. I will return to that matter in a moment.

One of the most intriguing and commendable aspects of the Eritrean revolution is the way the Eritreans have adopted the policy of equality for women. About 50 per cent of the population of Eritrea is of a Christian Coptic background, and the other 50 per cent is of a Moslem background. They are both very traditional societies with very traditional religions, in which women have been subservient through many centuries, yet they have adopted policies where women are guaranteed equal rights with men to own land, the right to divorce and the right to share in all aspects of the running of the society. This is seen, for example, in the fact that 30 per cent of the fighters at the front are women trained equally with men. From all accounts they are equally good fighters as men.

One of the things that for me were particularly marked was the fact that the Eritreans are educating their society on the issue of what some people in Australia would call female circumcision or female clitoridectomy. It is a practice which has been going on in this part of Africa for centuries. The EPLF, through education, has campaigned against this practice and has been very successful in both Moslem and Christian families in reducing the practice almost to non-existence. The Eritreans say that they do not force people to reject it and, if a family absolutely insists on the practice, they offer the opportunity to have the operation done medically by properly trained doctors and not by untrained people. That is an example of the extent of the revolution they have created in the way people think in that society.

I turn now to the war. When I went to Eritrea I was expecting to see a war of a guerilla nature in the traditional sense, and I was startled to find that the war is a conventional war. It is not fought by roving bands of guerillas in the hills; it is fought in a fully fledged conventional sense. One would have thought one was observing a war fought in North Africa or on the Russian front in the Second World War. Both sides have large numbers of tanks and heavy artillery, including rocket launchers called `Stalin organs' and heavy machine guns; large numbers of heavy trucks; all sorts of light armaments; and grenade throwers. The interesting thing is that all the EPLF arms have been captured from the Ethiopians, who have been supplied by the Soviet Union. It is estimated that in the last 10 or 12 years the Soviet Union has provided $4 billion to $5 billion worth of arms to Ethiopia, and large amounts of those armaments have been either destroyed in the fighting or captured. The EPLF does not rely on arms from any source other than what it captures, and it has certainly captured an enormous amount. Everywhere one goes in Eritrea one sees people carrying AK47s and Kalashnikov machine guns, all captured from the Soviet Union.

The EPLF soldiers and commanders have all learned their tactics on the job. None of them has been trained overseas, yet they are successfully conducting a conventional war. So successful is it that one of the great problems is that they now have over 12,000 Ethiopian prisoners of war in their charge. The Ethiopians refuse to have any discussions with them about repatriation because Mengistu describes the EPLF and the Eritreans as nothing but a bunch of bandits up in the hills.

I had the opportunity of inspecting a number of prisoner of war camps and walked freely amongst the Ethiopian prisoners. One of the most disturbing aspects about those prisoners of war is that most of them are conscripts and most of them are very young. We spoke to one prisoner who was only 15 years of age. At the age of 14 years, 12 months ago, he was attending high school in a southern province of Ethiopia when the Ethiopian Army arrived, surrounded the school with guns and trucks, and forcibly conscripted every boy 14 years of age and older straight into the Army. A number of these boys had only the most rudimentary training when they were put into action. The Eritreans said that some of those boys were so young that when the fighting started they cried for their mothers. They were terrified of the fighting in which they suddenly found themselves.

The Eritreans, though at considerable cost to themselves, ensure that they obey all the conventions of the Geneva Accord about the treatment of prisoners, despite the fact that the International Red Cross is very reluctant to have any discussion with the Eritreans about repatriation or the treatment of the prisoners because they recognise the Ethiopian Government, which does not recognise that there is a state of war. In my view the fact that the Eritreans are given little support is a very sad commentary. They would like to repatriate all these prisoners.

As I understand it, I was the first non-Eritrean to interview three Soviet prisoners of war who were captured in the battle of Afabet earlier this year. There were two colonels and a lieutenant who were military advisers to the Ethiopian Army. They were captured suddenly when the Eritreans had a successful operation to capture the town of Afabet. I spoke to the Soviet Embassy here on my return and gave the names of the two colonels and the lieutenant. For the record, they are Colonel Ivigne Cherivov, Colonel Yuri Kalestraton and Lieutenant Alexander Colvadir. In interviewing them I told them that I would attempt via the Soviet Embassy to pass a message back to the Soviet Union to let their families know that although they are prisoners of war they are in good health and being well looked after. I can certainly testify to that, and Thursday night's Channel 10 program that I mentioned earlier will show some film which demonstrates that they are in good health. The Eritreans do not want to keep them. They are quite willing to repatriate them to the Soviet Union, but the Soviet Union refuses to negotiate directly with the EPLF because that would create diplomatic difficulties, I presume, with the Mengistu regime in Addis Ababa. So, unless that impasse is broken, these three prisoners face a long period of being held in Eritrea.

One of the most disturbing features of the war-as I say, it is a conventional war-concerns the one area where the Ethiopians have superiority. They have a military air force, with many Mig fighter planes and light bomber planes supplied by the Soviet Union. These planes are used quite regularly to bomb not only the front line area where the battle is going on, but also Eritrean-controlled towns and farming areas, to try to destroy the food production capacity of the Eritreans. I visited the towns of Nacfa, which has been completely demolished by the bombing, and Afabet, which has been partly demolished by the bombing. While I was in the main street of Afabet I was able to inspect the wreckage of a shop which on 14 May was indiscriminately bombed by the Ethiopians. A bomb hit the shop and killed a woman and two children. They were civilians who had nothing to do with the war effort-and that is part of the tactics. While I was inspecting the wreckage I was able to collect a fragment of the bomb which killed these people. I seek leave to have this fragment of a Soviet-made 150-kilo bomb tabled in the Senate.

talk.start.para: —It is not possible to table objects, Senator Schacht. You have shown the item to the Senate and that is recorded in Hansard, so I think you have made your point.

—Thank you, Mr President. I realise it is not the normal thing to table but, if any member of the Senate wishes to have a look at it, it is available. I have brought back an extra fragment and at some suitable time I wish to make a presentation of it to the Soviet Ambassador to give him an example of some of the consequences of the Soviet policy in Ethiopia and Eritrea. As I mentioned, the bombing is used as a tactic of Ethiopian war policy, and one sees the consequences of this in a number of refugee camps. I visited a refugee camp of displaced persons at Filfil just outside Nacfa. It is a very rudimentary camp in a river valley where the people are living in very simple brush-made and stone-made huts. They are adequately supplied with food by the Eritrean Relief Association. Australian food aid has been donated by the Australian Government and delivered by non-government organisations (NGOs).

speech.para: While I was at that refugee camp I interviewed a woman called Amna Mohammed, 31 years of age, who came from a village called Sheb near Asmara. Her horrifying account of what happened to her only six months ago gives an idea of the extent of the cruelty of this war. She was in her village whilst her husband was in the hills with the goat herd. They are traditional peasants. Suddenly the Ethiopian army arrived in the village with tanks which immediately started running through the huts of the village, machine gunning people. Some accounts say that up to 400 people were massacred in a period of an hour or so. She lost a four-year-old son in the shooting. She and her two other children only survived because they lay on the ground with other children and pretended to be dead. At one stage two Ethiopian soldiers came near them and her two-year-old child started to cry. She was about to make that dreadful choice of whether she should stand up and protect the child. I suppose it is equivalent to that famous movie and book Sophie's Choice when one has to make a choice of sacrificing oneself or sacrificing a child. Fortunately, she was not forced into that situation because she heard one the Ethiopian soldiers say, `Don't waste a bullet on the baby. It will die of thirst anyway'. So the Ethiopian soldiers left. After they left, towards evening she, with her two remaining children and five other children whose parents had been massacred, with a container of a gallon of water, walked for two days and two nights to the EPLF controlled areas. I should also point out that she was seven months pregnant at the time. I suppose that in a world which is a bit inured to horror and cruelty the account of this woman is still particularly moving. Without doubt she appears to be one of the most courageous people I have ever met. I wanted to place her case in Hansard so that people can see the consequences of this war.

As I have mentioned Australian aid has been very well used in Eritrea. The Australian Government, through NGOs, has given aid to the Ethiopians and the Eritreans on a humanitarian basis to overcome the problems of famine. The fact is that with the large number of people displaced from their normal agricultural production there is not enough food being produced. Everywhere one goes in Eritrea, when one says that one is an Australian no matter whether they are the most limited educated peasants or whether they are part of the leadership of the EPLF, there is genuine regard for Australia in that we made the effort for a country which is far away from Australia to provide aid to keep people alive. I would like to pay compliments to a number of NGOs who have made their own efforts and to people like Dr Fred Hollows from Sydney. He is an expert in ophthalmology. He went to Eritrea for some two months. He passed on his experience to a number of Eritrean doctors about how to overcome the problems of blindness, particularly the problem of trachoma which is prevalent amongst some of the people of Eritrea. I think Australians can be proud that their aid has been so well used. The Eritrean Relief Association, from my observations-and I am not an expert on this-runs an extremely efficient system for the distribution of aid. There is no hint of corruption or of aid being lost or wasted. It is actually given and distributed to the people on the basis of need.

People have often mentioned that Africa gets afflicted with some of the famous biblical plagues. I had the opportunity to see the impact of a major locust plague at a place called Nacfa. I grew up on a farm in Australia and have seen a few grasshopper plagues in my time, but I have never seen anything as amazing as this locust plague. The locusts are about as big as a budgerigar or a canary. They came swarming over the hill like a dark brown cloud and when they were over the town they shaded the sun from the ground. Fortunately the wind was blowing and they blew past the farming areas of the town. But it was a chilling sight to see this extraordinary large swarm of locusts which is just one of many in north Africa. It is disappointing to note that the Ethiopians have refused to cooperate with a spraying program and have threatened to shoot down any plane that tries to spray the locust plague.

There are many other things I could mention about the efforts of the Eritrean people including their fantastic road building program, their health services, their education services and the underground factories which make shoes and sanitary napkins for women. This underground work is done at night but time does not allow me to continue on this subject as I do not want to delay the Senate too much. I have to admit that after visiting Eritrea I am biased. I am willing to support the Eritrean cause to get a political settlement. I think they have a just cause and I would only hope that the changes in Soviet foreign policy will lead to its putting pressure on Mengistu to reach a negotiated political settlement so that the killing and the war which is an enormous drain on both sides can stop.

In the last year I have had the opportunity not only to visit Eritrea but also, as I have reported previously to the Senate, to visit Kampuchea. These are two experiences which have made a great mark on me. In Kampuchea I saw the results of a revolution which turned in on itself and created one of the worst genocides in human history. It is an example of revolution that no one could support. In Eritrea I believe I saw a different example of a revolution. It is not just a revolution in the war sense but it is a revolution of the mind. I believe that is why there is much to commend it. It is why people like me, who have visited, can openly express support for the Eritrean people.

When we were in Eritrea we travelled most of the time by night because during the day there was a risk of getting bombed by Ethiopian Mig jets. Most of the time we travelled over rough roads for several hours. The week we were there was the time of the full moon. In the magnificent scenery of the Eritrean hills at midnight we experienced the most magnificent brilliant moonlight, the like of which I have never seen in Australia. I saw a society at work in this moonlight. I would suggest that one could call it the moonlight revolution. My thoughts will always be with the Eritreans. I suspect that whenever I see a full moon in Australia it will remind me that far away in the hills and valleys of Eritrea an amazing revolution is going on. My thoughts will go to the many Eritreans I have met. They were wonderful people who were dignified and committed to their cause. There are many of them whom I met and whom I would like to list but that would be far too many in the time available. I hope some day-as I said to them-to return to Eritrea, maybe in the not too distant future, and see the EPLF victory parade through Asmara when they achieve the independence that they so rightly deserve. I thank the Senate for giving me the opportunity to speak and put these remarks on the record.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.59 p.m.
